{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox film | name = Detroit | image = Detroit teaser poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Kathryn Bigelow]] | producer = {{Plainlist| * Kathryn Bigelow * [[Mark Boal]] * Matthew Budman * [[Megan Ellison]] * [[Colin Wilson (film producer)|Colin Wilson]] }} | writer = Mark Boal | based on = | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[John Boyega]] * [[Will Poulter]] * [[Algee Smith]] * [[Jacob Latimore]] * [[Jason Mitchell (actor)|Jason Mitchell]] * [[Hannah Murray]] * [[Kaitlyn Dever]] * [[Jack Reynor]] * Ben O'Toole * Nathan Davis Jr. * [[Peyton Alex Smith]] * [[Malcolm David Kelley]] * [[Joseph David-Jones]] * [[John Krasinski]] * [[Anthony Mackie]] <!-- PER POSTER BILLING BLOCK. --> }} | music = [[James Newton Howard]] | cinematography = [[Barry Ackroyd]] | editing = {{Plainlist| * [[William Goldenberg]] * Harry Yoon }} | production companies = {{Plainlist| * [[Annapurna Pictures]]<ref name=insight>{{cite web|url=https://www.varietyinsight.com/print_featurefilm_releases.php|title=Film releases|work=[[Variety Insight]]|accessdate=April 22, 2017}}</ref> * First Light Productions<ref name=insight/> * Page 1<ref name=insight/> }} | distributor = [[Annapurna Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|2017|7|26|[[Fox Theatre (Detroit)|Fox Theatre]]|2017|8|4|United States}} | runtime = 143 minutes<!-- Theatrical runtime: 142:48 --><ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/detroit-film | title=''DETROIT'' (15) | work=[[British Board of Film Classification]] | date=July 19, 2017 | accessdate=July 19, 2017}}</ref> | country = United States | language = English | budget = $34–40 million<ref name=BOM>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=detroit.htm|title=Detroit (2017)|publisher=[[Box Office Mojo]]|accessdate=August 31, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thewrap.com/welcome/2702210/single/~annapurna-upheaval-megan-ellison-reevaluating-film-division~/|title=Annapurna Upheaval: Megan Ellison Is ‘Reevaluating’ Film Division Amid Money Woes|publisher=[[TheWrap]]|date=October 10, 2018|accessdate=October 10, 2018}}</ref> | gross = $24.1 million<ref name=NUM>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movie/Detroit-(2017)#summary|title=Detroit (2017)|publisher=[[The Numbers (website)|The Numbers]]|accessdate=July 2, 2018}}</ref> }}
'''''Detroit''''' is a 2017 American [[Period film|period]] [[crime film|crime drama]] film directed by [[Kathryn Bigelow]] and written by [[Mark Boal]]. Based on [[The Algiers Motel Incident]] during Detroit's 1967 [[1967 Detroit riot|12th Street Riot]], the film's release commemorated the 50th anniversary of the event.<ref name=DFP>{{Cite news |last=Hinds |first=Julie |origyear=June 21, 2016 |date=June 22, 2016 |title=Detroit 1967 riot movie will film here—at least partly |url=http://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/movies/2016/06/21/movie-detroit-riots-1967-kathryn-bigelow-mark-boal-algiers-motel/85830068/ |work=[[Detroit Free Press]] |access-date=April 12, 2017 |language=en}}</ref> The film stars [[John Boyega]], [[Will Poulter]], [[Algee Smith]], [[Jacob Latimore]], [[Jason Mitchell (actor) | Jason Mitchell]], [[Hannah Murray]], [[Kaitlyn Dever]], [[Jack Reynor]], Ben O'Toole, Nathan Davis Jr., [[Peyton Alex Smith]], [[Malcolm David Kelley]], [[Joseph David-Jones]], with [[John Krasinski]] and [[Anthony Mackie]].
''Detroit'' premiered at the [[Fox Theatre (Detroit)|Fox Theatre]], [[Detroit]], on July 26, 2017, and began a limited theatrical release on August 4, 2017.<ref name="release">{{cite web|last1=Lesnick|first1=Silas|title=Annapurna Pictures Dates Kathryn Bigelow’s Untitled Detroit Project|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/805519-annapurna-pictures|website=[[ComingSoon.net]]|accessdate=January 20, 2017}}</ref> The film received positive reviews<!--I ask prospective editors to refrain from editing the directly preceding words before the issue is resolved on the talk page. I am beginning a new section there currently.--> from critics, with particular praise towards Bigelow's direction, Boal's screenplay and the performances of [[John Boyega]], [[Will Poulter]] and [[Algee Smith]]<ref name=reviews>{{cite news |title='Detroit': What other film critics are saying |url=http://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/movies/2017/07/27/detroit-film-critics-say/104033994/ |work=[[Detroit Free Press]] |date=July 27, 2017 |accessdate=July 28, 2017}}</ref><ref name=reviews2>{{cite web|url=https://editorial.rottentomatoes.com/article/dark-tower-condemned/|title=Dark Tower Condemned|first=Jeff|last=Giles|website=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]|date=August 3, 2017|accessdate=August 17, 2017}}</ref> but was a [[Box office bomb|box office failure]], only grossing $24 million against its $34 million budget.
== Plot == On July 23, 1967, the [[Detroit Police Department]] staged a raid on an [[Blind pig|unlicensed club]] during a celebration for returning black veterans from the [[Vietnam War]]. While suspects are being arrested, a mob forms and starts throwing rocks at the officers before looting nearby stores and starting fires, beginning the [[12th Street Riot]]. With state authorities, elected representatives, and even emergency services unable to maintain any semblance of order, Governor [[George W. Romney]] authorizes the [[Michigan Army National Guard]] and President [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] authorizes [[paratroopers#United States|Army paratroopers]] to enter Detroit in order to provide assistance. On the second day of rioting, two cops pursue a fleeing looter. One of them, Philip Krauss, kills the man with a shotgun against orders, but is allowed to remain on duty until his superiors can decide whether to file murder charges.
[[The Dramatics]], a professional black [[R&B]] group, arrive in Detroit hoping to score a recording contract. Seconds before their scheduled performance at a music hall, the police shut down the venue and order them to leave the city. En route, their bus is attacked by rioters and the group subsequently splits up, with lead singer Larry Reed and his friend Fred Temple renting a room at the local Algiers Motel for the night. They meet two white girls, Julie Ann and Karen, who introduce them to their friends Carl Cooper and Aubrey Pollard. Carl and another friend stage a prank using a [[Starting pistol|starter pistol]], upsetting Julie and Karen, who move to the room of Greene, a Vietnam War veteran, while Larry and Fred return to their own room.
Melvin Dismukes, a private [[security guard]], is assigned to protect a grocery store from looters and ingratiates himself with the Guardsmen. Carl decides to fire several blanks from his pistol in the direction of the troops to frighten them, but they mistake it for a [[sniper]] attack and pinpoint it coming from the Algiers due to the pistol's [[muzzle flash]]. The [[Michigan State Police]], National Guard, and Detroit Police arrive at the motel to investigate, led by Detroit police officer Krauss. Entering the building, they gun down Carl when he tries to escape, and Krauss plants a knife next to his body as he bleeds out and dies.
They round up everyone in the hotel and line them against the wall, demanding to know who the sniper was. Despite not finding any weapon during a search of the room, Krauss terrorizes and interrogates the occupants of the hotel. Dismukes arrives to try to help. Unwilling to get involved, most of the state police and National Guard leave without informing anyone of Krauss's abuse.
Krauss orders several suspects to be moved to different rooms and subjected to [[mock execution]]s in order to terrify the others into confessing. One police officer actually kills Aubrey, as he didn't understand the executions were supposed to be faked. Julie and Karen are taken to an upstairs room when they begin screaming, and Julie's clothes are torn off. Disgusted, a Guardsman returns, and manages to get them released from custody. Fearing arrest, Krauss permits the remaining suspects to leave, but only if they swear to keep silent. Greene and Larry agree, but Fred is killed when he refuses.
As the riots die down, Dismukes, while working his other job in a factory, is arrested and charged with murder after Julie identifies him as being present at the Algiers that night. Krauss and his fellow officers are questioned as well, and when everyone except Krauss confesses, they are also charged. Larry, whose singing career has stalled due to the trauma he experienced, is summoned as a witness to testify. The judge ultimately refuses to accept any of the confessions as evidence, and without a solid case, the all-white jury acquits Dismukes, Krauss, and their co-defendants of all charges. Dismukes confronts Krauss with the truth, but finds himself powerless to get any justice for the victims.
The film ends by explaining what became of the participants: Dismukes moved to the suburbs to escape death threats and resumed work as a security guard, Krauss and his men never returned to active duty, Julie rebuilt her life and started a family, and Larry became a choir singer and still lives in Detroit to the present day.
== Cast == {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[John Boyega]] as Melvin Dismukes * [[Will Poulter]] as Philip Krauss (based on David Senak) * [[Algee Smith]] as Larry Reed * [[Jacob Latimore]] as Fred Temple * [[Jason Mitchell (actor) | Jason Mitchell]] as Carl Cooper * [[Hannah Murray]] as Julie Ann Hysell * [[Kaitlyn Dever]] as Karen Malloy * [[Jack Reynor]] as Demens (based on Ronald August) * Ben O'Toole as Flynn (based on Robert Paille) * Nathan Davis Jr. as Aubrey Pollard * [[Peyton Alex Smith]] as Lee Forsythe * [[Malcolm David Kelley]] as Michael Clark * [[Joseph David-Jones]] as Morris * [[John Krasinski]] as Attorney Auerbach (based on Norman Lippitt) * [[Anthony Mackie]] as Karl Greene * [[Laz Alonso]] as [[John Conyers]], Jr. * [[Ephraim Sykes]] as Jimmy * [[Leon Thomas III]] as Darryl * [[Gbenga Akinnagbe]] as Aubrey Pollard, Sr. * [[Chris Chalk]] as Officer Frank * [[Jeremy Strong (actor)|Jeremy Strong]] as Attorney Lang * Austin Hébert as Warrant Officer Jack Roberts * [[Miguel (singer)|Miguel Pimentel]] as Malcolm * [[Samira Wiley]] as Vanessa * [[Tyler James Williams]] as Leon * Kris Sidberry as Roberta Pollard * Lizan Mitchell as Ma Pollard * Dennis Staroselsky as Detective Jones * Darren Goldstein as Detective Tanchuck * [[Chris Coy]] as Detective Thomas * [[Glenn Fitzgerald]] as Homicide Detective Anderson * [[Jennifer Ehle]] as a female doctor at the morgue * Cailyn Kemka as a nurse at the morgue * [[Karen Pittman]] as Melvin’s Mother * Zurin Villanueva as Martha Reeves * Morgan Taylor as Linda Tucker * Ato Blankson-Wood as Eddie Temple {{div col end}}
== Production == On January 28, 2016, it was announced that [[Kathryn Bigelow]] and [[Mark Boal]] would reteam to make a film about the [[1967 Detroit riot]]s, with Bigelow directing from a script by Boal.<ref name=Jan2016D>{{cite news|last1=Jr|first1=Mike Fleming|title=Kathryn Bigelow, Mark Boal Push Back Bowe Bergdahl For 1967 Detroit Race Riots Crime Drama Pic|url=http://deadline.com/2016/01/kathryn-bigelow-mark-boal-bowe-bergdahl-true-crime-drama-pic-1201692379/|accessdate=January 29, 2016|work=Deadline|date=January 28, 2016}}</ref> Both would also produce the film, along with [[Annapurna Pictures]]' [[Megan Ellison]] and Matthew Budman.<ref name="Jan2016D" /> ''[[Game of Thrones]]'' actress [[Hannah Murray]] was cast in a "key role" in the film, although her character was then being kept under wraps.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.slashfilm.com/kathryn-bigelow-hannah-murray/|title=Kathryn Bigelow Recruits ‘Game of Thrones’ Star Hannah Murray For Her Next Film}}</ref> The film was scheduled to shoot in the summer of 2016, in order to be released in 2017 for the 50th anniversary of the riots. On June 21, 2016, [[John Boyega]] joined the cast.<ref name="BoyegaCast">{{cite news|last1=Kit|first1=Borys|title=John Boyega Joins Kathryn Bigelow's Detroit Crime Drama (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/john-boyega-joins-kathryn-bigelows-905054|accessdate=June 22, 2016|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=June 21, 2016}}</ref> On August 3, 2016, [[Jack Reynor]], [[Will Poulter]], and Ben O'Toole were cast in lead roles.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kroll|first1=Justin|title=Kathryn Bigelow’s Detroit Riots Film Casts Will Poulter, Ben O’Toole, Jack Reynor (EXCLUSIVE)|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/kathryn-bigelow-detroit-riots-movie-will-poulter-jack-reynor-ben-otoole-1201823845/|work=Variety|date=August 3, 2016}}</ref> On August 4, 2016, [[Anthony Mackie]] joined the cast,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Fleming Jr.|first1=Mike|title= Anthony Mackie Reunites With ‘Hurt Locker’s Kathryn Bigelow, Mark Boal In Detroit Riots Pic|url=http://deadline.com/2016/08/anthony-mackie-kathryn-bigelow-mark-boal-detroit-riots-the-hurt-locker-1201798650/|work=Deadline.com|date=August 4, 2016}}</ref> and on August 5, 2016, [[Jacob Latimore]] and Algee Smith also joined.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kit|first1=Borys|last2=Ford|first2=Rebecca|title=Kathryn Bigelow's Detroit Riots Drama Adds Two Rising Stars (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/kathryn-bigelows-detroit-riots-drama-905111|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 5, 2016}}</ref> On August 8, 2016, [[Joseph David-Jones]] joined the cast,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/kathryn-bigelow-detroit-riots-movie-joseph-david-jones-1201832533/|title=Kathryn Bigelow’s Detroit Riots Film Casts ‘Legends of Tomorrow’s’ Joseph David-Jones|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|first=Dave|last=McNary|date=August 8, 2016|accessdate=August 8, 2016}}</ref> followed by [[Kaitlyn Dever]] on August 30, 2016.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Kit|first1=Borys|title=Kathryn Bigelow's Detroit Riot Drama Adds Kaitlyn Dever (Exclusive)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/kathryn-bigelows-detroit-riot-drama-924164|work=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 30, 2016}}</ref> On September 9, 2016, [[Jason Mitchell (actor)|Jason Mitchell]] joined the cast,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gettell|first1=Oliver|title=Jason Mitchell joins Kathryn Bigelow's Detroit riot drama|url=http://www.ew.com/article/2016/09/09/jason-mitchell-kathryn-bigelow-detroit-riot-drama|date=September 9, 2016|work=Entertainment Weekly}}</ref> and on September 13, 2016, [[John Krasinski]] was also added.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/john-krasinski-joins-kathryn-bigelows-928368|title=John Krasinski Joins Kathryn Bigelow's Detroit Race Drama (Exclusive)|website=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]|first=Borys|last=Kit|date=September 13, 2016|accessdate=September 13, 2016}}</ref> In October 2016, Jeremy Strong, [[Chris Chalk]], Austin Hébert, Ephraim Sykes, [[Laz Alonso]], Nathan Davis Jr., [[Malcolm David Kelley]], [[Peyton Alex Smith]], and [[Leon Thomas III]] all joined the cast of the film.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/news/kathryn-bigelow-detroit-riots-movie-cast-complete-1201892677/|title=Kathryn Bigelow Rounds Out Ensemble Cast for Detroit Riots Film (EXCLUSIVE)|website=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|first=Justin|last=Kroll|date=October 18, 2016|accessdate=October 18, 2016}}</ref>
===Filming=== It was reported at the end of July 2016 that the film had commenced [[principal photography]] in [[Boston]] during the previous week.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kathryn Bigelow’s Untitled Detroit Project, starring John Boyega, begins filming in Massachusetts|url=http://www.onlocationvacations.com/2016/07/29/kathryn-bigelows-untitled-detroit-project-starring-john-boyega-begins-filming-massachusetts/|date=July 29, 2016|work=On Location Vacations|accessdate=August 1, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Aurise|first1=Elana|title=Feature film shoots scenes on Ashmont Street|url=http://www.dotnews.com/2016/feature-film-shoots-scenes-ashmont-street|date=July 28, 2016|work=Dorchester Reporter|accessdate=August 1, 2016}}</ref> Scenes were filmed inside [[Dedham District Court]],<ref name=movie>{{cite news | url = http://patch.com/massachusetts/dedham/kathryn-bigelow-movie-be-filmed-dedham | title = Kathryn Bigelow Movie to be Filmed in Dedham | publisher = Dedham Patch | first = Daniel | last = Libon | date = August 20, 2016 | accessdate = August 20, 2016 }}</ref> in [[Dorchester, Massachusetts]] and in [[Brockton, Massachusetts]].<ref name=chester>{{cite news | title = Filming continues in Detroit-chester | url = https://www.bostonglobe.com/lifestyle/names/2016/08/19/filming-continues-detroit-chester/GY5DtKDwG1sNPrtGokNVjK/story.html | first = Emily | last = Sweeney | publisher = The Boston Globe | date = August 19, 2016 | accessdate = August 21, 2016}}</ref> In addition, the movie filmed in Detroit during October 2016. The elimination of Michigan's film incentives in 2015 affected the filming locations.<ref name=DFP/><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.freep.com/story/entertainment/movies/2016/10/04/detroit-riot-movie-kathryn-bigelow-mark-boal-motor-city-filming/91533922/|title=Detroit riot movie will film in Motor City this week|work=Detroit Free Press|access-date=April 13, 2017|language=en}}</ref>
===Post-production=== In May 2017, [[James Newton Howard]] was hired as the film's composer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://filmmusicreporter.com/2017/05/08/james-newton-howard-to-score-kathryn-bigelows-detroit/|title=James Newton Howard to Score Kathryn Bigelow’s ‘Detroit’|date=May 8, 2017|accessdate=May 8, 2017}}</ref> In July 2017, Detroit rapper [[Tee Grizzley]] released a song called "Teetroit" for the soundtrack.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefader.com/2017/07/28/tee-grizzley-teetroit|title=Tee Grizzley’s Urgent New Song "Teetroit" Might Radicalize You|date=July 28, 2017|accessdate=July 28, 2017}}</ref> [[The Roots]] and [[Bilal (American singer)|Bilal]] released a song named "It Ain't Fair" for the soundtrack.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2017/07/27/the_roots_and_bilal_reteam_for_a_stirring_new_song_from_the_movie_detroit.html|title=Listen to the Roots and Bilal’s Stirring New Song From the Detroit Soundtrack, “It Ain’t Fair”|first=Meeran|last=Karim|date=July 27, 2017|publisher=|via=Slate}}</ref>
==Release== ''Detroit'' began a limited release in 10 markets on July 28, 2017, opening in New York City, Los Angeles, Chicago, Dallas, Washington D.C., Detroit, San Francisco, Houston, Atlanta, and Baltimore.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/07/emoji-movie-atomic-blonde-dunkirk-detroit-weekend-box-office-1202136629/|title=‘Emoji Movie’ & ‘Atomic Blonde’ Vie To Take ‘Dunkirk’ Brigade Out At Box Office|publisher=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=July 26, 2017|accessdate=July 27, 2017}}</ref> [[Annapurna Pictures]] then released the film nationally, its first as a distributor, on August 4, 2017.<ref name="release"/> Annapurna handled the film's North American distribution, while [[Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer]] and [[Entertainment One]] handled distribution for its international release.<ref name=Variety>{{cite web|last=McNary|first=Dave|title=Bruce Willis’ ‘Death Wish’ Remake Lands November Launch With Annapurna|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/bruce-willis-death-wish-remake-annapurna-1202459109/|accessdate=June 8, 2017|newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=June 8, 2017}}</ref> On November 3, 2017, it was announced the film would get a ten city, 20 screen re-release on December 1, 2017 in an effort to push its award campaign.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/11/detroit-movie-back-in-theaters-kathryn-bigelow-new-trailer-1202200936/|title=Annapurna Puts Kathryn Bigelow-Directed ‘Detroit’ Back In Theaters For Limited Run: Watch New Trailer|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=November 3, 2017|accessdate=November 8, 2017}}</ref>
==Reception== ===Box office=== ''Detroit'' grossed $16.8 million in the United States and Canada and $7.3 million in other territories for a worldwide total of $24.1 million, against a production budget of $34 million.<ref name=NUM/>
In North America, ''Detroit'' grossed $350,190 in its limited opening from 20 theaters (an average of $17,510), finishing 16th at the box office.<ref name=limited>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/07/atomic-blonde-dunkirk-emoji-movie-weekend-box-office-openings-1202138047/|title=‘Dunkirk’ Marches Ahead Of ‘Emoji Movie’ For Top Spot With $28M+|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=July 30, 2017}}</ref> The film then had its wide expansion alongside ''[[Kidnap (2017 film)|Kidnap]]'' and ''[[The Dark Tower (2017 film)|The Dark Tower]]'', and was initially projected to gross $10–15 million from 3,007 theaters over the weekend.<ref name=preview>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/la-fi-ct-movie-projector-dark-tower-20170802-htmlstory.html|title=Sony's long-awaited 'Dark Tower' may unseat 'Dunkirk' with $25-million box-office premiere|website=''[[Los Angeles Times]]''|date=August 2, 2017}}</ref> The film made $525,000 from Thursday previews, which was more than the $515,482 it made in its entire week of limited release. It then made $2.6 million on its first day, lowering weekend projections to $7.5 million.<ref name=opening>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/08/the-dark-tower-detroit-kidnap-dunkirk-weekend-box-office-opening-1202142448/|title=‘The Dark Tower’ Opens To $18M+ In Diverse Marketplace: Was The Decade-Plus Battle To The Screen Worth It?|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=August 5, 2017}}</ref> It went on to open to $7.1 million, finishing 8th at the box office; 40% of its opening weekend audience were African American. [[Deadline Hollywood]] said that the film could have done better had it been released in the fall during festivals and awards season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/08/the-dark-tower-detroit-kidnap-weak-summer-box-office-weekend-1202143411/|title=‘The Dark Tower’ Is Tall Enough For No. 1 With $19.5M During Sluggish Summer Weekend|work=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=August 7, 2017}}</ref> In its second weekend the film grossed $2.9 million, dropping 59.5% (above average for an adult drama) and finishing in 13th.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/08/annabelle-creation-dark-tower-dunkirk-1202147007/|title='Annabelle: Creation' Comes Alive On Thursday With $4M|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|date=August 11, 2017}}</ref> In its third week of wide release the film was pulled from 1,579 theaters and grossed $850,000 (a drop of 70.9%).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://deadline.com/2017/08/hitmans-bodyguard-logan-lucky-annabelle-creation-august-box-office-opening-1202152509/|title='Hitman’s Bodyguard’ Flexes Muscle With $21M+ Opening During Sleepy Summer Weekend|first=Anthony|last=D'Alessandro|website=[[Deadline Hollywood]]|accessdate=August 20, 2017}}</ref>
===Critical response=== ''Detroit'' received praise for its direction, screenplay, and acting, especially Boyega, Poulter, and Smith's performances.<ref name=reviews/><ref name=reviews2/> On [[Rotten Tomatoes]], the film has an approval rating of 83% based on 260 reviews, and an [[average rating]] of 7.6/10. The website's critical consensus reads, "''Detroit'' delivers a gut-wrenching – and essential – dramatisation of a tragic chapter from America's past that draws distressing parallels to the present."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/detroit_2017 |title=Detroit (2017) |work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |publisher=[[Fandango Media|Fandango]] |accessdate=August 28, 2018}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], which assigns a normalized rating to reviews, the film has a weighted average score of 77 out of 100, based on 49 critics, indicating "generally favorable reviews".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/detroit |title=Detroit Reviews |publisher=[[CBS Interactive]]|work=[[Metacritic]]|accessdate=July 6, 2018}}</ref> Audiences polled by [[CinemaScore]] gave the film an average grade of "A−" on an A+ to F scale, while [[PostTrak]] reported filmgoers gave it an 86% overall positive score and a 63% "definite recommend".<ref name=opening/>
[[Richard Roeper]] of ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' gave the film 4 out of 4 stars and called it one of 2017's best, saying: "Journalist-screenwriter Mark Boal (Bigelow's collaborator on ''[[The Hurt Locker]]'' and ''[[Zero Dark Thirty]]'') does a magnificent job of juggling the multiple storylines and creating fully authentic characters—some flawed, some basically decent, some evil."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://chicago.suntimes.com/entertainment/roeper-tight-focus-intensifies-the-drama-of-riot-recap-detroit/ |title=Tight focus intensifies the drama of riot recap 'Detroit'|website=[[Chicago Sun Times]] |date=July 25, 2016|accessdate=July 27, 2017}}</ref> Writing for ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', [[Peter Travers]] praised the cast and script, giving the film 3.5/4 stars and saying, "... ''Detroit'' is far more than a liberal howl against the escalating toxicity of racism in America. Bigelow, with the same immersive intensity that [[Christopher Nolan]] brings to ''[[Dunkirk (2017 film)|Dunkirk]]'', smacks us down in the middle of a brutal historical event so we can see it – and feel it – for ourselves."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/peter-travers-detroit-will-leave-you-moved-scarred-w493733|title='Detroit' Review: Kathryn Bigelow's Recreation of Riots, Racism Is Cry of Rage |last=Travers |first=Peter |work=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=July 25, 2017 |accessdate=July 31, 2017}}</ref>
Conversely, Alexander Nazaryan of ''[[Newsweek]]'' said, "[Bigelow's] characters never come alive, moving through the film less as people than entries in a sociology textbook ... If Bigelow could get inside the minds of soldiers suffocated by post-traumatic stress disorder, as she did so capably in ''The Hurt Locker'', she can get into the mind of anyone. In ''Zero Dark Thirty'', she made even CIA interrogators likeable. The characters in ''Detroit'', though, black and white, are as flat as the plains of the Upper Midwest."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.newsweek.com/2017/07/28/kathryn-bigelow-detroit-race-riots-movie-review-642376.html |title=Kathryn Bigelow's 'Detroit' Is A Well-intentioned Misfire|website=[[Newsweek]] |date=July 26, 2016|accessdate=July 27, 2017}}</ref>
Several critics noted the film's questionable take on a predominantly African American-based story. [[A. O. Scott]] in ''[[The New York Times]]'' wrote, "It is curious that a movie set against a backdrop of black resistance and rebellion—however inchoate and self-destructive its expression may have been—should become a tale of black helplessness and passivity. The white men, the decent ones as much as the brutes, have the answers, the power, the agency."<ref>{{cite news |last1=Scott|first1=A.O. |title=In Detroit, Black Lives Caught in the Pre-History of the Alt-Right |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/26/movies/detroit-review.html|work=The New York Times }}</ref> K. Austin Collins of ''[[The Ringer (website)|The Ringer]]'' wrote, "This movie isn't really about black people as people, nor history as a lived experience, but is instead invested in a dutiful, 'just the facts, ma'am' reenactment that pretends those other things are already a given. Boal, and Bigelow beside him, refuse to speculate about — or imagine — the rest."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Collins |first1=K. Austin |date=July 28, 2017 |title='Detroit' Gives Us the Who, What, and Where, but Not the Why |url=https://theringer.com/detroit-film-review-kathryn-bigelow-john-boyega-4b4fbe64d509 |publisher=[[The Ringer (website)|The Ringer]] |access-date=August 2, 2017}}</ref>
''[[The New Yorker]]''{{'}}s Richard Brody called the film "a moral failure", saying: "[Bigelow's] intentions come through clearly: to depict an incident—and a climate—of racism, to show that the cruelty of these deeds was multiplied by their ultimate impunity, and to suggest that, in the intervening half-century since the events depicted in the film took place, little has changed. Movies aren’t made with intentions, though; they’re made with people and with equipment, and what Bigelow has her actors do for the benefit of the camera is repellent to imagine."<ref>{{cite web |last1=Brody |first1=Richard |date=August 27, 2017 |title=The Immoral Artistry of Kathryn Bigelow's 'Detroit' |url=http://www.newyorker.com/culture/richard-brody/the-immoral-artistry-of-kathryn-bigelows-detroit |publisher=[[The New Yorker (website)|The New Yorker]] |access-date=August 27, 2017}}</ref>
===Accolades=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! scope="col"| Award ! scope="col"| Date of ceremony ! scope="col"| Category ! scope="col"| Recipient(s) ! scope="col"| Result ! scope="col"| {{Abbr|Ref.|References}} |- | rowspan="4"| [[Black Reel Awards]] | rowspan="4"| February 22, 2018 | Outstanding Film | ''Detroit'' | {{nom}} | rowspan="4"| <ref>[http://blackreelawards.com/get-out-dominate-the-black-reel-awards/ Get Out Dominates the Black Reel Awards] Black Reel Awards. 13 December 2017.</ref><ref>[http://blackreelawards.com/get-out-sinks-the-competition-at-the-black-reel-awards/ Get Out “Sinks” the Competition at The Black Reel Awards] Black Reel Awards. 23 February 2018.</ref> |- | Outstanding Actor, Motion Picture | [[Algee Smith]] | {{nom}} |- | Outstanding Ensemble | [[Victoria Thomas]] | {{nom}} |- | Outstanding Score | [[James Newton Howard]] | {{nom}} |- |rowspan="5"| [[49th NAACP Image Awards|NAACP Image Awards]] |rowspan="5"| January 15, 2018 | [[49th NAACP Image Awards#Motion Picture|Outstanding Motion Picture]] | ''Detroit'' | {{nom}} | |- | Outstanding Actor in a Motion Picture | Algee Smith | {{nom}} | |- | Outstanding Writing in a Motion Picture | [[Mark Boal]] | {{nom}} | |- | Outstanding Independent Motion Picture | Detroit | {{won}} | |- |}
==Historical accuracy== According to Melvin Dismukes, who is depicted prominently in the film, ''Detroit'' "is 99.5% accurate as to what went down at the Algiers and in the city at the time."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2017/film/news/detroit-melvin-dismukes-interview-1202511170/|title=‘Detroit’ Subject Melvin Dismukes on What Kathryn Bigelow Film Gets Right|first=Brent|last=Lang|date=August 1, 2017|publisher=}}</ref> However, the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' wrote that "Bigelow does say there are moments of fiction, and Boal notes instances of 'pure screenwriting.' Some facts are contested within accounts; others were changed for the screen" and then raised the question "Does a disclaimer at the end sufficiently cover fictional manipulations in an ostensibly true story?"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/la-ca-mn-detroit-bigelow-20170727-story.html|title=Kathryn Bigelow's 'Detroit' takes on a tragedy then — and now - Los Angeles Times|first=Steven|last=Zeitchik|website=latimes.com}}</ref> [[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] went so far as to state that Bigelow and Boal "changed names [of characters] so as to enjoy other creative liberties in the storytelling."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/does-detroit-risk-a-lawsuit-real-life-cops-1026426|title=Does 'Detroit' Risk a Lawsuit From Real-Life Cops?|publisher=}}</ref> One such subject whose name was dropped in favor of a fictional one is lawyer Norman Lippitt (played in the film by actor [[John Krasinski]] under the name Auerbach).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20170722/news/634586/lawyer-who-earned-fame-defending-detroit-police-in-algiers-motel-case|title=Lawyer who earned fame defending Detroit police in Algiers Motel case recalls legacy|website=Crain's Detroit Business}}</ref>
In response to the historical criticism, Boal said, "I employed poetic license, under a self-imposed rule to never stray from what I understood to be the underlying truth of a scene or an event. This script is built on a sturdy base of journalism and history, but it is not the same as journalism or history, nor does it aspire to be. As a screenwriter, I take the responsibility of being the creator of a tale, of transforming these raw materials into a drama."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historyvshollywood.com/reelfaces/detroit/|title=Detroit Movie vs. the True Story of the Algiers Motel Killings|publisher=}}</ref>
==See also== *[[List of black films of the 2010s]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.detroit.movie/}} * {{IMDb title|5390504|Detroit}} * {{AllRovi title|662944|Detroit}} * {{Mojo title|detroit|Detroit}} * {{Metacritic film|detroit|Detroit}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|detroit_2017|Detroit}}
{{Kathryn Bigelow}}

revision.comment: spelling cleanup
revision.text:
'''Ecovention''' was a term invented by Amy Lipton and [[Sue Spaid]] in 1999 to refer to an [[ecological art]] intervention in environmental degradation.<ref>http://www.eyebeam.org/ecovention-current-art-to-transform-ecologies Eyebeam "Current Art to Transform Ecologies."</ref> The Ecovention movement in art is associated with [[land art]], earthworks, and [[environmental art]], and [[landscape architecture]], but remains its own distinct category. Many ecoventions bear tendencies similar to public works projects such as sewage and waste-water treatment plants, public gardens, landfills, mines, and sustainable building projects.<ref>http://greenmuseum.org/c/ecovention/sect1.html#landart Greenmuseum.org Ecoventions</ref>
The term ‘Ecovention’ appears by the composition of the terms 'ecology' and 'innovation' or 'intervention'. The intention was to concrete a kind of art that alludes to the interventions that artists were made in degraded natural territories, pretending to generate a public consciousness, showing the existence of solutions<ref>{{cite book|last1=MARÍN RUIZ|first1=Carmen|title=‘Arte medioambiental y ecología. Elementos para una reflexión crítica.’|date=2014|page=42}}</ref>. The fact of restoring make the artists enter in a collaboration process with the nature in a social way. They help to generate a new paradigm teaching how art could help the society not only in a social or political criticism, but getting directly involved in the world. They are responsible for extending the various environmental principles and practices to the community.
Artists will focus on various aspects like: biological, cultural, political or historical. <ref>{{cite web|title=Ecovention: current art to transform ecologies.|url=http://greenmuseum.org/c/ecovention/sect11.html|website=Greenmuseum}}</ref> At the same time, different professionals work that are fundamental; architects, botanists, zoologists, engineers, ecologists... all based on the imaginative idea of an artist<ref>{{cite book|last1=MARÍN RUIZ|first1=Carmen|title=‘Arte medioambiental y ecología. Elementos para una reflexión crítica.’|date=2014|page=98}}</ref> 4. Activism, the re-evaluation of territories, the study of diversity and the recovery of spaces will be some of its main characteristics. To carry them out, they use new techniques in order to transform that local ecology in order to reestablish natural resources and stabilize environments. His works have as a common goal to motivate the viewer to visit these spaces generating awareness and in turn encourage more interventions.
Artists associated with ecovention include: [[Joseph Beuys]], [[Mel Chin]], [[Agnes Denes]], Helen and Newton Harrison, Ocean Earth, [[Robert Smithson]], Alan Sonfist, and [[Mierle Laderman Ukeles]], among others.
==Exhibitions== ''Ecovention'' is also the title of a 2002 exhibition at the ''Cincinnati [[Contemporary Arts Center]]'' in [[Ohio]],<ref>{{cite book|title=Ground works : environmental collaboration in contemporary art.|date=2005|publisher=Carnegie Mellon University|location=Pittsburgh, PA|isbn=978-0-9772053-1-8|page=21|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ffYQeG4MrRAC&lpg=PA21&dq=%22Ecovention%22%20lipton&pg=PA21#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> and the title of exhibition catalog, joint published with the Greenmuseum.<ref>http://greenmuseum.org/c/ecovention/intro_frame.html Greenmuseum.org. Contemporary Arts Center.</ref> It was considered the definitive text on ecological art for several years and the only text available for teaching the topic at the college and University level.<ref>{{cite book|last=editor|first=Kim Kennedy White, editor ; Leslie A. Duram, contributing|title=America goes green : an encyclopedia of eco-friendly culture in the United States|date=2013|publisher=ABC-CLIO|location=Santa Barbara|isbn=978-1-59884-657-7|page=67|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=thVO3Bjbt0UC&lpg=PA67&dq=%22Ecovention%22&pg=PA67#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref><ref>Kagan, Sacha "Art and Sustainability; Connecting Patterns for a Culture of Complexity. Bielefeld: transcript Verlag, 2011."</ref>
Other major exhibitions apart from the CAC's "Ecovention" exhibition include: "Earth Art" (1969) at [[Cornell University]], "Elements of Art: Earth, Air and Fire" (1971) at Boston's Museum of Fine Arts, "Earthworks: Land Reclamation as Sculpture" (1979) at the [[Seattle Art Museum]], and "Fragile Ecologies" (1992) curated by Barbara Matilsky at the [[Queens Museum of Art]].<ref>Green acres. Artist farming fields, greenhouses and abandoned lots. 2012. Ithaca: Worldwide Books.</ref><ref>Song, Young Imm Kang. 2009. "Community Participatory Ecological Art and Education". International Journal of Art & Design Education. 28 (1): 4-13.</ref>
There is a new exhibition, Ecovention Europe, planned to open in the Fall of 2017. The show is also curated by Sue Spaid, and will feature a new text furthering the conversation around what an "Ecovention" is. The show will be held at the Museum De Domijnen in Sittard, Netherlands.<ref>http://www.dedomijnen.nl/exposities/exposities-hedendaagse-kunst/ecovention-europe/</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{cite book|last=Spaid|first=Sue|title=Ecovention : current art to transform ecologies|date=2002|publisher=Greenmuseum.org|location=[S.l.]|isbn=978-0-917562-74-7 |OCLC=50491550}} *[http://www.landviews.org/la2003/ecoventions-ss.html ''Ecoventions qua an Arendtian Account of Freedom, Action and Miracles.'' Sue Spaid.]
==External links== *[http://greenmuseum.org/ Greenmuseum.org]
[[Category:Environmental art]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1) ([[User:Balon Greyjoy|Balon Greyjoy]])
revision.text:
'''FedEx furniture''' is the artistic creation of computer programmer and [[creative consumer]] Jose Avila, III. In June, 2005, Avila created a website, Fedexfurniture.com, to display photographs of a couch, bed, dining room table, and desk that he had constructed out of cartons obtained from overnight shipping giant [[FedEx Corporation]] (FedEx). FedEx attorneys used the [[Notice and take down|takedown]] provisions of the [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act]] (DMCA) to force Avila's [[Internet service provider|ISP]] to take the site offline, accusing Avila of infringing on FedEx's [[copyright]]s and [[trademark]]s, breaching his [[contract]] with FedEx by using the cartons for purposes other than shipping, and potentially misleading consumers into believing that FedEx approved or endorsed Avila's actions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Berthon|first=Pierre R.|last2=Pitt|first2=Leyland F.|last3=McCarthy|first3=Ian|last4=Kates|first4=Steven M.|date=2007-01-01|title=When customers get clever: Managerial approaches to dealing with creative consumers|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0007681306000796|journal=Business Horizons|volume=50|issue=1|pages=39–47|doi=10.1016/j.bushor.2006.05.005}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Berthon|first=Pierre|last2=Pitt|first2=Leyland|last3=Kietzmann|first3=Jan|last4=McCarthy|first4=Ian P.|date=2015-08-01|title=CGIP: Managing Consumer-Generated Intellectual Property|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1525/cmr.2015.57.4.43|journal=California Management Review|language=en|volume=57|issue=4|pages=43–62|doi=10.1525/cmr.2015.57.4.43|issn=0008-1256}}</ref> Among attorneys and activist organizations concerned with the exercise of [[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] rights on the [[Internet]], FedEx's actions raised questions about the [[constitutionality]] of using the DMCA to [[censorship|censor]] unwanted speech. The Fedexfurniture.com website is down as of July 8th, 2017.
==The story==
In 2005, Avila moved to Tempe, Arizona with nothing more than clothes and work essentials. He was still stuck in a lease on his California apartment, and could barely afford his new apartment in Arizona.
After a bit of frustration over not having furniture, Avila remembered that a former roommate had solved a similar problem by constructing furniture using FedEx cartons. Using hundreds of FedEx boxes and materials that he "already had lying around" for shipping various items, Avila constructed every piece of furniture in his apartment. Avila's designs were sturdy and attractive. Friends urged Avila to put pictures of the furniture on a Web site.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Berthon|first=Pierre|last2=Pitt|first2=Leyland|last3=Kietzmann|first3=Jan|last4=McCarthy|first4=Ian P.|date=2015-08-01|title=CGIP: Managing Consumer-Generated Intellectual Property|url=https://doi.org/10.1525/cmr.2015.57.4.43|journal=California Management Review|language=en|volume=57|issue=4|pages=43–62|doi=10.1525/cmr.2015.57.4.43}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Berthon|first=Pierre R.|last2=Pitt|first2=Leyland F.|last3=McCarthy|first3=Ian|last4=Kates|first4=Steven M.|date=2007-01-01|title=When customers get clever: Managerial approaches to dealing with creative consumers|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0007681306000796|journal=Business Horizons|volume=50|issue=1|pages=39–47|doi=10.1016/j.bushor.2006.05.005}}</ref> According to Avila, he did so in order to show that trying financial circumstances need not lead to despair; one can respond creatively, even artistically, by using "found" materials.{{ref|ffstory}} The site's message was "It's OK to be ghetto".{{ref|counterthink}}
The site subsequently attracted widespread attention, both from Web surfers and the press. Because the site was getting so much traffic, Avila placed a PayPal donation link on the page and asked for help to pay for the bandwidth charges. He also announced a plan to sell Fedexfurniture.com T-shirts, although Avila says that no T-shirts were ever sold.{{ref|ffstory}}
On June 27, 2005, FedEx attorneys wrote to Avila's [[Internet service provider|ISP]]. Citing the takedown provisions of the [[Digital Millennium Copyright Act]] (DMCA), they demanded that the ISP remove Avila's materials from the Web.{{ref|takedownnotice}} They justified their request on two grounds: *Infringement of FedEx's [[intellectual property]] (specifically, [[copyright]]s and [[trademark]]s.) *Violation of FedEx's [[terms of use]] for packaging supplies.
In order to take advantage of the [[Safe harbor (law)|safe harbor]] provisions of the DMCA, Avila's ISP complied with the request and removed Avila's materials from the Web. Had the ISP not done so, it could have been held liable for [[contributory copyright infringement|contributory infringement]] (aiding and abetting the infringer) if Avila's materials were subsequently found to be infringing in a court of law.
FedEx's actions concerned Internet free speech activist organizations, such as [[Stanford University|Stanford University's]] [[Stanford Center for Internet and Society|Center for Internet and Society]], which are concerned about the use of the DMCA's takedown provisions to [[censorship|censor]] unwanted speech. According to these organizations, the DMCA's purpose is to prevent Internet copyright infringement; it was never Congress's intent that the DMCA's takedown provisions should be used when the real issue is [[trademark infringement]] or [[breach of contract]].{{ref|fairuse}}
A Stanford attorney, [[Jennifer Granick]], assisted Avila on a [[pro bono]] basis. In her letter to FedEx, she disputed the use of the DMCA to remove Avila's site from the Web; she argued that the company's claim of [[copyright infringement]] had no merit; therefore, FedEx should not have used the DMCA to silence Avila's speech. The company's underlying motivations, she argued, were to protect its [[trademark]] and ability to place restrictions on public use of its cartons.{{ref|stanford}} Avila restored his site briefly. The dispute attracted widespread press attention, and Avila was frequently interviewed to tell his side of the story. In response to Granick's letter, FedEx attorneys reiterated their claims. Subsequently, Avila removed his site from the Web, citing technical difficulties. By January 2006, Avila's site had returned, however, by June 30, 2006 the site had again disappeared. This was caused by a server crash, and as of July 27, 2006 it was back online, but as of August 16, 2007 the site is gone. It popped up again in October 2007, but is currently down (July 8, 2017).
==See also== *[[Chilling effect (term)|Chilling effect]] *[[Conversion (law)|Conversion]] *[[Copyright]] *[[Copyright infringement]] *[[Digital Millennium Copyright Act]] (DMCA) *[[First Amendment to the United States Constitution|First Amendment]] *[[Free speech]] *[[Lanham Act]] *[[Online Copyright Infringement Liability Limitation Act]] *[[Trademark dilution]] *[[Trademark law]]
==References== {{Reflist}} #{{note|ffstory}} [http://fedexaminer.com/FedEx/modules.php?name=FedExFurniture The Fedexfurniture Story]. #{{note|counterthink}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20060422151845/http://www.counterthink.org/011583.html CounterThink, "Free Speech Under Attack (August 11, 2005)]. #{{note|takedownnotice}} [http://www.chillingeffects.org/copyright/notice.cgi?NoticeID=2117 FedEx takedown notice]. Also see [http://fedexaminer.com/documents/FedExLetter235.pdf FedEx to Via Internet, June 27, 2005]. #{{note|fairuse}} Marjorie Heins and Tricia Beckels (2005), [http://www.fepproject.org/policyreports/WillFairUseSurvive.pdf "Will Fair Use Survive? Free Expression in the Age of Copyright Control"]. New York, NY: Brennan Center for Justice, New York University School of Law. #{{note|stanford}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20051125030640/http://cyberlaw.stanford.edu/archives/CIS%20letter.pdf Stanford Center for Internet & Society to FedEx, August 9, 2005]. #{{note|blog}} [http://pop-pr.blogspot.com/2005/08/fedex-speaks.html "FedEx Speaks!]. #{{note|mattel}}353 F.3d 792 ( 9th Circuit, 2003).
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050628000042/http://fedexfurniture.com/ fedexfurniture.com] @ web.archive.org * [http://yro.slashdot.org/article.pl?sid=05/08/11/1715204&from=rss Slashdot thread about Fedexfurniture.com] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060426070020/http://www.counterthink.org/013109.html Corporate censorship vs. free speech]. An interesting discussion of the pros and cons of Avila's actions. * [http://pop-pr.blogspot.com/2005/08/fedex-speaks.html FedEx Speaks!] Contains a balanced look with an interview of both FedEx and an IM interview with Avila. * [https://www.wired.com/culture/lifestyle/news/2005/08/68492 Furniture Causes FedEx Fits] Wired News story on the site and controversy, including interviews with Avila and his lawyer.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Fedex Furniture}} [[Category:Art websites]] [[Category:2005 in law]] [[Category:Digital Millennium Copyright Act takedown incidents]] [[Category:FedEx|Furniture]]

revision.comment: updated broken links
revision.text:
[[File:Alfred Stieglitz (American - The Steerage - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Alfred Stieglitz|Alfred Stieglitz's]] photograph ''[[The Steerage]]'' (1907) was an early work of artistic modernism, and considered by many historians to be the most important photograph ever made.<ref>{{cite book|last=Winters|first=Dan|title=Road to Seeing|date=2014|publisher=New Riders|isbn=978-0-13-315420-7|pages=563–564|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NmD6AgAAQBAJ&pg=PT256#v=onepage&q&f=false}}</ref> Stieglitz was notable for introducing fine art photography into museum collections.]]
'''Fine Art Photography''' is [[photography]] created in accordance with the vision of the artist as a photographer. Using photography as a medium to bring something to life that only lives in the artist's mind. Simply capturing what you see in an artistic way is the art of photography and not creating fine art. The goal is to express an idea, a message, or an emotion. Fine art photography stands in contrast to representational photography, such as photojournalism, which provides a documentary visual account of specific subjects and events, literally representing objective reality rather than the subjective intent of the photographer; and commercial photography, the primary focus of which is to advertise products or services.
==List of definitions== Here is a list of definitions of the related terms "art photography", "artistic photography", and "fine art photography".
===In reference books=== Among the definitions that can be found in reference books are: * "Art photography": "Photography that is done as a fine art -- that is, done to express the artist's perceptions and emotions and to share them with others".<ref name=McDarrah>McDarrah, Gloria S., et al. ''The photography encyclopedia''. New York: Schirmer, 1999. {{ISBN|0-02-865025-5}}</ref> * "Fine art photography": "A picture that is produced for sale or display rather than one that is produced in response to a commercial commission".<ref name=Hope>Hope, Terry. ''Fine art photography: creating beautiful images for sale and display''. Mies, Switzerland: RotoVision, 2003. {{ISBN|2-88046-724-1}}</ref> * "Fine art photography": "The production of images to fulfill the creative vision of a photographer. ... Synonymous with art photography".<ref name=Lynch-Johnt>Lynch-Johnt, Barbara, and Michelle Perkins. ''Illustrated dictionary of photography: the professional's guide to terms and techniques''. Buffalo, NY: Amherst Media, 2008. {{ISBN|978-1-58428-222-8}}</ref> * "Art photography": A definition "is elusive," but "when photographers refer to it, they have in mind the photographs seen in magazines such as ''American Photo'', ''Popular Photography'', and ''Print'', and in salons and exhibitions. Art (or artful) photography is salable.".<ref name=Engh>Engh, Rohn. ''Sell & re-sell your photos'', 5th ed. Cincinnati, Ohio: Writer's Digest Books, 2003. {{ISBN|1-58297-176-5}}</ref> * "Artistic photography": "A frequently used but somewhat vague term. The idea underlying it is that the producer of a given picture has aimed at something more than a merely realistic rendering of the subject, and has attempted to convey a personal impression".<ref>Jones, Bernard E. ''Cassell's cyclopaedia of photography''. New York: Arno, 1973. {{ISBN|0-405-04922-6}}</ref> * "Fine art photography": Also called "decor photography," or "photo decor," this "involves selling large photos... that can be used as wall art".<ref name=Engh/>
===In scholarly articles=== Among the definitions that can be found in scholarly articles are: * In 1961, [[S. D. Jouhar|Dr S. D.Jouhar]] founded the Photographic Fine Art Association, and he was its chairman. Their definition of Fine Art was “Creating images that evoke emotion by a photographic process in which one's mind and imagination are freely but competently exercised.”<ref>{{cite journal |last=Jouhar |first=Sultan |date=October 1964 |title=The Work of Dr. Jouhar |url=https://archive.rps.org/archive/volume-104/742322 |journal=The Royal Photographic Society Journal |volume=104 |issue=10 |page=261}}</ref> * Two studies by Christopherson in 1974 defined "fine art photographers" as "those persons who create and distribute photographs specifically as 'art.'"<ref>Christopherson, Richard W. Making Art With Machines: Photography's Institutional Inadequacies. ''Urban Life and Culture'', Vol. 3, No. 1, April 1974, pages 3-34.</ref><ref>Christopherson, Richard W. From Folk Art To Fine Art: A Transformation in the Meaning of Photographic Work. ''Urban Life and Culture'', Vol. 3, No. 2, July 1974, pages 123-157.</ref> * A 1986 [[Ethnography|ethnographic]] and [[History|historical]] study by Schwartz did not directly define "fine art photography" but did compare it with "camera club photography".<ref name=Schwartz>Schwartz, Dona. [http://sjmc.cla.umn.edu/faculty/schwartz/contents/Camera_clubs/camera_clubs.html Camera clubs and fine art photography: the social construction of an elite code.] Originally published in ''Urban Life,'' vol. 15, no. 2 (July 1986), pp.165-195.</ref> It found that fine art photography "is tied to other media" such as painting; "responds to its own history and traditions" (as opposed to "aspir[ing] to the same achievements made by their predecessors"); "has its own vocabulary"; "conveys ideas" (e.g., "concern with form supersedes concern with subject matter"); "is innovative"; "is personal"; "is a lifestyle"; and "participates in the world of commerce."<ref name=Schwartz/>
===On the World Wide Web=== Among the definitions that can be found on the [[World Wide Web]] are: * The [[Library of Congress]] [[Library of Congress Subject Headings|Subject Headings]] use "art photography" as "photography of art," and "artistic photography" (i.e., "Photography, artistic") as "photography as a fine art, including aesthetic theory".<ref>Library of Congress. [http://authorities.loc.gov/cgi-bin/Pwebrecon.cgi?DB=local&PAGE=First Authority headings search.] Retrieved August 6, 2008.</ref> * The [[Art & Architecture Thesaurus]] states that "fine art photography" (preferred term) or "art photography" or "artistic photography" is "the movement in England and the United States, from around 1890 into the early 20th century, which promoted various aesthetic approaches. Historically, has sometimes been applied to any photography whose intention is aesthetic, as distinguished from scientific, commercial, or journalistic; for this meaning, use 'photography'".<ref>Getty Research Institute. [http://www.getty.edu/vow/AATFullDisplay?find=art+photography&logic=AND&note=&english=N&prev_page=1&subjectid=300178594 Art photography.] Art & Architecture Thesaurus Online. Retrieved August 6, 2008.</ref> * Definitions of "fine art photography" on photographers' static Web pages vary from "the subset of fine art that is created with a camera"<ref>Beck, Stephen G. [http://www.sgbphotography.com/articles/What_Is_Fine_Art_Photography.aspx What Is Fine Art Photography?] Retrieved August 6, 2008.</ref> to "limited-reproduction photography, using materials and techniques that will outlive the artist".<ref>Steinman, Jan. [http://www.bytesmiths.com/News/n0012.php Bytesmiths Editions Newsletter December 2000.] Retrieved August 6, 2008.</ref>
==History== [[File:Aktikompositsioon 19 (J. Künnap).jpg|thumb|Depiction of [[nudity]] has been one of the dominating themes in fine-art photography. ''Nude composition 19'' from 1988 by [[Jaan Künnap]].]] One photography historian claimed that "the earliest exponent of 'Fine Art' or composition photography was [[John Jabez Edwin Mayall|John Edwin Mayall]], "who exhibited [[daguerrotype]]s illustrating the [[Lord's Prayer]] in 1851".<ref>Gernsheim, Helmut. ''Creative photography: aesthetic trends 1839-1960''. New York: Dover, 1991. {{ISBN|0-486-26750-4}}</ref> Successful attempts to make fine art photography can be traced to [[Victorian era]] practitioners such as [[Julia Margaret Cameron]], [[Charles Lutwidge Dodgson]], and [[Oscar Gustave Rejlander]] and others. In the U.S. [[F. Holland Day]], [[Alfred Stieglitz]] and [[Edward Steichen]] were instrumental in making photography a fine art, and Stieglitz was especially notable in introducing it into museum collections.
In the UK as recently as 1960, photography was not really recognised as a Fine Art. Dr [[S.D.Jouhar]] said, when he formed the Photographic Fine Art Association at that time - ''"At the moment photography is not generally recognized as anything more than a craft. In the USA photography has been openly accepted as Fine Art in certain official quarters. It is shown in galleries and exhibitions as an Art. There is not corresponding recognition in this country. The London Salon shows pictorial photography, but it is not generally understood as an art. Whether a work shows aesthetic qualities or not it is designated 'Pictorial Photography' which is a very ambiguous term. The photographer himself must have confidence in his work and in its dignity and aesthetic value, to force recognition as an Art rather than a Craft"''
Until the late 1970s several genres predominated, such as nudes, portraits, and natural landscapes (exemplified by [[Ansel Adams]]). Breakthrough 'star' artists in the 1970s and 80s, such as [[Sally Mann]], [[Robert Mapplethorpe]], [[Robert Farber (photographer)|Robert Farber]] and [[Cindy Sherman]], still relied heavily on such [[genre]]s, although seeing them with fresh eyes. Others investigated a [[snapshot aesthetic]] approach.
American organizations, such as the [[Aperture (magazine)|Aperture Foundation]] and the [[Museum of Modern Art]], have done much to keep photography at the forefront of the fine arts. MOMA's establishment of a department of photography in 1940 and appointment of [[Beaumont Newhall]] as its first curator are often cited as institutional confirmation of photography's status as an art.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Phillips |first1=Christopher |title=The Judgment Seat of Photography |journal=October |date=Autumn 1982 |volume=22 |doi=10.2307/778362 |jstor=778362 }}</ref>
==Framing and print size== Until the mid-1950s it was widely considered vulgar and pretentious to frame a photograph for a gallery exhibition. Prints were usually simply pasted onto blockboard or plywood, or given a white border in the darkroom and then pinned at the corners onto display boards. Prints were thus shown without any glass reflections obscuring them. Steichen's famous [[The Family of Man]] exhibition was unframed, the pictures pasted to panels. Even as late as 1966 [[Bill Brandt]]'s MoMA show was unframed, with simple prints pasted to thin plywood. From the mid-1950s to about 2000 most gallery exhibitions had prints behind glass. Since about 2000 there has been a noticeable move toward once again showing contemporary gallery prints on boards and without glass. In addition, throughout the twentieth century, there was a noticeable increase in the size of prints.
[[File:Adams The Tetons and the Snake River.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Ansel Adams]]' ''The Tetons and the Snake River'' (1942).]]
==Politics== Fine art photography is created primarily as an expression of the artist’s vision, but as a byproduct it has also been important in advancing certain causes. The work of [[Ansel Adams]] in [[Yosemite]] and [[Yellowstone]] provides an example. Adams is one of the most widely recognized fine art photographers of the 20th century, and was an avid promoter of conservation. While his primary focus was on photography as art, some of his work raised public awareness of the beauty of the [[Sierra Nevada (U.S.)|Sierra Nevada]] and helped to build political support for their protection.
Such photography has also had effects in the area of censorship law and free expression, due to its concern with the nude body.
==Current trends== [[File:Gursky Shanghai.jpg|thumb|left|Andreas Gursky, ''Shanghai'', 2000, C-print mounted to plexiglass, 119 x 81 inches]] There is now a trend toward a careful staging and lighting of the picture, rather than hoping to "discover" it ready-made. Photographers such as [[Gregory Crewdson]], and [[Jeff Wall]] are noted for the quality of their [[Tableaux Vivant|staged]] pictures. Additionally, new technological trends in digital photography have opened a new direction in [[full spectrum photography]], where careful filtering choices across the ultraviolet, visible and infrared lead to new artistic visions.
As printing technologies have improved since around 1980, a photographer's art prints reproduced in a finely-printed limited-edition book have now become an area of strong interest to collectors. This is because books usually have high production values, a short print run, and their limited market means they are almost never reprinted. The collector's market in photography books by individual photographers is developing rapidly.
According to [http://press.artprice.com/pdf/Trends2004.pdf ''Art Market Trends 2004''] (PDF link) 7,000 photographs were sold in auction rooms in 2004, and photographs averaged a 7.6 [[percent]] annual price rise from 1994 and 2004.{{Failed verification|date=October 2008}} Around 80 percent were sold in the United States. Of course, auction sales only record a fraction of total private sales. There is now a thriving collectors' market for which the most sought-after art photographers will produce high quality archival prints in strictly limited editions. Attempts by online art retailers to sell fine photography to the general public alongside prints of paintings have had mixed results, with strong sales coming only from the traditional "big names" of photography such as Ansel Adams.
In addition to the "digital movement" towards manipulation, filtering, or resolution changes, some fine artists deliberately seek a "naturalistic," including "natural lighting" as a value in itself. Sometimes the art work as in the case of [[Gerhard Richter]] consists of a photographic image that has been subsequently painted over with oil paints and/or contains some political or historical significance beyond the image itself. The existence of "photographically-projected painting" now blurs the line between painting and photography which traditionally was absolute.
==Overlap with other genres== Although fine art photography may overlap with many other genres of photography, the overlaps with [[fashion photography]] and [[photojournalism]] merit special attention.
In 1996 it was stated that there had been a "recent blurring of lines between commercial illustrative photography and fine art photography," especially in the area of fashion.<ref name=Bryant>Bryant, Eric. Review of ''Fashion: Photography in the Nineties''. ''Library Journal'', February 15, 1997, p.131.</ref> Evidence for the overlap of fine art photography and fashion photography includes lectures,<ref>[https://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/catherine-atherton-the-fine-art-of-fashion-photography-673645.html Catherine Atherton: The fine art of fashion photography. From a talk given at the Museum of Modern Art by the senior lecturer in art, publishing and music at Oxford Brookes University.] ''The Independent'', June 12, 2001. Retrieved October 21, 2008.</ref> exhibitions,<ref>[http://www.moma.org/exhibitions/2004/fashion_fiction.html Fashioning fiction in photography since 1990.] Museum of Modern Art, April 16 - June 28, 2004. Retrieved August 6, 2008.</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |last=Naves |first=Mario |date=April 23, 2004 |title=Striking poses: is fashion photography art? |url=http://www.slate.com/id/2099336/ |magazine=Slate |access-date=August 6, 2008}}</ref><ref>[http://www.sva.edu/sa/index.jsp?sid0=201&page_id=482&event_id=642 Click chic: the fine art of fashion photography.] School of Visual Arts, September 6, 2007 - October 6, 2007. Retrieved August 6, 2008.</ref> trade fairs such as [[Art Basel]] Miami Beach,<ref>{{cite news |last=Trebay |first=Guy |date=December 6, 2007 |title=Work with me, baby |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/12/06/fashion/06photo.html |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=August 6, 2008}}</ref> and books.<ref name=Bryant/><ref>{{cite book |last= |first= |year=1991 |title=The idealizing vision: the art of fashion photography |location=New York |publisher=Aperture Foundation |isbn=0-89381-462-8}}</ref>
Photojournalism and fine art photography overlapped beginning in the "late 1960s and 1970s, when... news photographers struck up liaisons with art photography and painting".<ref name=Goldberg>Goldberg, Vicki. Picture this - magazine photography, in just a few decades, has changed the way life itself is regarded. ''Life'' magazine, April 15, 1999.</ref> In 1974 the [[International Center of Photography]] opened, with emphases on both "humanitarian photojournalism" and "art photography".<ref name=Goldberg/> By 1987, "pictures that were taken on assignments for magazines and newspapers now regularly reappear[ed] - in frames - on the walls of museums and galleries".<ref>{{cite news |last=Grundberg |first=Andy |date=April 12, 1987 |title=Art; photojournalism lays claim to the realm of esthetics |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9B0DE1D9133EF931A25757C0A961948260 |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=August 6, 2008}}</ref>
New smartphone apps such as [[Snapchat]] sometimes are used for fine-art photography.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://stevegiovinco.com/while-i-watch-my-father-die-photography-exhibition-on-snapchat-explores-memory-emotional-vanishing/|title=While I Watch My Father Die: Photography Exhibition on Snapchat Explores Memory, Emotional Vanishing {{!}} Fine Art Photography, Commissions, NYC Teaching Tutorials Steve Giovinco|website=stevegiovinco.com|access-date=2017-01-10}}</ref>
==Attitudes of artists in other fields== The reactions of artists and writers have contributed significantly to perceptions of photography as fine art. Prominent painters, such as [[Francis Bacon (artist)|Francis Bacon]] and [[Pablo Picasso]], have asserted their interest in the medium:
{{quote|I have discovered photography. Now I can kill myself. I have nothing else to learn.|Pablo Picasso}}
{{quote|I have always been very interested in photography. I have looked at far more photographs than I have paintings. Because their reality is stronger than reality itself.|Francis Bacon.}}
Noted authors, similarly, have responded to the artistic potential of photography:
{{quote|...it does seem to me that [[Robert Capa|Capa]] has proved beyond all doubt that the camera need not be a cold mechanical device. Like the pen, it is as good as the man who uses it. It can be the extension of mind and heart...|[[John Steinbeck]]}}
==See also== {{Portal|Photography}} * [[Fine art]] * [[List of photographers]] * [[Photography studies]] * ''[[Tableau vivant]]''
==References==
===Notes=== {{Reflist|2pppp}}
===Further reading=== {{Commons|Art Photography}} * Thompson, Jerry L. ''Truth and photography: notes on looking and photographing''. Chicago: Ivan R. Dee, 2003. {{ISBN|1-56663-539-X}} * Bright, Susan. ''Art photography now''. New York: Aperture, 2005. {{ISBN|1-931788-91-X}} * Peres, Michael R. ed. ''The Focal encyclopedia of photography: digital imaging, theory and applications, history, and science''. 4th edition. Amsterdam & Boston: Elsevier/Focal Press, 2007. {{ISBN|978-0-240-80740-9}} * [[Naomi Rosenblum|Rosenblum, Naomi]]. ''A world history of photography''. 4th edition. New York: Abbeville Press, 2007. {{ISBN|978-0-7892-0937-5}} * [[Marco Fodde|Fodde, Marco]]. ''Fotografia Fine Art''. 1st edition. Milano: Apogeo La Feltrinelli, 2012. {{ISBN|978-88-503-1397-6}}
==External links== * [http://americanhistory.si.edu/1896/index.htm The 1896 Washington Salon & Art Photographic Exhibition] An exhibition in Washington, D.C., more than a century ago played a major role in the establishment and acceptance of art photography in America (from the National Museum of American History).
{{photography subject|state=collapsed}}

{{notability|organisations|date=January 2016}} {{unreferenced|date=January 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox company |name = The Friends of Dorothy Society (fods) |logo = [[Image:Fods.gif|fods|200px|The Friends of Dorothy Society]] |type = Bellringing Society |foundation = 1991 |founder = [[John Paul Adams]] |location = UK based |homepage = [http://www.thefods.info/ www.thefods.info] }}
'''The Friends of Dorothy Society''' (commonly abbreviated "'''fods'''") is a [[bell ringing]] society for [[LGBT]] people and their friends. The society is based in the United Kingdom but has members throughout the world; particularly in the United States of America and Australia.
The Society takes its name from the euphemism [[Friend of Dorothy]], meaning [[gay]] man.
== History ==
The society started following a notice placed in ''[[The Ringing World]]'' (a weekly publication for bell ringers) in May 1991. The notice aimed to assemble a band to ring for the [[Pride London|London Pride Festival]] that year.
A number of people responded to the notice and the bells of [[St. Martin in the Fields]], [[Trafalgar Square]] were rung for that year’s parade.
== Tours ==
The society holds a spring tour and an autumn tour each year. The first tour was to [[Bristol]] in October 1991. Since then, members of the society have toured many cities throughout the United Kingdom. The first international tour was held in May 2006 when members visited [[Washington DC]].
{| class="wikitable" border="1" |+ The Society's Tours ! Year !! Date !! Location |- |1991 || 11-13 Oct || Bath & Bristol |- |1992 || 28 Feb - 1 Mar || Manchester |- |1992 || 20-22 Nov || Brighton |- |1993 || 26-28 Feb || Nottingham |- |1994 || 25-27 Feb || London |- |1994 || 28-30 Oct || Newcastle |- |1995 || 27-29 Oct || Blackpool |- |1996 || 24 Feb || Basingstoke |- |1996 || 25-27 Oct || York |- |1997 || 21-23 Feb || Manchester |- |1997 || 25-26 Oct || Birmingham |- |1998 || Oct || Gloucester |- |1999 || Oct || Liverpool |- |2000 || 26 Feb || Petersfield |- |2000 || 27-29 Oct || Newcastle |- |2001 || 2-4 Mar || Cardiff |- |2001 || 19-21 Oct || Leeds |- |2002 || 9-11 Feb || Northern Ireland |- |2002 || 18-20 Oct || Birmingham |- |2003 || 7-9 Feb || Southampton |- |2003 || 17-19 Oct || York |- |2004 || 27-29 Feb || Shrewsbury |- |2004 || 15-17 Oct || Edinburgh |- |2004 || 19-20 Nov || Leicester |- |2005 || 4 - 6 Mar || Coventry |- |2005 || 21-23 Oct || Canterbury |- |2006 || 10-12 Feb || Nottingham |- |2006 || 25 May - 4 Jun || Washington DC, Philadelphia & New York |- |2006 || 20-22 Oct || Exeter |- |2007 || 23-25 Feb || Manchester |- |2007 || 26–28 May || Boston MA, USA |- |2007 || 28-30 Sep || Oxford |- |2008 || 22-24 Feb || Reading |- |2008 || 16-19 Oct || Dublin |- |2009 || 27 Feb-1 Mar || Bristol |- |2009 || 25-27 Sep || Liverpool |- |2010 || 19-21 Feb || Worcester |- |2010 || 10-12 Sep || Cambridge |- |2011 || 18-20 Feb || Leeds |- |2011 || 14-16 Oct || London |}
==References== <references/>
== Today ==
The society’s membership is ever-increasing. Peals are rung several times each year. There are annual spring and autumn tours and the society rings for [[Pride London|London Pride]] and [[Brighton Pride]].
==External links== *[http://www.thefods.info fods official website](incorrect link)
{{LGBT |culture=yes}}

{{Orphan|date=December 2015}} The '''Gabriel Prize''' is an award given annually by the Western European Architectural Foundation, through a three-stage national competition, to one American candidate working in the field of [[architecture]] or [[landscape architecture]]. Results are announced in March of each year. Award winners spend three months in residence in [[France]], focusing on a particular aspect of [[French architecture]] they have chosen to research. They spend much of their [[sabbatical]] traveling, sketching and measuring, and in the course of three months, produce three large [[Architectural rendering|rendering]]s. The laureates work closely with the foundation's European representative, a [[Paris]]ian architect who serves to assist their progress. The Prize was founded in 1991 by George Parker, Jr.{{cite web|url=http://www.gabrielprize.org/ |title=Gabriel Prize |publisher=Gabriel Prize |date= |accessdate=2011-12-12}} ==List of Winners== 2017 - Barbara Worth Ratner {{cite web|url=http://www.architectmagazine.com/design/the-western-european-architecture-foundation-announces-the-2017-gabriel-prize-winner_o|title=The Western European Architecture Foundation Announces the 2017 Gabriel Prize Winner |publisher=Architect Magazine |date= |accessdate=2017-07-10}}
2016 - Marcela Delgado
2015 - Stephanie Arrienda Jazmines
2014 - Nicholas Quiring
2013 - Stephanie Bower
2012 - Daria Khapalova
2011 - Simon David{{cite web|url=http://www.arch.virginia.edu/spotlight/Gabriel2011/ |title=UVa School of Architecture | Alumnus Simon David Wins Gabriel Prize |publisher=Arch.virginia.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-12-12}}
2010 - George J. Martin{{cite web|url=http://publicaffairs.cua.edu/releases/2010/10GabrielPrize.cfm |title=CUA news |publisher=Publicaffairs.cua.edu |date=2010-03-03 |accessdate=2011-12-12}}
2009 - Jay Cantrell{{cite web|url=http://www.arch.virginia.edu/news/390 |title=UVa School of Architecture | Jason "Jay" Cantrell Awarded The Gabriel Prize from W.E.A.F |publisher=Arch.virginia.edu |date=2009-03-10 |accessdate=2011-12-12}}
2008 - Riggs Pearson Skepnek
2007 - Joyce Rosner{{cite web|url=http://www.utexas.edu/news/2007/03/05/architecture/ |title=School of Architecture Lecturer Awarded $17,500 Gabriel Prize for Study in France | News |publisher=Utexas.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-12-12}}
2006 - Mario C. Cortes{{cite web|url=http://www.vtnews.vt.edu/articles/2006/03/2006-146.html |title=Architecture professor Mario Cortes wins international Gabriel Prize | Virginia Tech News | Virginia Tech |publisher=Vtnews.vt.edu |date=2006-03-24 |accessdate=2011-12-12}}
2005 - [[Michael Reardon (architect)|Michael Reardon]]
2004 - Victor Agran
2003 - David E. Gamble{{cite web |url=http://www.gsd.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/faculty/details.cgi?faculty_id=1481 |title=Harvard Design School Faculty - internal |publisher=Gsd.harvard.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-12-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819114119/http://www.gsd.harvard.edu/cgi-bin/faculty/details.cgi?faculty_id=1481 |archivedate=2010-08-19 |df= }}
2002 - Alexander Fernandez
2001 - Richard Chenoweth{{cite web|url=http://www.chenarch.com/gabriel.html |title=architecture |publisher=Chenarch.com |date= |accessdate=2011-12-12}}
2000 - Mireille Roddier
1999 - Melissa Weese Goodill
1999 - Erik Thorkildsen
1998 - Alexander Ortenberg
1997 - Ron Witte
1996 - Stephen W. Harby
1995 - C. Errol Barron, Jr.
1994 - Stephen A. Bross
1993 - Kimberly R. Kohlhaas
1993 - David T. Mayernik{{cite web|url=http://www.nd.edu/~dmayerni/ |title=Prof. David Mayernik |publisher=Nd.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-12-12}}
1992 - Amy E. Gardner
1991 - Ralph Jackson == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * [http://www.gabrielprize.org/pages/gabriel_prize.php] [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Architecture awards]]
