{{Infobox government agency |agency_name = Ghana Open Data Initiative |type = |nativename = |nativename_a = |nativename_r = |logo = Ghana Open Data Initiative logo.png |logo_width = |logo_caption = Ghana Open Data Initiative |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |picture = |picture_width = |picture_caption = |formed = {{Start date|2012|01}} |preceding1 = |preceding2 = <!-- (etc.) --> |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = [[Government of Ghana]] |headquarters = [[Accra]] |coordinates = <!--{{coord|LATITUDE|LONGITUDE|type:landmark_region:US|display=inline,title}}--> |motto = |employees = |budget = |minister1_name = |minister1_pfo = |minister2_name = |minister2_pfo = <!-- (etc.) --> |deputyminister1_name = |deputyminister1_pfo = |deputyminister2_name = |deputyminister2_pfo = <!-- (etc.) --> |chief1_name = Mr. Kwaku Ofosu-Adarkwa |chief1_position = Steering Committee Chair |chief2_name = Prof. [[Nii Narku Quaynor]]<ref name="GODI1" /> |chief2_position = Steering Committee Co-Chair |chief3_name = [[Mr. William Tevie]]<ref name="GODI1" /> |chief3_position = Project Director |chief4_name = Mr. Eric Akumiah<ref name="GODI1" /> |chief4_position = Project Manager |chief5_name = Mr. Wisdom Donkor<ref name="theafricareport" /> |chief5_position = Technical Lead & Open Data Evangelist <!-- (etc.) --> |agency_type = |parent_department = |parent_agency = [[National Information Technology Agency]] |child1_agency = |child2_agency = <!-- (etc.) --> |keydocument1 = <!-- (etc.) --> |website = {{URL|data.gov.gh}} |footnotes = |map = |map_width = |map_caption = }}
'''Ghana Open Data Initiative''' ('''GODI''') was started in January 2012 by the [[National Information Technology Agency]] (NITA) in partnership with the [[Web Foundation]] (WF), to make [[Ghana|Government of Ghana]] data available to the public for re-use. The establishment of GODI is meant to promote [[efficiency]], [[transparency (behavior)|transparency]] and [[accountability]] in governance as well as to facilitate economic growth by means of the creation of Mobile and Web applications for the Ghanaian and world markets. The project was scheduled for completion in 2014 and aimed to create a sustainable Open Data ecosystem for Ghana. GODI was launched with a 100 data sets categorized as political, legal, organizational, technical, social or economic. The vision of GODI is to develop an open data community involving the Government of Ghana, civil society organizations, industry, developer communities, academia, media practitioners, and the citizenry, to interact with one another with the aim of developing an open data portal to bring about transparency, accountability and efficiency in government.<ref name="GODI1">{{cite web|url=http://www.ghana.gov.gh/index.php/news/general-news/17132-open-government-data-portal-ready-by-december-2013 |title=Open Government Data Portal Ready By December 2013 |author=GNA |date=October 24, 2012 |work= |publisher=ghana.gov.gh |accessdate=May 29, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304030605/http://www.ghana.gov.gh/index.php/news/general-news/17132-open-government-data-portal-ready-by-december-2013 |archivedate=March 4, 2016 |df= }}</ref><ref name="BIZTECH">{{cite web |url=http://www.biztechafrica.com/article/godi-project-get-us-tech-support/4605/?country=ghana |title= GODI project to get US tech support |author= BiztechAfrica|date= November 3, 2012 |work= |publisher= biztechafrica.com |accessdate=June 2, 2013}}.</ref><ref name="GODIsite">{{cite web|url=http://data.gov.gh/about-us |title=About GODI |author=GODI |date= |work= |publisher=data.gov.gh |accessdate=May 29, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130818061103/http://data.gov.gh/about-us |archivedate=August 18, 2013 |df= }}.</ref><ref name="webfoundation">{{cite web |url= http://www.webfoundation.org/2012/02/ghana-godi-launch/|title= New Project: Ghana Open Data Initiative (GODI)|author= José M. Alonso|date= Feb 1, 2012 |work= |publisher=World Wide Web Foundation |accessdate=June 2, 2013}}.</ref>
== History == At the close of 2011, the president of the Republic of Ghana, [[John Atta Mills|His Excellency Prof. J.E. Mills]], signed the [[Open Government Partnership]] (OGP), a global initiative started by the [[United States government]].<ref name="theafricareport" /><ref name=" BIZTECH " /><ref name=" vibegh " /><ref name="BIZGH">{{cite web |url=http://www.ghanabusinessnews.com/2012/11/22/ghanas-open-data-portal-goes-live/feed/|title= Ghana’s open data portal goes live|author= GNA|date= November 22, 2012 |work= |publisher= ghanabusinessnews.com |accessdate=May 29, 2013}}.</ref> The [[Open Government Partnership|OGP]] is a new multilateral initiative that aims to secure concrete commitments from governments to promote transparency, empower citizens, fight corruption, and harness new technologies to strengthen governance. In the spirit of multistakeholder collaboration, the [[Open Government Partnership|OGP]] is overseen by a steering committee of governments, [[civil society]] organizations, [[academia]] and the [[Software developer|developer community]].<ref name="theafricareport">{{cite web |url=http://www.theafricareport.com/West-Africa/ghana-sets-up-open-data-platform.html |title= Ghana sets up Open Data platform |author=Lawrence Quartey |date= November 22, 2012 |work= |publisher= theafricareport.com |accessdate=June 2, 2013}}.</ref><ref name=" webfoundation " /><ref name="vibegh">{{cite web |url=http://vibeghana.com/2012/11/01/us-data-team-visits-ghana/ |title= US Data team visits Ghana|author= GNA |date= November 1, 2012 |work= |publisher= vibeghana.com |accessdate=June 2, 2013}}.</ref>
Prior to Ghana signing onto the [[Open Government Partnership|OGP]], the [[Web Foundation|World Wide Web Foundation]] (WF) had conducted feasibility studies in Ghana and Chile as special case studies for developing countries and published the report in February 2011. On the basis of the feasibility report, the [[National Information Technology Agency]] (NITA), an agency of the Ministry of Communications, which was created by an Act of Parliament to oversee and implement government policy on [[Information and Communication Technology]] (ICT), began discussions with the WF in April 2011 on how to develop an open government portal in Ghana.<ref name=" webfoundation " /><ref name=" theafricareport" /><ref name=" GODIsite " /><ref name="ISTO">{{cite web |url=http://www.ist-africa.org/home/default.asp?page=news-doc-by-id&docid=6259 |title=Ghana launches Open Data Platform |author=ISTO |date=November 1, 2012 |work= |publisher=vibeghana.com |accessdate=June 2, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160807043959/http://www.ist-africa.org/home/default.asp?page=news-doc-by-id&docid=6259 |archivedate=August 7, 2016 |df= }}.</ref>
[[National Information Technology Agency|NITA]] over the last three years has been deploying a massive government network dubbed the GovNET across the country and data centers which will be repositories of Government data. NITA has also been mandated to engage the citizenry with government by providing [http://eservices.gov.gh/ e-Services] platforms to serve the citizenry with services like online passport application, business and birth and death registration which NITA is executing with 11 pilot e-service platforms.<ref name=" webfoundation " /><ref name=" ISTO " />
On the initial signing of the [[Open Government Partnership|OGP]] commitment by the embassy of Ghana in the US in September 2011, [[National Information Technology Agency|NITA]] intensified its discussions with the WF on developing a national plan to create an open data portal where government could make its data available in a format that [[Civil society|civil society organizations]] (CSOs), the [[International development|developer community]], [[academia]], the [[Mass media|media]] and [[industry]] could re-use.<ref name=" theafricareport" /> These discussions culminated in a visit to Ghana by a team from the WF during which a strategic plan was developed at a formal stakeholders’ meeting which took place in Accra, where the initiative was duly launched. The visiting WF team and [[National Information Technology Agency|NITA]] officials paid a courtesy call on the then Vice President [[John Mahama|His Excellency John Dramani Mahama]] to invite him to champion the Ghana Open Data Initiative.
== Relevance of open government data to Ghana == Open government data is particularly important to low and middle income countries like Ghana because: * Transparency and accountability are critical dimensions for foreign aid and investments, which in turn is essential for social and economic development. The potential of ICT in developing countries to provide basic services in health, education, business and governance has been highlighted for more than a decade by the [[World Summit on Information Society|WSIS]]. * Easy access to government-held data reduces risks and transaction costs in the economic sector, thus reducing barriers to growth. * Citizen inclusion and participation in government agenda have been historically low in developing countries, particularly due to lack of information and infrastructure. Increasing such citizen participation has proven to be essential for the establishment of stable democratic processes. * Data on government services is capable of attracting groups and organizations to form communities whose activities can improved social capital and economic growth.
== Development of GODI ==
=== Executive level === The WF feasibility report indicated that the Government of Ghana has the political will to make information transparently available to its citizens. In January 2012, then vice president of Ghana, [[John Mahama]], informed a delegation from the WF that he was committed to championing the GODI at the cabinet level.
=== Public administration level === The feasibility report of the WF indicated that government departments and agencies are in support of OGD initiatives. Substantial information is already available in digital format; however end user access still remains on paper which imparts negatively on the access and reuse of information. Since January 2012 when the GODI started, several public administrators have indicated their willingness to provide data in the format required to contribute to the project.
=== Civil society level === The WF feasibility report indicated that there is already a movement towards reuse of information driven by organizations like the Population Council as well as universities that are advocating the access to raw data for their studies.
== Organogram == [[File:GODI Project Organogram.jpg]]
== Implementation == The [[National Information Technology Agency]] (NITA) is the implementing agency for the [http://www.data.gov.gh/ Ghana Open Data Initiative] (GODI).<ref name=" webfoundation " /><ref name=" theafricareport" /><ref name=" GODIsite " /> The GODI portal was developed on the fourth thematic area of the [[Open Government Partnership]].
The objectives of the GODI project are to: * Provide a central platform for access to public government data. * Bring about the development of the open data community. * Promote participation between government, civil society organizations, academia, media practitioners, industry, developer community and the citizen. * Serve as a concrete action plan of the fourth thematic area of the Open Government Partnership (technology and innovation) for the republic of Ghana. * Promote transparency, accountability and efficiency in government through citizen feedback.
== Benefits == Ghana’s decision to create an open data portal was informed by the fact the [[Open Data|Open Government Data]] (OGD) programs around the world have demonstrated multiple benefits. GODI perceives that Ghana can gain all the benefit of open data which are grouped around three main themes:
=== Transparency and accountability === * Increased transparency of governments * Greater accountability of officials by citizens being able to see and challenge individual spending and purchasing decisions * Behaviour change due to the possibility of greater scrutiny * Better understanding by civil society of the reasons for government decisions * Better democracy and increased civic capital * Better informed and balanced journalism; i.e. [[data journalism]]
=== Improved public services === * Increased number of services to people due to an increased base of potential service providers * New synergies among government, public administration and civil society organizations * Increased citizen participation and inclusion through extended offers of services closer to people’s needs * Closer cooperation between central and local government * Increased internal government efficiency and effectiveness
=== Economic growth === * New business opportunities for services to businesses and citizens using government data * Better functioning of the economy through easy access to core reference information held by the government * Increased employment for application and service developers * New innovative uses of [[Open Data|OGD]] that can help spur innovation and development in the IT sector
== References == {{Reflist|2}}
== External links == * [http://nita.gov.gh/ NITA website] * [http://data.gov.gh/ GODI website]
{{Ministries and Agencies in Ghana}}
[[Category:Open data]] [[Category:Access to Knowledge movement]] [[Category:Open content]] [[Category:Public domain]] [[Category:Science and technology in Ghana]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2012]]

revision.text:
{{no footnotes|date=August 2011}}
'''Gorm Henrik Rasmussen''' (born 1955) is a Danish poet who wrote the first biography about the guitarist and singer-songwriter [[Nick Drake]], ''Pink Moon'' (1986). The book is based upon interviews Gorm Henrik Rasmussen made with Nick Drake's parents, Rodney and [[Molly Drake]], in their home in [[Tanworth-in-Arden]], [[Warwickshire]], England, in 1979 and 1980. ''[http://rocket88books.com/2012/01/27/pink-moon/ Pink Moon]'' was re-written and translated into English in 2009. In 2012, it became the launch title for [http://rocket88books.com/ Rocket 88], a new music book imprint of [http://www.essentialworks.co.uk/ Essential Works]. A Spanish version has also appeared in 2012.
Gorm Henrik Rasmussen is known in Denmark for a number of books about eccentrics and strange places in the [[northern part of Jutland]] where he was born and raised. He has received several literary awards from [[The Danish Arts Foundation]] and The Danish Arts Council.
== References == <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}} *[[Trevor Dann|Dann, Trevor]]: ''Darker than the Deepest Sea'', DaCapo Press: London, 2006: 166, 207-8 *[[Gabrielle Drake|Drake, Gabrielle]] & Cally Callomon: ''Remembered for a While'', John Murray: London, 2014, p. 419-422.
== External links == * [http://www.litteraturpriser.dk/aut/RG.htm#RGormHenrikRasmussen List of awards from litteraturpriser.dk] * [http://www.algonet.se/~iguana/DRAKE/NDunrel.html The Nick Drake Files] * [http://www.tannforsen.com/nickdrake/media.asp?intId=36 nickdrake.net] * [http://rocket88books.com/2012/01/27/pink-moon ''Pink Moon: A Story about Nick Drake'' published by Rocket 88, a music book imprint of Essential Works] * [http://rocket88books.com/2012/02/29/mojo-magazine-review-of-pink-moon-a-story-about-nick-drake Review in Mojo of ''Pink Moon: A Story about Nick Drake''] * [http://reviews.libraryjournal.com/2012/03/collection-development/books-for-dudes/books-for-dudes Review in Library Journal of ''Pink Moon: A Story about Nick Drake''] * [http://gaffa.dk/anmeldelse/58029 Review in Gaffa of ''Pink Moon: A Story about Nick Drake'']
{{authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rasmussen, Gorm Henrik}} [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:Danish male writers]] [[Category:Arts in Denmark|Literature]] [[Category:Danish biographers]] [[Category:Male biographers]] [[Category:Articles created via the Article Wizard]] [[Category:Living people]]

revision.text:
[[File:Prayer Bead with the Adoration of the Magi and the Crucifixion MET DP371962.jpg|thumb|"[[Prayer Bead with the Adoration of the Magi and the Crucifixion]]", height (open): 11.2cm,<ref>"[http://www.metmuseum.org/toah/works-of-art/17.190.475/ Rosary Bead 1500–1510]". New York: Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved 25 November 2018</ref> South Netherlandish. 1500–1510. [[The Cloisters]], New York]] [[File:Half of a Prayer Bead with the Lamentation.jpg|thumb|340px|"Half of a Prayer Bead with the Lamentation", height: 3cm, Netherlandish, early 16th century. Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York]]
'''Gothic boxwood miniatures''' are very small [[wood carving|carved wood]] [[Christian]] religious sculptures produced during the 15th and 16th centuries, mostly in [[Early Netherlandish painting|today's Low Countries]], at the end of the [[Gothic art|Gothic period]] of [[Northern Renaissance|northern European art]].<ref name="es">Sharpe, Emily. "[https://www.theartnewspaper.com/news/good-things-come-in-small-packages-at-the-rijksmuseum Good things come in small packages at the Rijksmuseum]". ''[[The Art Newspaper]]'', 17 June 2017. Retrieved 8 October 2018</ref> They consist of highly intricate layers of [[relief]]s often rendered to nearly microscopic level. The miniatures are made of [[Buxus|boxwood]], which has a fine grain and high density suitable for detailed micro carving. There are around 150 surviving examples. The majority are spherical beads ([[prayer nut]]s), statuettes, skulls, or coffins; some 20 are in the form of [[polyptych]]s such as [[triptych]] or [[diptych]] [[altarpieces]], or [[Church tabernacle|tabernacle]]s and [[monstrance]]s.<ref name="SuS">Suda, Sasha; Ellis, Lisa. "[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eD5M-je1yf4 Small Wonders: Gothic Boxwood Miniatures Introduction]". [[Art Gallery of Ontario]], 28 October 2016. Retrieved 24 November 2017</ref> The polyptychs tend to be in the 10–13 cm height range, while most of the beads are 10–15 cm in diameter; the latter were designed so they could be held in the palm of a hand during personal devotion, or hung from necklaces and belts as fashionable accessories.
Boxwood miniatures were highly prized in the early 16th century. Their iconography, form, and utility can be linked to medieval [[ivory diptychs]], as well as contemporary [[Miniature (illuminated manuscript)|illuminated miniatures]], altarpieces, panel paintings, sculpture, [[woodcut]]s, and engravings. They often contain imagery from the life of [[Mary, mother of Jesus|Mary]], the [[Crucifixion of Jesus]], and vistas of [[Heaven]] and [[Hell]]. Each miniature's production required exceptional craftsmanship, and some may have taken decades of [[man-hours|cumulative work]] to complete, suggesting that they were commissioned by high-ranking nobles.
A number of the miniatures appear to have come from a workshop led by Adam Dircksz, who is thought to have produced dozens of miniatures. Almost nothing is known about Dircksz, outside of a Latin signature on a single work now held in Copenhagen, and little is known of the artisans who produced the miniatures. Some of the original owners can be identified from markings, usually initials or coats of arms, placed by the sculptors.<ref name="m162">Marks (1977), p. 162</ref> Important collections are in the [[Art Gallery of Ontario]], in the [[British Museum]] as part of the [[Waddesdon Bequest]], and at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], New York.<ref>Thornton (1985), pp. 162–194</ref> Because of their rarity and the difficulty in discerning their intricacy from reproductions, boxwood miniatures are relatively understudied compared to other forms of Netherlandish visual art.
==Production== [[File:Half of a Prayer Bead with the Crucifixion MET DP371024.jpg|280px|thumb|Crucifixion scene from "Half of a Prayer Bead with the Crucifixion", early 16th century, Netherlandish. Height: 5.7 cm. Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York<ref name="MET3">"[https://images.metmuseum.org/CRDImages/md/original/DP371981.jpg Half of a Prayer Bead with the Crucifixion]". Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved 25 November 2018</ref>]] [[Buxus sempervirens|Boxwood]] is a dense hardwood with fine [[Wood grain|grain]], resistant to splitting and chipping—ideal for wood carving.<ref name="l25">Ellis; Suda (2016), p. 25</ref><ref>Drake Boehm, Barbara; Suda, Alexandra. "[http://boxwood.ago.ca/publication/what-boxwood What is Boxwood?]". Art Gallery of Ontario. Retrieved 22 September 2018</ref> In the 16th century, [[woodcut]] blocks used for [[woodblock printing]] were usually made of boxwood. Uses for boxwood were similar to those for ivory in medieval carvings, but with boxwood a far less expensive option than ivory.<ref name="s23">Scholten (2017), p. 23</ref> Designs were overseen by master craftsmen who must have had access to prints and [[woodcuts]] of contemporary works of art, and who were apparently influenced by diptych and triptych panel paintings.<ref name="l23">Ellis; Suda (2016), p. 23</ref>
Boxwood grows slowly, so the trunk remains fairly narrow, a fact that impedes the size of any carvings made from any single piece. In addition, the wood assumes an even, soft and tactile surface if polished or, more importantly, frequently handled; especially the prayer nuts were intended to be held in the owner's hand.<ref name="s20">Scholten (2017), p. 20</ref> The wood loses its tactility when painted over, explaining why most of the miniatures are in monochrome. In addition, polychromy would have reduced the legibility of the carvings, "quite apart from the difficulty of effectively coloring such tiny and complex scenes" as the art historian [[Frits Scholten]] has noted.<ref>Scholten (2017), pp. 22–23</ref>
The tools used in production were similar to those used in the production of larger [[altarpiece]]s and would have included [[saw]]s, [[Plane (tool)|planes]], [[card scraper]]s, chisels, [[auger (drill)|augers]], braces, and [[gimlet (tool)|gimlets]]. Wood was cut into the required dimensions as blocks, after which the [[joiner|joins]] were carved out. Prayer beads were made on a [[lathe]] used to [[Woodturning|turn]] the wood.<ref name="t162">Thornton (1985), p. 162</ref> The woodcutters carved a single block of boxwood into a sphere, which was then cut in half, hollowed out and attached to a fastening hinge and carrying loops. The carvings in the interiors were typically made separately from the smaller hemispheres and later fitted onto an outer shell.<ref name="t164" />
[[File:BLW Portable Shrine.jpg|300px|left|thumb|Miniature altar, height: 9.3cm, boxwood and silver, c. 1500–20, Netherlandish. [[Victoria and Albert Museum]], London]] Because of their diminutive scale, the pieces were produced using magnifying glasses.<ref name="s57">Scholten (2017), p. 57</ref> The very small wood pieces were difficult to hold in place (brace) during carving. They were likely positioned on a bench, between two posts, so that they could be turned around. Domed spaces, intended to evoke church architecture, were drilled or carved, and these were divided, using [[compass]]es and a [[straight edge]], into pie-shaped segments. A surface plane was established onto which the [[relief]]s would be added. These would have been created from multiple separate wood sheets, individually produced before being joined in layers.<ref name="l25" /> Major figures, usually saints, were carved from single blocks of wood. Relief components were either glued into prefixed niches,<ref name="l63">Ellis; Suda (2016), p. 63</ref> <ref name="Interior">Dandridge, Peter; Ellis, Lisa. "[http://boxwood.ago.ca/publication/interior-carvings-gothic-boxwood-miniature-altarpieces The Interior Carvings of Gothic Boxwood Miniature Altarpieces]". Art Gallery of Ontario. Retrieved 17 November 2018</ref> or they were bound with pegs, which were sometimes functional and obviously visible or implanted into the relief form.<ref name="l47">Ellis; Suda (2016), p. 47</ref> Because of this layered structure, they are often fragile.<ref name="Interior" /> An example of this layering technique is in the ''Prayer bead'' (AGO 29365) in the Art Gallery of Ontario, where minuscule, individually carved, pointed rods suggesting rays of light were added to the vaulted ceiling via tiny drilled holes.<ref name="l55">Ellis; Suda (2016), p. 55</ref> In some cases, prayer bead shells were placed in a silver housing.<ref name="f332">Scholten (2011), p. 332</ref><ref name="ca">"[https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/193475 Rosary bead, ca. 1525–50, Flemish (CA 17.190.328)]". Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved 18 November 218</ref>
The level of detail indicates the use of magnification in their production, probably with the same instruments used by contemporary jewellers.<ref name="l27">Ellis; Suda (2016), p. 27</ref> Describing these intricacies, the art historian Eve Kahn writes that the works can be so rich that "individual feathers are visible on angel wings, and dragon skins are textured with thick scales. Crumbling shacks are shown with shingles missing from their gabled roofs. Saints' robes and soldiers' uniforms are trimmed with buttons and embroidery, and there are nearly microscopic representations of jewelry and rosary beads".<ref name="nyt" />
==Attribution and dating== [[File:Prayer Bead in the Form of a Skull.jpg|thumb|220px|"Prayer Bead in the Form of a Skull" (interior: [[Triumphal entry into Jerusalem|The Entry into Jerusalem]] and the [[Christ Carrying the Cross|Carrying of the Cross]]), c. 1515. H: 5.8cm. Art Gallery of Ontario, Toronto]] Only one miniature is explicitly dated, the triptych catalogued WB.232 in the [[Waddesdon Bequest]] in the British Museum is inscribed with "1511".<ref name="w43" /><ref name="WB232">[https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/collection_online/collection_object_details.aspx?objectId=36553&partId=1 WB.232: Triptych / case / altar-piece]". British Museum. Retrieved 30 November</ref> A minority bear a [[coat of arms]] or other indications of origin or the source of commission. A carving in the [[Musée de Cluny – Musée national du Moyen Âge|Musée de Cluny]], Paris, contains the letter "M", and must have been completed before the 1524 inventory of [[Margaret of Austria, Duchess of Savoy|Margaret of Austria]]. Approximate dates for other examples can be inferred from the inventories of their owners.<ref name="m140">Marks (1977), p. 140</ref> The rosary beads owned by Henry VIII must have been produced between his marriage to Catherine in 1509 and his earliest efforts to separate from her in 1526.<ref name="w43" />
Most surviving boxwood miniatures are attributed to [[Northern Renaissance]] artisans working in the [[Burgundian Netherlands|Burgundian]] and [[Habsburg Netherlands]] during the late 15th and early 16th centuries.<ref name="m132">Marks (1977), p. 132</ref> Due to their quality and stylistic similarities to the full sized Flemish and [[Brabantine Gothic|Brabantine]] altarpieces, they were for centuries assumed to originate from [[Southern Netherlands]], however more recent research has found that a majority of the early owners came from the northern provinces of [[County of Holland|Holland]] and [[Zeeland]].<ref name="sc31">Scholten (2017), p. 31</ref> There are examples from Italy, although according to Wilhelm Bode, "The broad monumental tendency of Italian art, especially in sculpture, seems to exclude a taste for daintily executed small works".<ref>Bode (1904), p. 179</ref> German examples include a carving encased in a miniature skull, now in the Art Gallery of Ontario, which contains branchwork (''Astwerk'') of a type often found in contemporary German sculpture.<ref name="ws171">Wetter; Scholten (2017), p. 171</ref>
That a majority of the miniatures share technical, stylistic, and thematic similarities, and could be considered as a near homogeneous group was first noted by the art historian Jaap Leeuwenberg.<ref name="s339">Scholten (2011), p. 339</ref> Such stylistic traits include broad and densely populated animated scenes, often placed, in the words of the art historian William Wixom, on "steeply angled ground planes of tiled floors".<ref name="w43">Wixom (1983), p. 43</ref> Other shared features include spatial devices, figures in contemporary dress, and draperies arranged in angular folds. On this basis Leeuwenberg attributed a large number of the objects to Adam Dircksz.<ref name="w43" />
[[File:Prayer nut with carrying of the cross and crucifixion - crucifixion.jpg|left|400px|thumb|"Prayer Bead with the Crucifixion and Jesus before Pilate" (open), c. 1500–30. Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York]] The art historians Lisa Ellis and Alexandra Suda estimate that the more complex boxwood miniatures may have taken decades of work to complete, a period equivalent to the entire career of a medieval master carver.<ref name="l28">Ellis; Suda (2016), p. 28</ref> Production would have been organised between different workshops of specialised artisans.<ref name="l73">Ellis; Suda (2016), p. 73</ref> Because the miniatures were so intricate, only a small number of workshops were likely involved in their production.<ref name="a112">Anderson (2012), p. 112</ref> Due to this high degree of artistry, art historians presume they were intended as luxury items and status symbols for a high-born and sophisticated European elite;<ref name="mc69">McConnell (1991), p. 69</ref> [[Henry VIII of England]] and [[Catherine of Aragon]],<ref name="w39">Wixom (1983), p. 39</ref> [[Charles VI, Holy Roman Emperor|Holy Roman Emperor Charles VI]]<ref name="s18">Shultz (1986), p. 18</ref> and [[Albert V, Duke of Bavaria|Albert V of Bavaria]]<ref name="t164">Thornton (1985), p. 164</ref> are known to have owned individual boxwood miniatures.<ref name="nyt">Kahn, Eve. "[https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/04/arts/design/unlocking-the-secrets-of-boxwood-miniatures.html?_r=0 Unlocking the Secrets of Boxwood Miniatures]." ''[[New York Times]]'', November 3, 2016. Retrieved March 17, 2017</ref>
===Adam Dircksz=== Because of shared characteristics, including common use of [[horror vacui]], similar spatial approaches and use of depth,<ref name="s27">Scholten (2017), p. 27</ref> as well as similar hinges and methods of construction,<ref name="condex">Suda, Alexandra; Ellis, Liza. "[https://ezine.codart.nl/17/issue/45/artikel/investigating-miniature-boxwood-carving-at-the-art-gallery-of-ontario-in-toronto/?id=119#!/page/8 Investigating Miniature Boxwood Carving at the Art Gallery of Ontario in Toronto]". CODART eZine, Spring 2003. Retrieved 18 November 2018</ref> Leeuwenberg has suggested that production of a number of the miniatures was overseen by a single master named Adam Dircksz,<ref>Van Os; Filedt Kok (2000), pp. 107–108</ref><ref name="m142">Marks (1977), p. 142</ref> Almost nothing is known about Dircksz except that the works were produced c. 1500-30. The signature may indicate that he was a woodcutter, sculptor, [[medallist]], or just simply the patron.<ref name="BMA">"[https://www.britishmuseum.org/research/search_the_collection_database/term_details.aspx?bioId=227583 Adam Dircksz (Biographical details)]". British Museum. Retrieved 18 November 2018</ref> Dircksz may have led a workshop in the southern Netherlands,<ref name="ts">Shaw, Tamsin. "[https://www.nybooks.com/daily/2017/05/12/the-universe-in-a-nutshell-gothic-boxwood-miniatures/ The Universe in a Nutshell]". ''[[The New York Review of Books]]'', 12 May 2017. Retrieved 8 October 2018</ref> possibly at [[Delft]] or [[North Brabant|Brabant]],<ref name="s342">Scholten (2011), p. 342</ref> given that Flemish inscriptions appear on some of the carvings,<ref name="w43" /> and that, apart from Henry VIII and Catherine, all of the original owners come from the Netherlands.<ref name="m141">Marks (1977), p. 141</ref> He is thought to have been active between 1500 and 1530, and responsible for some sixty of the surviving examples.<ref name="BMA" />
Dircksz was first identified through a signature on a prayer nut now in the [[Statens Museum]] Copenhagen, reading "Adam Theodrici me fecit" (''Adam Dircksz has made me'').<ref>Scholten (2017), pp. 24–36</ref> The Latin name "Adam Theodrici" may be translated into English as "Adam of Theodoric", but art historians usually use the Dutch version of his name, Adam Dircksz.<ref name="s339" /><ref>"[https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/671342 Prayer Bead with the Crucifixion and Jesus Carrying the Cross]". Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved 8 October 2018</ref> While it was rare in the 16th century for artists to sign a work, when employed, the construct usually took the "me fecit" (made me) form, in effect of making the object speak.<ref>Scholten (2017), p. 32</ref>
Regardless of the number of works that Dircksz or his workshop can be attributed with, art historians often debate what the artistic and technical precedents for the miniatures might be. Scholten observes how, to a large extent, it seems "as if this exquisite sculpture was born ex nihilo around 1500", but points out that "giant strides are rarely made in art history", pointing to affinities with silversmith's art, especially the miniature architectural elements often found in ecclesiastical silver and ornaments.<ref name="sc31" />
==Iconography== [[File:Miniature Coffin 1985-136.jpg|thumb|280px|"Miniature Coffin" or "Sarcophagus" (1985.136). Netherlandish, c. 1500. Height 10.1 cm. The Cloisters, New York<ref name="coffin" />]] Boxwood miniatures follow in the tradition of earlier Christian sculptures, including ivory diptychs,<ref>Scholten (2017), p. 23</ref> sculptures of the Virgin and Child, and relief carvings.<ref name="condex" /> They are similar in style to larger scale contemporary artworks, especially Flemish panel paintings, altarpieces, and sculpture, and they were conceived with similar religious outlook and conviction. Their [[iconography]] is often a mix of [[Old Testament|Old]] and [[New Testament]] scenes, with depictions of the Nativity and Passion being the most common.<ref name="ws176">Wetter; Scholten (2017), p. 176</ref><ref>Scholten (2017), p. 39</ref> However, while the central subject matter may be similar across many pieces, there is considerable variation in compositions.<ref>Scholten (2017), p. 64</ref> Expansive depictions, such as of the Crucifixion, were sometimes influenced by contemporary literature.<ref name="s18" />
The objects' dramatic and incongruous impact, being both tiny and hugely expansive at the same time, are particularly suited to depictions of Heaven and Hell.<ref>Alleyne, Allyssia. "[http://edition.cnn.com/2016/12/09/arts/mystery-of-the-boxwood-miniatures/ 500-year-old secrets of boxwood miniatures unlocked]". [[CNN]], 9 December 2016. Retrieved 29 January 2017</ref> A miniature in the Art Gallery of Ontario depicting the Last Judgement contains some thirty separately carved spikes set into the ceiling vault and around Christ.<ref name="condex" />
==Formats== [[File:Miniature Altarpiece with the Crucifixion.jpg|thumb|left|240px|"[[Miniature Altarpiece with the Crucifixion]]", early 16th century. Height: 15 cm. Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York]] The Metropolitan Museum of Art broadly categorises boxwood miniatures into two groups, those with simple reliefs and those with complex design.<ref name="AIC">Owczarek, Nina. "[http://www.conservators-converse.org/2016/05/44th-annual-meeting-objects-wooden-artifacts-session-monday-16-may-2016-the-study-of-boxwood-prayer-beads-and-miniature-altars-from-the-thomson-collection-at-the-art-gallery-of-ontario-and-the-m/ The study of boxwood prayer beads and miniature altars]". [[American Institute for Conservation]], 16 May 2016. Retrieved 11 February 2017</ref> A majority of the surviving examples are single prayer beads, often with extravagant combinations of carving, Gothic [[tracery]], and [[Epigraphy|inscriptions]] on the outer shells. They often take the form of two hemispheres joined by a [[girdle]] with hinges and clasps, with the interiors hollowed out to accommodate the elaborate carvings.<ref name="l31">Ellis; Suda (2016), p. 31</ref> Apart from the more usual prayer nuts and polyptychs, other formats include statuettes, round [[pendant]]s, coffins, statuettes, perfume flasks,<ref name="coffin">"[http://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/469895 Memento Mori: Dives in Hell. Miniature Coffin]". Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved 29 January 2017</ref><ref>"[http://wb.britishmuseum.org/MCN10197#1612963066 Perfume flask WB.265]". British Museum. Retrieved 24 February 2017</ref> and [[memento mori]] in the form of skulls.
Owing to the commonality of materials, production techniques, and the general absence of paint application, the miniatures would have have had similar original colouring. This has diverged over the centuries, given various storage and handling methods, as well as different restorations and coating applications.<ref name="el" />
The use of tracery used for geometric decoration on the exteriors can be categorised into three different styles. One style super-imposes intersecting circles around the head of the dome. A second uses small circles to punctuate and divide the dome into segments. The style is a combination of the first two, but far more complex, and uses the arcs of the circles to link the first style's looping circles with the second style's repeating patterns. Yet all of the works are similar in proportion, circumference and the size of the hinge and clasps.<ref name="el">Dandridge, Peter; Ellis, Lisa. "[http://boxwood.ago.ca/publication/tracery-patterns-gothic-boxwood-prayer-beads The Tracery Patterns of Gothic Boxwood Prayer Beads]". Art Gallery of Ontario. Retrieved 1 October 2018</ref>
===Prayer nuts=== [[File:Half of a Prayer Bead with the Crucifixion.jpg|thumb|280px|"Half of a Prayer Bead with the Crucifixion", Netherlandish, early 16th century. Height: 5.7cm. Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York<ref name="MET3" />]]
{{Main|Prayer nut}} The English term ''Prayer nut'' comes from the equivalent Dutch word ''gebedsnoot'', and took on common usage in the 18th century. The use of the word "nut" may be derived from the fact that some of the beads were actually carved from nuts or pits, and although no such miniatures survive, it was a known practice in medieval southern Germany.<ref name="s20" /> They are mostly the same shape (deliberately to resemble apples),<ref>Scholten (2017), p. 15</ref> decorated with carved Gothic openwork tracery and flower-heads, and of a size suitable for holding in the palm of a hand.<ref name="wb">Braimbridge, Mark. "[https://www.ebts.org/2013/12/the-waddesdon-bequest-at-the-british-museum-part-1-by-mark-v-braimbridge/ The Waddesdon Bequest At The British Museum Part 1]". ''Topiarius'', Volume 14, Summer 2010. pp. 15–17. Retrieved 25 February 2017</ref>
Prayer nuts often contain central scenes depicting episodes from the life of [[Mary, mother of Jesus|Mary]] or the [[Passion of Jesus]].<ref name="l80">Ellis; Suda (2016), p. 80</ref> Some are a single bead; more rare are those consisting of up to eleven beads, including the "[[Chatsworth House|Chatsworth]] Rosary" gifted by Henry VIII to Catherine of Aragon,<ref name="l77" /> which is one of only two surviving boxwood rosaries.<ref name="prayer">Drake Boehm, Barbara; Suda, Alexandra. "[http://boxwood.ago.ca/publication/gothic-boxwood-miniatures-and-private-prayer Gothic Boxwood Miniatures and Private Prayer]". Art Gallery of Ontario. Retrieved 30 November 2018</ref> The figures are often dressed in fashionable contemporary clothing. The level of detail extends to the soldier's shields, their jacket buttons, jewellery, and candles.<ref name="s50">Ellis; Suda (2016), p. 50</ref> In some instances, they contain carved inscriptions usually related to the meaning of the narrative.<ref name="t162" /><ref name="l78">Ellis; Suda (2016), pp. 78–79</ref>
[[File:Prayer Bead with the Crucifixion and Jesus before Pilate 2.jpg|left|thumb|340px|"Prayer Bead with the Crucifixion and Jesus before Pilate", interior view. Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York.<ref>"[https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/464447 Prayer Bead with the Crucifixion and Jesus before Pilate]". Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved 2 December 2018</ref>]] The beads are quite uniform in size and shape, with a diameter ranging from around 30 to 65 millimetres.<ref name="s27" /> They were often made as two half-shells that could be opened to reveal intricate interior detail. According to the art historian Dora Thornton, when the prayer nuts was opened out, it "revealed the representation of the divine hidden inside.<ref name="t162" /> The art historian [[Frits Scholten]] notes that the tracery may have been intended to suggest that the object contained a small [[relic]], "so that the object took on the character of a [[talisman]] and was deemed to have an [[Apotropaic magic|apotropaic]] effect".<ref name="f323">Scholten (2011), p. 323</ref> A number contain a wooden loop in the middle of one half so they could be worn hanging from a belt, or carried in a case.<ref name="l77">Ellis; Suda (2016), p. 77</ref><ref name="t187">Thornton (1985), pp. 167, 187</ref> A fragrant substance was sometimes placed inside, which diffused when the beads were used, making them comparable to the then fashionable [[pomander]]s.<ref name="f323" />
The shape of a prayer nut likely carried deep significance; with the outer sheath representing Christ's human flesh; the bead stand, His cross; and the interior reliefs, His divinity.<ref name="t162" /><ref>Freeman (1976), p. 115</ref> According to Thornton, "unfolding the nut is in itself an act of prayer, like opening up a personal illuminated prayer book, or watching the leaves of a large scale altarpiece being hinged back in a church service".<ref name="t186">Thornton (1985), p. 186</ref> However, Scholten questions their use for private religious devotion, noting how their microscopic scale made them impractical for meditation, as their imagery was not discernible without a magnifying glass or strong spectacles.<ref name="f338">Scholten (2011), p. 338</ref>
<gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="3"> File:Half of a Prayer Bead with Jesus Carrying the Cross MET DP371017 (cropped).jpg|Detail: "Half of a Prayer Bead with Jesus Carrying the Cross", Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York File:Prayer nut with carrying of the cross and crucifixion - carryinig the cross.jpg|Detail: "Prayer Bead with the Crucifixion and Jesus before Pilate", interior view. Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York File:Flemish - Rosary Bead with Scene of Christ Carrying the Cross - Walters 61131.jpg|"Rosary Bead with Scene of Christ Carrying the Cross", c. 1500-25. Walters Art Museum, Baltimore
</gallery>
===Polyptychs=== Miniature boxwood triptychs, diptychs, and other polyptychs are typically altarpieces, with [[Church tabernacle|tabernacles]] and monstrances more rare. The multi-paneled works exist in both horizontal and landscape formats, and were usually formed from a single block of wood with its components hinged together. Triptychs generally followed the format and style of their larger-scale counterparts, with a central panel with major saints and two ancillary wings.<ref name="l656">Ellis; Suda (2016), pp. 65–66</ref>
[[File:Adoration of the Magi, Triptych, Flemish.jpg|thumb|Triptych: ''Adoration of the Magi'', c. 1500. Flemish, c. 1500. Height: 43.8 cm. [[Wallace Collection]], London<ref name="wcoll">"[https://wallacelive.wallacecollection.org/eMP/eMuseumPlus?service=ExternalInterface&module=collection&objectId=65966&viewType=detailView Adam Dircksz and workshop: The Adoration of the Magi]". Wallace Collection. Retrieved 2 December 2018</ref>]] The polyptychs usually served as portable devices for laypersons, used for private devotion,<ref name="w283">Wixom (1999), p. 283</ref> and their popularity reflects the growing affluence of merchants living in the major northern European ports. Their iconography often follows contemporary larger scale panel altarpieces,<ref name="l85">Ellis; Suda (2016), p. 85</ref> with depictions of Christ Carrying the Cross, and the [[Triumphal entry into Jerusalem|Entry into Jerusalem]] as common subjects.<ref name="ws171" /> The altarpieces typically consist of three major elements; an architectural housing, interior reliefs, and a base or [[predella]], which may be fixed or detachable. In turn, each of these elements may have several components, which were either pinned or bound with glue.<ref name="l65">Ellis; Suda (2016), p. 65</ref> They usually contain folding wings, within which the miniatures are carved in low relief, and often much smaller again figures and scenes around the borders of the central pictorial space.<ref name="ws172">Wetter, Scholten (2017), p. 172</ref> Typically, the larger fixed elements were connected with interlocking [[mortise and tenon]] joins cut into the slabs.<ref name="Interior" />
A triptych altarpiece (MMA 17.190.453) in the Metropolitan Museum of Art has a compartment (receptacle) for holding [[relic]]s which is covered by a hinged disc.<ref name="l85" /><ref name="prayer" /> An especially detailed and complex 25.1 cm high triptych catalogued as WB.232 in the British Museum, credited to the workshop of Adam Dircksz, contains two triptychs on upper and lower registers. The upper, far larger register consists of a central panel with a background Crucifixion and numerous foreground figures; a [[Resurrection of Jesus|Resurrection]], [[Burial of Jesus|Entombment]] and other scenes are on the right-hand wing, while depictions of [[Christ Carrying the Cross]] and the [[Sacrifice of Isaac]] are the main features of the left wing.<ref name="WB232" />
[[File:Miniature Altarpiece with the Crucifixion (center).jpg|left|200px|thumb|"[[Miniature Altarpiece with the Crucifixion]]" (detail), early 16th century. Full height: 15 cm. The Cloisters, New York<ref>"[http://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/464439 Miniature Altarpiece with the Crucifixion]". Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved 25 November 2018</ref>]] The reliefs are typically positioned on a horizontal plane, and allow a long space between the tops of the figures and the end of the typically rounded overhead arches.<ref name="l656" /> The panels are usually quite shallow, with just enough depth in the [[Niche (architecture)|niche]] to position the figures, which can be either free-standing or carved in high relief. The niches vary in profile, with [[dome]] or mushroom shapes being most common.<ref name="l68">Ellis; Suda (2016), p. 68</ref> Other features, including architectural or landscape elements, were similarly inserted fully formed; in more elaborate and detailed examples, the reduced scale was too constrained to create all of the elements in relief.<ref name="Interior" /> The approach also mirrors the practice employed by contemporary northern European artists working on full-scale altarpieces.<ref>Serck-Dewaide (1998), p. 83</ref>
Many of the features of the miniatures resemble contemporary northern Gothic style architecture. Only the example, in the British Museum, contains an Italian Renaissance influence, evident in its [[baluster|baluster shafts]] and the [[pilaster]]s containing prophets on either side of the Crucifixion.<ref name="m142" /> The late 15th-century veneration for the [[Passion of Jesus]] and the [[Our Lady of Sorrows|Sorrows of Mary]] had a strong bearing on the design and form of many of these types of altarpieces.<ref name="t189">Thornton (1985), p. 189</ref> Part of the appeal of the Passion was the contrast between relatively simple scenes from the Life of Christ, juxtaposed against more complex scenes with detailed vistas, such as the Crucifixion or depictions of Heaven and Hell.<ref name="t179">Thornton (1985), p. 179</ref>
==Collections== Boxwood miniatures seemed to have served three original functions: aids to private devotion, luxury objects of status, and novel playthings. Later they became precious family heirlooms, passed from generation to generation, and as medieval art fell out of fashion in the early modern period, their provenance was often lost.<ref name="es94">Ellis; Suda (2016), p. 94</ref> The earliest record of a collection is the 1598 inventory of the [[List of rulers of Bavaria|dukes of Bavaria]], which contain several boxwood miniatures.<ref name="es934">Ellis; Suda (2016), pp. 93–94</ref>
Of the surviving works, over one hundred re-emerged in 19th century Paris, then the leading market for medieval art.<ref name="es77">Ellis; Suda (2016), p. 97</ref> During this period, they were acquired by collectors such as [[Sir Richard Wallace, 1st Baronet|Richard Wallace]], [[Frédéric Spitzer]], and [[Ferdinand de Rothschild]].<ref name="w44">Wixom (1983), p. 44</ref> When the American financier [[J. P. Morgan]] purchased Baron [[Oppenheim family|Albert Oppenheim]]'s collection in 1906, he acquired four boxwood miniatures, including a triptych with the Crucifixion and Resurrection, and a prayer nut showing the Carrying of the Cross, all of which are now in the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York.<ref name="es978">Ellis; Suda (2016), pp. 97–98</ref><ref>"[https://www.nytimes.com/1906/11/18/archives/mr-morgans-old-carvings-baron-oppenheims-collection-bought-by-j.html Mr. Morgan's Old Carvings; Baron Oppenheim's Collection Bought by J. Pierpont Morgan Is Shown to London, But Not to New York – Our Ridiculous Tariff Prevents Bringing Over Ancient Statues and Reliefs]". ''The New York Times'', 18 November 1906. Retrieved 14 September 2018</ref> The Canadian publishing magnate [[Kenneth Thomson, 2nd Baron Thomson of Fleet|Kenneth Thomson]] was an important collector for over 50 years, and his collection included the world's largest gathering of boxwood miniatures, including two skulls, two triptychs and six prayer beads. These were bequeathed to the Art Gallery of Ontario, along with three other works collected by his family after his death.<ref name="es99">Ellis; Suda (2016), p. 99</ref>
==Study and conservation== Objects of this scale are difficult to view with the naked eye, and, even when held in hand, the true level of intricacy is not easily recognised.<ref name="SuS" /> The difficulty of producing magnified reproductions contributes to the fact that there has been comparatively little research into the format. Even traditional photography can fail to convey the true level of detail. Meaningful reproduction can only be achieved by computer modelling, where a series of photographs at various [[aperture|focal depths]] are [[Focus stacking|stacked]] to attain consistent sharpness.<ref name="AIC" />
Modern imaging technology has greatly improved the study of the objects since the late 20th century, including the use of x-ray.<ref name="CT">Ellis, Lisa; Nelson, Andrew. "[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pMdX1rtKUew MicroCT Scanning our Gothic Boxwood Miniatures]". Art Gallery of Ontario, 28 October 2016. Retrieved 12 February 2017</ref> Micro [[CT scan]]ning, using technology similar to medical scanning, allows the capture of thousands of images which can then be assembled into a three-dimensional model.<ref name="SuS" />
== Gallery == <gallery widths="200px" heights="200px" perrow="3"> File:Letter P with the Legend of Saint Philip MET DP-12590-005.jpg||''Letter P with the Legend of Saint Philip'', height (open): 7.1 cm, Netherlandish, 1500–06. [[The Cloisters]], New York<!---This work may be associated with Saint Philip, perhaps commissioned for [[Margaret of Austria, Duchess of Savoy|Margaret of Austria]].--><ref>"[https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/738679?exhibitionId=%7b49419ef4-95b9-4237-b6cb-4bb4ccdcc9f7%7d&oid=738679&pkgids=392&pg=1&rpp=4&pos=4&ft=* Letter P with the Legend of Saint Philip]". Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved 9 October 2018</ref> File:Waddesdon Bequest, British Museum DSCF9632 14.JPG|Prayer Nut, [[Waddesdon Bequest]], British Museum, London File:Flemish - Rosary Pendant Bead with the Crucifixion and Resurrection - Walters 61132.jpg|Rosary Pendant Bead with the Crucifixion and Resurrection, Flemish, c. 1500–25. [[Walters Art Museum]], Baltimore File:Rosary bead MET DP371984.jpg|Prayer nut with sliver gilt case (CA 17.190.328), Flemish, c. 1525–50. Height: 6.7 cm (closed), 8.7 cm (open). Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York<ref>"[https://www.metmuseum.org/art/collection/search/193475 Rosary bead]". Metropolitan Museum of Art. Retrieved 1 December 2018</ref> File:Adam Theodrici - Prayer nut with case 90402 BK 1981 1.jpeg|Prayer nut case with tracery, attributed to Adam Dircksz, c. 1500–30. Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam File:Jan Gerritsz van Egmond (d. 1523). Bailiff of Nieuwburg, by or after Jacob Cornelisz. van Oostsanen.jpg|''Man holding a Prayer Nut'': Jan Gerritsz van Egmond (d. 1523), Bailiff of Nieuwburg. [[Jacob Cornelisz van Oostsanen]] or workshop, c. 1518. Rijksmuseum, Amsterdam </gallery>
==References== ===Notes=== {{reflist|30em}}

revision.comment: +{{[[Template:Redirect category shell|Redirect category shell]]}} for multiple-{{R}} #Rs using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
Don't know what a "cover page" is. Looks like the cover to me.
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=March 2016}}
[[File:Battleofdorking.jpg|thumb|right|200px|''The Battle of Dorking'' (1871) triggered an explosion of invasion literature. Cover of a 1914 edition.]]
'''Invasion literature''' (or the '''invasion novel''') is a [[literary genre]] most notable between 1871 and the [[World War I|First World War]] (1914) but still practised to this day. The genre first became recognizable starting in [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|Britain]] in 1871 with ''[[The Battle of Dorking]]'', a fictional account of an invasion of [[England]] by [[Germany]]. This short story was so popular it started a literary craze for tales that aroused imaginations and anxieties about hypothetical [[invasion]]s by foreign powers, and by 1914 the genre had amassed a corpus of over 400 books, many best-sellers, and a world-wide audience.<ref name="reiss">{{Harvnb|Reiss|2005}}.</ref> The genre was influential in Britain in shaping politics, national policies, and popular perceptions in the years leading up to the First World War, and remains a part of popular culture to this day. Several of the books were written by or ghostwritten for military officers and experts of the day who believed that the nation would be saved if the particular tactic that they favoured was or would be adopted.<ref>{{cite book |last=Echevarria |first=Antonio J. |title=Imagining Future War: The West's Technological Revolution and Visions of Wars to Come 1880–1914 |year=2007 |publisher=Prager Institute |location= |isbn=9780313051104 }}</ref>
==Pre-"Dorking"==
Nearly a century before the invasion literature genre became a true popular phenomenon after the publication of ''The Battle of Dorking'' in the 1870s, a mini-boom of invasion stories appeared soon after the French developed the [[hot-air balloon]]. Poems and plays that centred on armies of balloons invading England could be found in France, and even America. However, it was not until the Prussians used advanced technologies such as [[rifled breech-loader|breech-loading artillery]] and railroads to defeat the French in the [[1870 War]] that the fear of invasion by a technologically superior enemy became more realistic.
==In Europe==
''The Battle of Dorking'' (1871) by [[George Tomkyns Chesney]] first appeared in ''[[Blackwood's Magazine]]'', a respected [[Victorian era|Victorian]] political journal read by important British politicians.<ref>Patrick M Kirkwood, "The Impact of Fiction on Public Debate in Late Victorian Britain: The Battle of Dorking and the 'Lost Career' of Sir George Tomkyns Chesney," The Graduate History Review 4, No. 1 (Fall, 2012), 1-16.</ref> This [[short story]] describes the invasion of England by an unnamed enemy (who happen to speak [[German language|German]]), in which the narrator and 1,000 citizens defend the small English town of [[Dorking]], with no supplies or news of outside events. The story then moves forward in time 50 years and England is still devastated.
The author, like many of his countrymen at the time, was alarmed by [[Kingdom of Prussia|Prussia]]'s [[Franco-Prussian War|successful invasion of France]] in 1870, defeating Europe's largest army in only two months.<ref name="reiss" /> ''The Battle of Dorking'' was initially meant to shock readers into becoming more aware of the possible dangers of a foreign threat, but unwittingly created a new literary genre appealing to popular anxieties. The story was an immediate success, with one reviewer saying "We do not know that we ever saw anything better in any magazine... it describes exactly what we all feel."<ref name="reiss" /> It was so popular that the magazine was re-printed six times, a new pamphlet version was created, dozens of spoofs were created, and it was for sale throughout the [[British Empire]].<ref name="reiss" /> One [[running joke]] in England at the time was an injury, such as a bruise or scrape, being attributed to a wound received at the battle of Dorking.
Between the publication of ''The Battle of Dorking'' in 1871 and the start of the [[World War I|First World War]] in 1914 there were hundreds of authors writing invasion literature, often topping the best seller lists in Germany, [[France]], England and the [[United States]].<ref name="reiss" /> During the period it is estimated over 400 invasion works were published. Probably the best known work was [[H. G. Wells]]'s ''[[The War of the Worlds]]'' (1898), bearing plot similarities to ''The Battle of Dorking'' but with a [[science fiction theme]]. In 1907, Wells wrote ''[[The War in the Air]]'', a cautionary tale depicting purely human invasions: a German invasion of the US triggers off a worldwide chain of attacks and counter-attacks, leading to the destruction of all major cities and centers, the collapse of world economy, disintegration of all the fighting nations and the sinking of the world into new Middle Ages.
''[[Dracula]]'' (1897) also tapped into English fears of foreign forces arriving unopposed on its shores, although between 1870 and 1903 the majority of these works assumed that the enemy would be France, rather than Germany. This changed with the publication of [[Robert Erskine Childers|Erskine Childers]]'s 1903 novel ''[[The Riddle of the Sands]]''. Often called the first modern [[spy novel]], two men on a sailing holiday thwart a German invasion of England when they discover a secret fleet of invasion barges assembling on the German coast. Of these hundreds of authors, few are in print now. [[Saki]] is one of the exceptions, although his 1913 novel ''[[When William Came]]'' (subtitled "A Story of London Under the [[Hohenzollerns]]") is more [[jingoistic]] than literary. Another is [[John Buchan, 1st Baron Tweedsmuir|John Buchan]], whose novel ''[[The Thirty-Nine Steps]]'', published in 1915 but written just prior to the outbreak of World War I, is a thriller dealing with German agents in Britain preparing for an invasion.
[[William Le Queux]] was the most prolific author of the genre; his first novel was ''[[The Great War in England in 1897]]'' (1894) and he went on to publish from one to twelve novels a year until his death in 1927. His work was regularly serialised in newspapers, particularly the ''[[Daily Mail]]'', and attracted many readers. It is believed{{By whom|date=April 2018}} [[Ian Fleming]]'s [[James Bond]] character was inspired by Le Queux's agent "Duckworth Drew". In some ways ''The Great War'' can be considered an antithesis to ''The Battle of Dorking'' – with the one ending for Britain in sombre and irrevocable defeat and decline, while in the other the invasion of [[London]] is pushed back in the last moment (with the help of [[Germany]], portrayed as a staunch ally against [[France]] and [[Russia]]), with enormous territorial aggrandizement (Britain gets [[Algeria]] and Russian [[Central Asia]]; "Britannia" becomes "Empress of the World").
Le Queux's most popular invasion novel was ''[[The Invasion of 1910]]'' (1906) which was translated into twenty-seven languages selling more than a million copies world-wide. Le Queux and his publisher changed the ending depending on the language, so in the German print edition the fatherland wins, while in the English edition the Germans lose. Le Queux was said to be [[Alexandra of Denmark|Queen Alexandra]]'s favorite author.
[[P. G. Wodehouse]] parodied the genre in ''[[The Swoop!]]'', in which England is simultaneously invaded by nine different armies, including Switzerland and Germany. English elites appear to be more interested in a cricket tournament, and the country is eventually saved by a boy scout named Clarence.
==In Asia== Invasion literature had its impact also in [[Empire of Japan|Japan]], at the time undergoing a fast process of [[modernization]]. [[Shunrō Oshikawa]], a pioneer of Japanese [[science fiction]] and adventure stories (genres unknown in Japan until a few years earlier), published around the start of the 20th century the [[best-seller]] ''Kaitō Bōken Kidan: Kaitei Gunkan'' ("Undersea Battleship"): the story of an armoured, [[ramming|ram]]-armed [[submarine]] involved in a [[future history]] of war between Japan and Russia. The novel reflected the [[imperialist]] ambitions of Japan at the time, and foreshadowed the [[Russo-Japanese War]] that followed a few years later, in 1904. When the actual war with Russia broke out, Oshikawa covered it as a journalist while also continuing to publish further volumes of fiction depicting Japanese imperial exploits set in the [[Pacific]] and [[Indian Ocean]] – which also proved an enormous success with the Japanese public. In a later career as a magazine editor, he also encouraged the writing of more fiction in the same vein by other Japanese authors.
Colonial [[Hong Kong]]'s earliest work of invasion literature is believed to have been the 1897 ''[[The Back Door (fiction)|The Back Door]]''. Published in serial form in a local English-language newspaper, it described a fictional French and Russian naval landing at [[Hong Kong Island]]'s [[Deep Water Bay]]; the story was intended to criticise the lack of [[British Empire|British]] funding for [[British Forces Overseas Hong Kong|the defence of Hong Kong]], and it is speculated that members of the [[Imperial Japanese Army]] may have read the book in preparation for the 1941 [[Battle of Hong Kong]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Bickley|first=Gillian| isbn = 962-209-526-7 |publisher=Hong Kong University Press|location=Hong Kong, China|title=Hong Kong Invaded! A 97 Nightmare}}</ref>
==In the U.S.== [[Image:Liberty-shall-not-perish-Pennell.jpeg|thumb|190px|[[Joseph Pennell]]'s 1918 [[Liberty bond]] poster calls up the pictorial image of an invaded, burning [[New York City]].]] One of the earliest stories to appear in print in the U.S. was "The Stricken Nation" by [[Henry Grattan Donnelly]] published in 1890 in New York. It tells of a successful British invasion of the U.S.<ref>{{cite book |title=Tales of the next great war |editor1-first=I. F. |editor1-last=Clarke |publisher=Syracuse University Press |year=1995 |isbn=081562672X }}</ref> The move of American public opinion towards participation in [[World War I]] was reflected in ''Uncle Sam's Boys at The Invasion of the United States'' by [[H. Irving Hancock]]. This four-book series, published by the [[Henry Altemus Company]] in 1916, depicts a German invasion of the U.S. in 1920–1921. The plot seems to transfer the main story line of Le Queux's ''The Great War'' (with which the writer may have been familiar) to an American theatre: the Germans launch a surprise attack, capture [[Boston]] despite heroic resistance by "Uncle Sam's boys", overrun all of [[New England]] and [[New York (state)|New York]] and reach as far as [[Pittsburgh]] – but at last are gloriously crushed by fresh American forces.
==In Australia==
Australia's contribution to invasion literature was set against the background of pre-[[Federation of Australia|Federation]] colonial fears of the "[[Yellow Peril]]" and the foundations of the [[White Australia policy]]. From the late 1880s through to the beginning of World War I, this fear was expressed in Australia through cartoons, poems, plays and novels. Three of the most well known of these novels were ''White or Yellow? A Story of the Race War of AD 1908'' (1888) by journalist [[William Lane]], ''The Yellow Wave'' (1895) by Kenneth Mackay and ''The Australian Crisis'' (1909) by Charles H. Kirmess (possibly a pseudonym for another Australian author Frank Fox). Each of these novels contained two major common themes which were a reflection of the fears and concerns within a contemporary Australian context; the Australian continent was at risk of major invasion from a strong Asian power (ie. China or Japan, sometimes with the assistance of the Russian Empire) and that the United Kingdom was apathetic towards the protection of its faraway colonies, and would not come to Australia's aid when needed.<ref>{{cite book |title=Australia and the Wider World: Selected Essays of Neville Meaney |editor1-first=James |editor1-last=Curran |editor2-first=Stuart |editor2-last=Ward |publisher=Sydney University Press |year=2013 |isbn=9781743320259 }}</ref>
==After World War I==
The "[[First Red Scare]]" following [[World War I]] produced [[Edgar Rice Burroughs]]'s ''[[The Moon Maid|The Moon Men]]'' (1925), a depiction of Earth (and specifically, the United States) under the rule of cruel invaders from the [[Moon]]. This book is known to have been originally written as ''Under the Red Flag'', an explicit [[anti-Communist]] novel, and when rejected by the publishers in that form it was successfully "recycled" by Burroughs as science fiction.
[[Ivan Petrushevich]]'s "[[The Flying Submarine]]" (1922), depicted an invasion of The United Kingdom by Soviet forces after most of Europe and Asia had fallen to communism. The story features the British fleet being destroyed by a swarm of insect-like single pilot submarines which can emerge from the water to attack their foes.
[[Robert A. Heinlein]]'s ''[[Sixth Column]]'' (1941) told the story of the invasion and conquest of the United States by the technologically advanced PanAsians, and the subsequent guerrilla struggle to overthrow them with even more advanced technology.
==After World War II==
Fears of Communist invasion became even more pronounced in books like [[Robert A. Heinlein]]'s ''[[The Puppet Masters]]'' (1951) and films like ''[[Invasion U.S.A. (1952 film)|Invasion USA]]'' (1953) and a Department of Defense information film released to the general public ''[[Red Nightmare]]'' (1957). A more explicit Soviet invasion and occupation is depicted in [[Jerry Sohl]]'s'' [[Point Ultimate]]'' (1955) – where the United States lies prostrate under cruel and degenerate Soviet occupiers, helped by "Commie" American collaborators – but a band of undaunted rebels manage the improbable feat of launching an extensive space program under the Soviets' noses, colonising [[Mars]] and using it as a base of operations. Similar themes were continued in the 1980s with the film ''[[Red Dawn]]'' (1984) and TV miniseries ''[[Amerika (TV miniseries)|Amerika]]'' (1987).
During the 1960s, the enemy was changed from the Soviet Union to [[China|Red China]] where China was shown as behind plots to destroy the American economy with a nuclear weapon in ''[[Goldfinger (film)|Goldfinger]]'' (1964), instigating a war between the USA and USSR in ''[[You Only Live Twice (film)|You Only Live Twice]]'' and invading the United States from tunnels dug beneath the ocean in ''[[Battle Beneath the Earth]]'' (1967).
In 1971, when realization of losing the [[Vietnam War]] was sinking into the American consciousness, two books appeared almost simultaneously, both depicting a United States under [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] occupation. In ''[[Vandenberg (novel)|Vandenberg]]'' by [[Oliver Lange]] – written, like "Dorking", as a cautionary tale – most Americans accept Soviet overlordship without much protest, the only resistance coming from a group of oddballs in a corner of [[New Mexico]]. In contrast, in [[John Ball (American author)|John Ball]]'s ''[[The First Team (novel)|The First Team]]'' – as in "The Great War" – a seemingly hopeless situation is retrieved by a band of courageous patriots with the book ending on a note of uplifting liberation. The ''[[Amerika (miniseries)|Amerika]]'' TV miniseries, depicting a Soviet-occupied US, was aired in 1987 - a time when [[Gorbachev]]'s [[Perestroika]] already rendered its theme highly implausible.
The [[Tomorrow series|''Tomorrow'' series]] by [[John Marsden (writer)|John Marsden]], published between 1993 and 1999, detail an invasion of [[Australia]] by an unnamed country from the perspective of a band of teenage [[Guerrilla warfare|guerillas]].
Allebury, ''All Our Tomorrows'', resistance to a Soviet occupation of the U.K.
==Political impact== Stories of a planned German invasion rose to increasing political prominence from 1906. Taking their inspiration from the stories of Le Queux and Childers, hundreds of ordinary citizens began to suspect foreigners of espionage. This trend was accentuated by Le Queux, who collected 'sightings' brought to his attention by readers and raised them through his association with the Daily Mail. Subsequent research has since shown that no significant German espionage network existed in Britain at this time. Claims about the scale of German invasion preparations grew increasingly ambitious. The number of German spies was put at between 60,000 and 300,000 (in spite of the total German community in Britain being no more than 44,000 people). It was alleged that thousands of rifles were being stockpiled by German spies in order to arm saboteurs at the outbreak of war.
Calls for government action grew ever more intense, and in 1909 it was given as the reason for the secret foundation of the [[Secret Service Bureau]], the forerunner of [[MI5]] and [[MI6]]. Historians today debate whether this was in fact the real reason, but in any case the concerns raised in invasion literature came to define the early duties of the Bureau's Home Section. [[Vernon Kell]], the section head, remained obsessed with the location of these saboteurs, focusing his operational plans both before and during the war on defeating the saboteurs imagined by Le Queux.
Invasion literature was not without detractors; policy experts in the years preceding the First World War said invasion literature risked inciting war between England and Germany and France. Critics such as [[Prime Minister]] [[Henry Campbell-Bannerman]] denounced Le Queux's ''[[The Invasion of 1910]]'' as "calculated to inflame public opinion abroad and alarm the more ignorant public at home."<ref name="reiss" /> Journalist [[Charles Lowe (journalist)|Charles Lowe]] wrote in 1910: "Among all the causes contributing to the continuance of a state of bad blood between England and Germany perhaps the most potent is the baneful industry of those unscrupulous writers who are forever asserting that the Germans are only awaiting a fitting opportunity to attack us in our island home and burst us up."<ref name="reiss" />
==Notable invasion literature== [[File:jamesgillraycartoon.jpg|thumb|"Promised Horrors of the French Invasion" – a cartoon by the British [[James Gillray]] published during the [[French Revolution]] and depicting a London occupied by the French]]
===Pre-World War I=== *''[[The Battle of Dorking]]'' (1871), [[George Tomkyns Chesney]] *''[[A Catástrofe]]'' (c.1878), [[José Maria Eça de Queiroz]] *''La Guerre de demain'' (1888), [[Émile Driant]] *''[[The Germ Growers]]'' (1892), [[Robert Potter (Australia)|Robert Potter]] *''The Captain of the Mary Rose'' (1894), [[William Laird Clowes]] *''[[The Great War in England in 1897]]'' (1894), [[William Le Queux]] *''[[The Yellow Wave]]'' (1897), [[Kenneth Mackay (Australian politician)|Kenneth Mackay]] *''[[The War of the Worlds]]'' (1898), [[H. G. Wells]] *''[[The Riddle of the Sands]]'' (1903), [[Robert Erskine Childers|Erskine Childers]] *''[[The Invasion of 1910]]'' (1906), [[William Le Queux]] *''[[The Australian Crisis]]'' (1907), [[C. H. Kirmess]] *''[[Spies of the Kaiser]]'' (1909), [[William Le Queux]] *''[[When William Came]]'' (1913), [[Saki]] *''[[The Fall of a Nation (novel)|The Fall of a Nation]]'' (1916), [[Thomas Dixon Jr.]] *''[[Before Armageddon|Before Armageddon: An Anthology of Victorian and Edwardian Imaginative Fiction Published Before 1914]]'' edited by [[Michael Moorcock]] (1975) *''[[England Invaded]]'' (1977), a collection of six popular Invasion Literature stories edited by Michael Moorcock published in 1977.
===Post-World War I=== * ''The Third World War: August 1985'' (1978) and ''[[The Third World War: The Untold Story]]'' (1982) by [[John Hackett (British Army officer)|General Sir John Hackett]] *''[[The Survivalist (novel series)|The Survivalist]]'' series (1981–1993), [[Jerry Ahern]] *''[[Tomorrow series|Tomorrow]]'' series (1993–1999), [[John Marsden (writer)|John Marsden]] *''[[Out of the Ashes (Ashes series)|The Ashes]]'' series (1983–2003), [[William W. Johnstone]]
==See also== *[[Alien invasion]] *[[Alternate history]] *[[British Empire in fiction]] * [[World War III in popular culture]] * [[Book of Invasions]] * ''[[Not This August]]'' * ''[[Invasion U.S.A. (1952 film)]]'' * ''[[Invasion U.S.A. (1985 film)]]'' * ''[[Red Dawn]]'' * [[Axis victory in World War II]] * ''[[Amerika (TV miniseries)]]'' * ''[[World War III (miniseries)]]''

The Literary Invasion of Australia |title=Racism and Modernity |editor1-first=Iris |editor1-last=Wigger |editor2-first=Sabine |editor2-last=Ritter |location=Berlin |publisher=Lit |pages=222–235 |isbn=9783643901491 }} *{{cite book |last=Christopher |first=Andrew |year=1985 |title=Secret Service: the making of the British intelligence community |isbn=0-434-02110-5 }} *{{cite book |last=Clarke |first=I.
