revision.text:
{{Infobox Artwork | image_file=William III at the Battle of the Boyne.jpg | backcolor= | painting_alignment= | image_size=300px | title= The Battle of the Boyne | artist= [[Benjamin West]] | year= 1778, prints after 1781 | type=[[Oil painting|Oil on canvas]], [[historical painting]] | height_metric= | width_metric= | height_imperial= | width_imperial= | metric_unit=cm | imperial_unit=in | city=[[Newtownards]], Northern Ireland | museum=[[Mount Stewart]] }} '''''The Battle of the Boyne''''' is a 1778 [[historical painting]] by the Anglo-American artist [[Benjamin West]]. It portrays the [[Battle of the Boyne]] which took place in Ireland in 1690. West's depiction of [[William III of Ireland|William of Orange]] on his white horse became the iconic image of liberation from Catholic Ireland; the painting was widely copied and distributed throughout the nineteenth century. The painting itself is at [[Mount Stewart]], [[Newtownards]], [[Northern Ireland]], and is the property of the [[National Trust]].<ref>[http://artuk.org/discover/artworks/the-death-of-frederick-1st-duke-of-schomberg-at-the-battle-of-the-boyne-132931/search/makers:benjamin-west-17381820/page/5 Art UK]</ref>
==West and Historicism== West became a celebrated figure for his 1770 work ''[[The Death of General Wolfe]]'', which portrayed [[James Wolfe]]'s death during the [[Battle of the Plains of Abraham|fight for Quebec]] in 1759. His [[historical painting]]s brought him to national attention and he became a leading member of the [[Royal Academy of Arts|Royal Academy]]. West was influenced by [[neoclassicism]] and attempted to portray scenes that drew an emotional response, rather than being historically accurate. As a "history painter," he was more concerned with the epic rendition of the narrative rather than with its possible accuracy.<ref>{{cite book|author=Pamela M. Fletcher|title=Narrating Modernity: The British Problem Picture, 1895-1914|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kvT_0aOkOSkC&pg=PA146|date=1 January 2003|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-0-7546-3568-0|page=146 note 12}}</ref>
West's 1778 work portrays the fighting at the Boyne, part of the [[Williamite War in Ireland]] (1689–91). The battle was a decisive victory for the [[Williamite|Williamites]] over [[James II of Ireland|James II]]'s [[Jacobitism|Jacobite]] [[Irish Army (Kingdom of Ireland)|Irish Army]], leading to the capture of the Irish capital city [[Dublin]]. By the time West made the painting, the Boyne had come to occupy an important position in Irish [[Protestant culture]]. The dominant image of the painting is [[William III of Ireland|William of Orange]] crossing the [[River Boyne]]. West's portrayal of the King became influential on subsequent images of William, particularly his use of a white horse.<ref>Nordstrom p.193</ref>
In the bottom right corner, he portrays the death of [[Marshal Schomberg]], the second-in-command of William's army. Schomberg had crossed the Boyne earlier than William and had been killed by Jacobite cavalry in the melee around [[Oldbridge]] ford. West transformed Schomberg's chaotic death into a tableau, one that has strong similarities to other heroic death scenes in West's paintings, such as General Wolfe or [[Horatio Nelson]] in ''[[The Death of Nelson (West painting)|The Death of Nelson]]'' (1806).<ref>Nordstrom p.193</ref> ==Adoption by the Orange Order== Since the 1690s commemorations—state-sponsored and those held by the lower classes—had been held throughout Ireland celebrating key dates in the [[Williamite War]] such as the [[Battle of the Boyne]], [[Siege of Derry]] and the [[Siege of Cork]].<ref name="McBride">{{Cite book |author=Ian McBride |title=History and Memory in Modern Ireland |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=0-521-79366-1}}</ref> These followed a tradition started in [[Elizabethan era|Elizabethan]] England of celebrating key events in the Protestant calendar. By the 1740s such organizations as the Boyne Club and the Protestant Society, both seen as forerunners to the [[Orange Order]], held parades in Dublin.<ref name="McBride"/> As a "history painting, then, West's Battle of the Boyne represented an important moment in time, making it a crucial depiction of an event that was at least anecdotally important, monoscenic depictions of crucial moments in an implied narrative in the ongoing Orangist narrative.<ref>Lecture IV, p. 172, ''Lectures on Architecture and Painting: Delivered at Edinburgh, in November, 1853'', 1854, Wiley, [https://books.google.com/books?id=qKsaAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA172&dq=%22historical+painting%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lxuvUePlD4Pu0gXYk4CwBA&ved=0CEQQ6AEwBDgK#v=onepage&q=%22historical%20painting%22&f=false google books].</ref> ==Origin of the painting== In 2011, another original painting of the battle was discovered in a basement of Brownlow House, [[Lurgan]], and testing indicated the painting dates from about the same time as West's 1778 work. Experts conducting the testing and restoration believe the painting was made by a Dutch artist who did not sign his or her work and the piece contains more details than the West painting, suggesting it may even be an earlier production. The painting was damaged by bullet holes and knife slashes, and approximately 45 percent of the painting had been destroyed.<ref>Newsletter: The Pride of Northern Ireland. [http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/northern-ireland-news/historic-boyne-painting-back-to-its-former-glory-1-2738761 Restoration of boyne painting]. Friday 03 June 2011. Accessed 23 December 2015.</ref>
==Reproductions== Since West's painting, several reproductions have been made, mostly line etchings and engravings; these are widely exhibited. The most prominent of these was made in 1781 by [[John Hall (artist)|John Hall]] ([[Wivenhoe]] 1739 – London 1797), which can be found at the [[Wordsworth House]], [[Cumbria]]. Versions of West's painting were often reproduced on walls throughout Belfast, although these reproductions are becoming increasingly rare as the walls give way to urban development.<ref>Rex Cathcart, [http://historyonline.chadwyck.co.uk/getImage?productsuffix=_studyunits&action=printview&in=gif&out=pdf&src=/pci/c172-1988-038-07-000007/conv/c172-1988-038-07-000007.pdf&IE=.pdf ''Ireland and King Billy: Triumphalism Usage and Abusage.''] <u>History Today</u>. July 1988, pp. 41–45. Online edition 2001. Accessed 23 December 2015.</ref>
==References== <references/>
==Bibliography== * Carlton, Charles. ''This Seat of Mars: War and the British Isles, 1485–1746''. Yale University Press, 2011. * Cathcart, Rex. [http://historyonline.chadwyck.co.uk/getImage?productsuffix=_studyunits&action=printview&in=gif&out=pdf&src=/pci/c172-1988-038-07-000007/conv/c172-1988-038-07-000007.pdf&IE=.pdf ''Ireland and King Billy: Triumphalism Usage and Abusage.''] <u>History Today</u>. July 1988, pp. 41–45. Online edition 2001. Accessed 23 December 2015. *{{cite book|author=Pamela M. Fletcher|title=Narrating Modernity: The British Problem Picture, 1895-1914|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kvT_0aOkOSkC&pg=PA146|date=1 January 2003|publisher=Ashgate Publishing, Ltd.|isbn=978-0-7546-3568-0|page=146 note 12}} *{{Cite book |author=Ian McBride |title=History and Memory in Modern Ireland |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=0-521-79366-1}} *Newsletter: The Pride of Northern Ireland. [http://www.newsletter.co.uk/news/northern-ireland-news/historic-boyne-painting-back-to-its-former-glory-1-2738761 Restoration of Boyne painting]. Friday 03 June 2011. Accessed 23 December 2015. * Nordstrom, Carolyn. ''The Paths to Domination, Resistance, and Terror''. University of California Press, 1992.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Battle of the Boyne}} [[Category:Paintings by Benjamin West]] [[Category:1778 paintings]] [[Category:War paintings]] [[Category:William III of England]] [[Category:Paintings in Northern Ireland]]

{{Other uses|Butler (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox film | name = The Butler | image = The Butler poster.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Lee Daniels]] | producer = Pamela Oas Williams
[[Laura Ziskin]]
Lee Daniels
Buddy Patrick
[[Cassian Elwes]] | writer = [[Danny Strong]] | based on = {{based on|"A Butler Well Served by This Election"|[[Wil Haygood]]}} | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Forest Whitaker]] * [[Oprah Winfrey]] * [[Mariah Carey]] * [[John Cusack]] * [[Jane Fonda]] * [[Cuba Gooding Jr.]] * [[Terrence Howard]] * [[Lenny Kravitz]] * [[James Marsden]] * [[David Oyelowo]] * [[Vanessa Redgrave]] * [[Alan Rickman]] * [[Liev Schreiber]] * [[Robin Williams]] * [[Clarence Williams III]] }} | music = [[Rodrigo Leão]] | cinematography = [[Andrew Dunn (cinematographer)|Andrew Dunn]] | editing = [[Joe Klotz]] | studio = [[Laura Ziskin|Laura Ziskin Productions]]
Windy Hill Pictures
Follow Through Productions
Salamander Pictures
Pam Williams Productions | distributor = [[The Weinstein Company]] | released = {{Film date|2013|08|16}} | runtime = 132 minutes{{cite web|title=''THE BUTLER'' (12A)|url=http://www.bbfc.co.uk/releases/butler-film|work=[[Entertainment Film Distributors]]|publisher=[[British Board of Film Classification]]|date=October 15, 2013|accessdate=October 15, 2013}} | country = United States | language = English | budget = $30 million | gross = $176.6 million{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=butler.htm |title=Lee Daniels' The Butler (2013) |publisher=Box Office Mojo |date= |accessdate=August 25, 2014}} }} '''''The Butler''''' (full title '''''Lee Daniels' The Butler'''''){{cite news|last=Lee|first=Chris|title=MPAA permits Weinstein Co. to use 'Lee Daniels' 'The Butler' title|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/jul/20/entertainment/la-et-mn-mpaa-weinstein-lee-daniels-butler-title-20130720|accessdate=September 2, 2013|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|date=July 20, 2013}}{{cite news|last=McNary|first=Dave|title='Lee Daniels' The Butler' Gets First Posters Following MPAA Ruling|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/lee-daniels-the-butler-gets-first-posters-following-mpaa-ruling-1200566874/|accessdate=September 2, 2013|newspaper=Variety|date=July 23, 2013}} is a 2013 American [[Historical film|historical]] [[drama film]] directed and produced by [[Lee Daniels]] and written by [[Danny Strong]].{{cite news |last=Nordyke |first=Kimberly |title='The Butler' Trailer: Oprah Winfrey Plays 'Proud' Wife to Forest Whitaker (Video) |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/race/butler-trailer-oprah-winfrey-plays-518900 |accessdate=May 10, 2013|newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=May 7, 2013}} It is inspired by Wil Haygood's ''Washington Post'' article "A Butler Well Served by This Election". Loosely based on the real life of [[Eugene Allen]] who worked in the White House for decades, the film stars [[Forest Whitaker]] as Cecil Gaines, an [[African Americans|African-American]] who is a witness of notable political and social events of the 20th century during his 34-year tenure serving as a [[White House]] [[butler]].{{cite news |last=Child |first=Ben |title=The Butler trailer: Oprah Winfrey in the White House |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/may/09/the-butler-trailer-forest-whitaker |accessdate=May 10, 2013 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |location=London |date=May 9, 2013}}{{cite news |last=Roberts |first=Roxanne |title=Trailer for 'The Butler,' based on life of the White House's Eugene Allen |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/reliable-source/wp/2013/05/08/trailer-for-the-butler-based-on-life-of-the-white-houses-eugene-allen/ |accessdate=May 10, 2013 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=May 8, 2013 |author2=Amy Argetsinger}} In addition to Whitaker, the film's [[all-star#Entertainment|all-star cast]] also features [[Oprah Winfrey]], [[John Cusack]], [[Jane Fonda]], [[Alex Pettyfer]], [[Cuba Gooding Jr.]], [[Terrence Howard]], [[Lenny Kravitz]], [[James Marsden]], [[David Oyelowo]], [[Vanessa Redgrave]], [[Alan Rickman]], [[Liev Schreiber]], [[Robin Williams]], [[Minka Kelly]], [[Mariah Carey]], and [[Clarence Williams III]]. It was the last film produced by [[Laura Ziskin]],{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/07/citing-its-1916-silent-film-short-warner-bros-blocking-harvey-weinstein-from-using-the-butler-title-on-lee-daniels-film/ |title=UPDATE: David Boies Charges Extortion As He Returns Fire In 'The Butler' Spat Between Warner Bros And The Weinstein Company Directly |last1=Fleming |first1=Mike, Jr. |date=July 6, 2013 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |accessdate=July 27, 2013}}{{cite news |last=Rosen |first=Christopher |title='The Butler' Trailer: Lee Daniels' 'Forrest Gump' |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/05/08/the-butler-trailer_n_3237243.html |accessdate=May 10, 2013 |newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]] |date=May 9, 2013}} who died in 2011. The film was theatrically released by [[The Weinstein Company]] on August 16, 2013, to mostly positive reviews from critics,{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/07/20/director-lee-daniels-loses-appeal-over-title-of-new-film-the-butler-3891423/|title=The Butler to be re-titled – but only slightly – following dispute over name|last=Williamson|first=Caroline|date=July 20, 2013|publisher=''[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]''|accessdate=August 6, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Feinberg|first=Scott|title='The Butler' Builds Oscar Credentials With Strong Critical, Commercial Debut (Analysis)|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/race/butler-builds-oscar-credentials-strong-608479|accessdate=August 19, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 17, 2013}} grossing over $176 million worldwide against a budget of $30 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=butler.htm|title=Lee Daniels' The Butler (2013) - Box Office Mojo|author=|date=|website=www.boxofficemojo.com|accessdate=March 28, 2018}} ==Plot== In 2009, an elderly Cecil Gaines [[Frame story|recounts]] his life story while waiting at the [[White House]] to meet the newly inaugurated president. In 1926, at the age of seven, Gaines is raised on a [[Plantation complexes in the Southeastern United States|cotton plantation]] in [[Macon, Georgia|Macon]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. When the farm's owner [[rape]]s Cecil's mother, Cecil's father confronts him and is killed. Cecil is taken in by the estate's caretaker, who trains Cecil as a house servant. In 1937, at age eighteen, Cecil leaves the plantation. Desperately hungry, he breaks into a hotel pastry shop. The elderly master servant, Maynard, takes pity on Cecil and gives him a job. Cecil learns advanced serving and interpersonal skills from Maynard, who later recommends Cecil for a position in a [[Washington, D.C.]] hotel. While working there, Cecil meets and marries Gloria, and the couple has two sons: Louis and Charlie. In 1957, Cecil is hired by the [[White House]] during [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]]'s administration. White House [[maître d'hôtel]] Freddie Fallows introduces Cecil to head butler Carter Wilson and co-worker James Holloway. Cecil witnesses Eisenhower's reluctance to use troops to enforce school desegregation, then his resolve to uphold the law by [[Little Rock Nine|racially integrating]] [[Little Rock Central High School]] in [[Little Rock, Arkansas|Arkansas]]. Louis, the elder son, becomes a university student at [[Fisk University]] in [[Nashville, Tennessee]], although Cecil feels that the [[Deep South|South]] is too volatile. Louis joins a student program led by [[Southern Christian Leadership Conference]] (SCLC) activist [[James Lawson (American activist)|James Lawson]], which leads to a [[Nonviolence|nonviolent]] [[sit-in]] at a [[Nashville sit-ins|segregated diner]], where he is arrested. Gloria, who feels that Cecil puts his job ahead of her, descends into [[alcoholism]]. In 1961, after [[John F. Kennedy]]'s inauguration, Louis and [[Freedom Riders|others]] are attacked by members of the [[Ku Klux Klan]] while on a [[Freedom Riders|freedom ride]] to [[Birmingham, Alabama]]. Louis participates in the 1963 [[Birmingham Campaign|Birmingham Children's Crusade]], where dogs and water cannons are used to stop the marchers, one of the movement's actions which inspires Kennedy to deliver [[Civil Rights Address|a national address]] proposing the [[Civil Rights Act of 1964]]. After Kennedy is [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|assassinated]] his successor, [[Lyndon B. Johnson]], enacts the legislation. As a goodwill gesture, [[Jackie Kennedy]] gives Cecil one of the former president's [[necktie]]s. Louis participates in the 1965 [[Selma to Montgomery marches|Selma Voting Rights Movement]], which inspires Johnson to demand that Congress enact the landmark [[1965 Voting Rights Act|Voting Rights Act of 1965]]. Johnson also gives Cecil a [[tie bar]]. In the late 1960s, after civil rights activist [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]]'s [[Assassination of Martin Luther King, Jr.|assassination]], Louis tells his family that he has joined the [[Black Panthers]]. Cecil orders Louis and his girlfriend to leave his house. Louis is arrested again. Cecil becomes aware of President [[Richard Nixon]]'s plans to suppress the Black Panthers. Charlie confides to Louis that he plans to join the [[Vietnam War|war in Vietnam]]. After enlisting, Charlie is killed and buried at [[Arlington National Cemetery]]. When the Black Panthers resort to violence, Louis leaves the organization and returns to college, earning his [[master's degree]] in [[political science]] and eventually running for a seat in [[United States Congress|Congress]], although Cecil continues to hold resentment against him. Cecil repeatedly confronts his supervisor at the White House over the unequal pay and career advancement provided to the black White House staff. With President [[Ronald Reagan]]'s support, Cecil prevails, his reputation growing to the point that he and his wife are invited by the Reagans to be guests at a state dinner. Cecil becomes uncomfortable with the class divisions in the White House. After witnessing Reagan's refusal to support [[Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act|economic sanctions]] against Apartheid [[South Africa]], Cecil resigns. Gloria encourages Cecil to mend his relationship with Louis. Realizing his son's actions are heroic, Cecil joins Louis at a protest against [[Apartheid in South Africa|South African apartheid]]; they are arrested and jailed together. In 2008, Gloria dies shortly before [[Barack Obama]] [[United States presidential election, 2008|is elected]] as the nation's first African-American president. Two months, two weeks and one day later, Cecil prepares to meet the newly [[First inauguration of Barack Obama|inaugurated]] President, wearing the articles he received from Kennedy and Johnson. [[Stephen W. Rochon]] approaches Cecil and tells him the president is ready, preparing to show him the way to the Oval Office. Cecil tells him that he knows the way. ==Cast== * [[Forest Whitaker]] as Cecil Gaines, the film's main character, who dedicates his life to becoming a professional [[domestic worker]]. Michael Rainey, Jr. and [[Aml Ameen]] portray Cecil at ages 8 and 15, respectively. ;Gaines' private life * [[Oprah Winfrey]] as Gloria Gaines, Cecil's wife. * [[David Oyelowo]] as Louis Gaines, the Gaines' elder son. * [[Elijah Kelley]] as Charlie Gaines, the Gaines' younger son. Isaac White portrays him at age 10. * [[Alex Pettyfer]] as Thomas Westfall, the brutal plantation owner who kills Earl after raping Cecil's mother. * [[David Banner]] as Earl Gaines,{{cite news|last=Scott|first=A.O.|title=Black Man, White House, and History|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/2013/08/16/movies/lee-daniels-the-butler-stars-forest-whitaker.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=August 17, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times|date=August 15, 2013}} Cecil's father. * [[Mariah Carey]] as Hattie Pearl,{{cite web | title=Lee Daniels' The Butler (2013) | url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/456871/Lee-Daniels-The-Butler/cast | publisher = [[All Media Guide]] via ''[[The New York Times]]'' | accessdate=August 8, 2013}} Cecil's mother. * [[Terrence Howard]] as Howard, the Gaines' neighbor who romantically pursues Gloria. * [[Adriane Lenox]] as Gina. Howard's wife. * [[Yaya DaCosta]] as Carol Hammie, Louis' girlfriend.{{cite web|last=Johnson|first=Terence|title=Awards Profile: The Butler|url=http://www.awardscircuit.com/2013/04/12/awards-profile-the-butler/|publisher=Awards Circuit|accessdate=May 12, 2013}} * [[Vanessa Redgrave]] as Annabeth Westfall, matron of the plantation. * [[Clarence Williams III]] as Maynard, an elderly man who mentors a young Cecil and introduces him to his profession. ;White House co-workers * [[Cuba Gooding Jr.]] as Carter Wilson, the fast-talking head butler at the White House, with whom Cecil forms a close friendship. * [[Lenny Kravitz]] as James Holloway, a co-worker butler of Cecil's at the White House. * [[Colman Domingo]] as Freddie Fallows, the White House maitre d' who hires Cecil. ;White House historical figures * [[Robin Williams]] as [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]],{{cite news |last=Labrecque |first=Jeff |title='The Butler': The new trailer showcases Oscar-winning actors tackling history – VIDEO |url=http://popwatch.ew.com/2013/05/08/the-butler-trailer-presidents/ |accessdate=May 10, 2013 |publisher=[[Entertainment Weekly]] |work=PopWatch (column)|date=May 8, 2013}} the 34th [[President of the United States]]. * James DuMont as [[Sherman Adams]], Eisenhower's [[White House Chief of Staff]].{{cite web|last=Ingram|first=Bruce|title=Fame comes second for Evanston actor starring in 'The Butler'|url=http://lincolnshire.suntimes.com/people/butler-DIN-08152013:article|publisher=Sun-Times Media|accessdate=August 17, 2013|date=August 16, 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016213249/http://lincolnshire.suntimes.com/people/butler-DIN-08152013:article|archivedate=October 16, 2013|df=mdy-all}} * Robert Aberdeen as [[Herbert Brownell Jr.]], Eisenhower's [[Attorney General]].{{cite news|title=Lee Daniels' The Butler (2013)|url=https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/456871/Lee-Daniels-The-Butler/cast|accessdate=August 17, 2013|newspaper=The New York Times}} * [[James Marsden]] as [[John F. Kennedy]], the 35th President of the United States. * [[Minka Kelly]] as [[First Lady of the United States|First Lady]] [[Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis|Jackie Kennedy]] * [[Liev Schreiber]] as [[Lyndon B. Johnson]], the 36th President of the United States. * [[John Cusack]] as [[Richard Nixon]], the 37th President of the United States. * Alex Manette as [[H. R. Haldeman]], Nixon's [[White House Chief of Staff]]. * Colin Walker as [[John Ehrlichman]], Nixon's [[White House Counsel]].{{cite news|last=Wirt|first=John|title=N.O. native Walker joins The Butler cast|url=http://theadvocate.com/utility/homepagestories/6781003-129/no-native-walker-joins-the|accessdate=August 17, 2013|newspaper=The Advocate|date=August 16, 2013}} * [[Alan Rickman]] as [[Ronald Reagan]], the 40th President of the United States. * [[Jane Fonda]] as First Lady [[Nancy Reagan]] * [[Stephen Rider]] as [[Stephen W. Rochon]], [[Barack Obama]]'s [[White House Chief Usher]]. ;Civil rights historical figures * [[Nelsan Ellis]] as [[Martin Luther King, Jr.]]. * [[Jesse Williams (actor)|Jesse Williams]] as civil rights activist [[James Lawson (American activist)|James Lawson]] * [[Danny Strong]], the film's screenwriter, appears as a [[Freedom Riders|Freedom Bus]] journalist. news|last=Makarechi|first=Kia|title='Lee Daniels' The Butler' Celebrated By Oprah, Forest Whitaker, Gayle King & More In New York|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/08/01/lee-daniels-the-butler-screening_n_3685944.html|accessdate=August 19, 2013|publisher=The Huffington Post|date=August 1, 2013}} [[Melissa Leo]] and Orlando Eric Street were cast as First Lady [[Mamie Eisenhower]] and Barack Obama, respectively, but did not appear in the finished film.{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Kam|title=Two-time 2013|newspaper=The Bay State Banner|date=August 15, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Child|first=Ben|title=Lee Daniels pleads with Warner Bros to retain title of The Butler|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/filmblog/2013/jul/04/lee-daniels-warner-brothers-the-butler|accessdate=August 19, 2013|newspaper=The Guardian|date=July 4, 2013}}{{cite news|title='The Butler' Poster: Lee Daniels' New Film Fits Massive Cast List On New One-Sheet|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/06/03/the-butler-poster_n_3366504.html|accessdate=August 19, 2013|newspaper=The Huffington Post|date=June 3, 2013}} ==Production== ===Development=== [[Danny Strong]]'s screenplay is inspired by Wil Haygood's ''[[The Washington Post|Washington Post]]'' article "A Butler Well Served by This Election".{{cite news |last=Haygood |first=Wil |title=A Butler Well Served by This Election|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/11/06/AR2008110603948_pf.html |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=November 7, 2008}}{{cite web |author=The Reliable Source | date= August 6, 2013 | title= No, President Obama isn't doing a cameo in 'The Butler' | url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/reliable-source/wp/2013/08/06/no-president-obama-isnt-doing-a-cameo-in-the-butler/ |department=Reliable Source (blog) | work=[[The Washington Post]] | accessdate=August 8, 2013}} The project received initial backing in early 2011, when producers Laura Ziskin and Pam Williams approached [[Sheila Johnson]] for help in financing the film. After reading Danny Strong's screenplay, Johnson pitched in her own $2.7 million before bringing in several African-American investors. However, Ziskin died from cancer in June 2011. This left director Daniels and producing partner Hilary Shor to look for further producers on their own. They started with [[Cassian Elwes]], with whom they were working on [[The Paperboy (2012 film)|''The Paperboy'']]. Elwes joined the list of producers, and started raising funding for the film. In spring 2012, Icon U.K., a British financing and production company, added a $6 million guarantee against foreign pre-sales. Finally the film raised its needed $30 million budget through 41 producers and executive producers, including Earl W. Stafford, Harry I. Martin Jr., Brett Johnson, [[Michael Finley]], and Buddy Patrick. Thereafter, as film production started [[Weinstein Co.]] picked up U.S. distribution rights for the film. David Glasser, Weinstein Co. COO, called fund raising as an independent film, "a story that's a movie within itself."{{cite web| title = Why 'Lee Daniels' The Butler' Has 41 Producers| url = http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/why-lee-daniels-butler-has-605011|date=August 14, 2013| accessdate = August 15, 2013|work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]]}}{{cite web| title = Lee Daniels' The Butler: The film with FORTY ONE producers: How a host of stars and entrepreneurs raised $30m to fund The Butler |work=[[Daily Mail]] | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2394397/Lee-Daniels-The-Butler--The-film-FORTY-ONE-producers-How-host-stars-entrepreneurs-raised-30m-fund-The-Butler.html |date=August 15, 2013| accessdate = August 15, 2013}} [[The Weinstein Company]] acquired the distribution rights for the film after [[Columbia Pictures]] put the film in [[Turnaround (filmmaking)|turnaround]].{{cite web |last=Brevet |first=Brad |title=New Look at 'The Butler' as the Weinstein Co. Picks It Up for Distribution |url=http://www.ropeofsilicon.com/weinstein-co-butler-distribution-whitaker-daniels/ |publisher=Ropes of Silicon |accessdate=May 10, 2013 |date=September 24, 2012}}{{cite news |last=Kit |first=Borys |title=Columbia tells White House butler story |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/columbia-tells-white-house-butler-123281 |accessdate=May 10, 2013 |newspaper=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=November 19, 2008}} The film's title was up for a possible rename due to a [[Motion Picture Association of America]] claim from [[Warner Bros.]], which had inherited from the defunct Lubin Company a now-lost 1916 silent short film with the same name.{{cite news |last=Johnson |first=Ted |title=Harvey Weinstein Has Already Won 'The Butler' Battle (Opinion) |url=https://variety.com/2013/biz/biz/the-butler-title-tiff-why-weinstein-is-already-victorious-1200560460/ |accessdate=July 10, 2013 |newspaper=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=July 9, 2013}} The case was subsequently resolved with the MPAA granting The Weinstein Company permission to add Daniels' name in front of the title, under the condition that his name was "75% the size of ''The Butler''{{-"}}.{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/07/toldja-mpaa-oks-weinstein-co-to-use-lee-daniels-the-butler/ |title=TOLDJA! Weinstein Co. Can Title Its Movie 'Lee Daniels' The Butler', If It Wants |date=July 19, 2013 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |accessdate=July 23, 2013}} On July 23, 2013, the distributor unveiled a revised poster, displaying the title as ''Lee Daniels' The Butler''.{{cite web |url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/07/weinstein-co-unveils-new-poster-for-lee-daniels-the-butler-to-comply-with-mpaa/ |title=Weinstein Co Unveils New Poster For 'Lee Daniels' The Butler' To Comply With MPAA |author=The Deadline Team |date=July 23, 2013 |website=[[Deadline Hollywood]] |accessdate=July 23, 2013}} ===Filming=== [[Principal photography]] started in June 2012 in [[New Orleans]]. Production was originally scheduled to wrap in early August 2012 but was delayed by the impact of [[Hurricane Isaac (2012)|Hurricane Isaac]].{{cite news|last=Scott|first=Mike|title=Tropical Storm Isaac chases 'The Butler' away, as film suspends production|url=http://www.nola.com/movies/index.ssf/2012/08/tropical_storm_isaac_chases_th.html|newspaper=The Times-Picayune|date=August 27, 2012}} ==Reception== === Box office performance === In its opening weekend, the film debuted in first place with $24.6 million.{{cite news|last=Kilday|first=Gregg|title=Box Office Report: 'The Butler' Tops the Field With $25 Million|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-report-butler-tops-608689|accessdate=August 19, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 18, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Mendelson|first=Scott|title=Weekend Box Office: 'The Butler' Opens To $25m, 'Kick-Ass 2', 'Jobs', And 'Paranoia' Crash|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/scottmendelson/2013/08/18/weekend-box-office-the-butler-opens-to-25m-kick-ass-2-jobs-paranoia-crash/|accessdate=August 19, 2013|newspaper=Forbes|date=August 18, 2013}} The film topped the North American box office in its first three consecutive weeks.{{cite news|last=Cunningham|first=Todd|title=Oprah Winfrey's 'The Butler' Powers Past 'One Direction' for 3rd Straight Box-Office Win|url=http://mc-3596-1705542522.us-west-2.elb.amazonaws.com/movies/article/oprah-winfrey-s-butler-powers-past-one-direction-3rd-straight-box-office-win-114621|accessdate=September 2, 2013|newspaper=The Wrap|date=September 2, 2013}}{{Dead link|date=June 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}{{cite news|last=McClintock|first=Pamela|title=Box Office Report: 'The Butler' Wins Again With $17 Million, Crosses $50 Million|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/box-office-report-butler-wins-614083|accessdate=August 26, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 25, 2013}} The film has grossed $116.6 million in Canada and the United States, it earned $51.1 million elsewhere, for a total of $167.7 million. ===Critical response=== ''The Butler'' received mostly positive reviews from critics, with a 71% rating on the [[film critic]] aggregate site [[Rotten Tomatoes]], based on 175 reviews. The site's consensus says, "Gut-wrenching and emotionally affecting, ''Lee Daniels' The Butler'' overcomes an uneven narrative thanks to strong performances from an all-star cast."{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/lee_daniels_the_butler/ |title=''Lee Daniels' The Butler'' (2013) |publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] |date=August 16, 2013 |accessdate=August 16, 2013}} Another review aggregator, [[Metacritic]], which assigns a [[Normalization (statistics)|normalized]] rating out of 100 top reviews from mainstream critics, calculated a score of 66 based on 47 reviews, indicating "generally positive reviews".{{cite web|title=Lee Daniels' The Butler|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/lee-daniels-the-butler|publisher=Metacritic|accessdate=August 16, 2013}} [[Todd McCarthy]] praised the film saying, "Even with all contrivances and obvious point-making and familiar historical signposting, Daniels' ''The Butler'' is always engaging, often entertaining and certainly never dull."{{cite news|last=McCarthy|first=Todd|title=Lee Daniels' The Butler: Film Review|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/movie/butler/review/601991|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 9, 2013}} [[Richard Roeper]] lauded the film's casting in particular, remarking that "Forest Whitaker gives the performance of his career".{{cite news|last=Roeper|first=Richard|title=Lee Daniels' The Butler|url=http://www.richardroeper.com/reviews/leedanielsthebutler.aspx|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=Richard Roeper & The Movies}} [[Rolling Stone (magazine)|''Rolling Stone'']] also spoke highly of Whitaker writing that his "reflective, powerfully understated performance...fills this flawed film with potency and purpose."{{cite news|last=Travers|first=Peter|title=Lee Daniels' The Butler|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/lee-daniels-the-butler-20130815|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=Rolling Stone|date=August 15, 2013}} [[Variety (magazine)|''Variety'']] wrote that "Daniels develops a strong sense of the inner complexities and contradictions of the civil-rights landscape."{{cite news|last=Foundas|first=Scott|title=Film Review: 'Lee Daniels' The Butler'|url=https://variety.com/2013/film/reviews/lee-daniels-the-butler-review-forest-whitaker-oprah-winfrey-1200575215/|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=Variety|date=August 8, 2013}} ''[[USA Today]]'' gave the film three out of four stars and noted that "It's inspiring and filled with fine performances, but the insistently swelling musical score and melodramatic moments seem calculated and undercut a powerful story."{{cite news|last=Puig|first=Claudia|title='The Butler' is mannered and moving|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/movies/2013/08/15/the-butler-review/2581949/|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=USA Today|date=August 15, 2013}} Miles Davis of the ''[[New York Tribune]]'' gave the film a negative review, claiming the film to be "[[Oscar bait]]", a cliche film designed to attract Oscar nominations."The Butler Review", New York Tribune, 2013. [[Kenneth Turan]] of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' was more negative; "An ambitious and overdue attempt to create a Hollywood-style epic around the experience of black Americans in general and the civil rights movement in particular, it undercuts itself by hitting its points squarely on the nose with a 9-pound hammer."{{cite news|last=Turan|first=Kenneth|title=Review: 'Lee Daniels' The Butler' significant but often contrived|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-review-the-butler,0,581076.story|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=The Los Angeles Times|date=August 15, 2013}} Several critics compared the film's historical anecdotes and sentimentality to [[Forrest Gump (film)|''Forrest Gump'']].{{cite news|last=Anderson|first=John|title='Lee Daniels' The Butler' movie review|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/goingoutguide/movies/lee-daniels-the-butler-movie-review/2013/08/14/a8976a42-0443-11e3-9259-e2aafe5a5f84_story.html|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=August 15, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Rodriguez|first=Rene|title='Lee Daniels' The Butler' (PG-13)|url=http://www.miami.com/039lee-daniels039-butler039-pg-13-article|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=Miami Herald|date=August 15, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Williams|first=Joe|title=Forest Whitaker shines as 'The Butler'|url=http://www.stltoday.com/entertainment/movies/reviews/forest-whitaker-shines-as-the-butler/article_9622adf4-b80a-584c-b0ec-6dcb97a840b2.html|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|date=August 15, 2013}}{{cite news|last=Burr|first=Ty|title='The Butler' examines civil rights history from a new perspective|url=http://www.boston.com/ae/movies/2013/08/15/movie-review-lee-daniels-the-butler-examines-civil-rights-history-from-whole-new-perspective/XRwirtvqC0IWlFk0o1Mj0M/story.html|accessdate=August 16, 2013|newspaper=The Boston Globe|date=August 15, 2013}} President [[Barack Obama]] said, "I teared up thinking about not just the butlers who worked here in the White House, but an entire generation of people who were talented and skilled. But because of [[Jim Crow laws|Jim Crow]] and because of [[discrimination]], there was only so far they could go."{{cite news|last=Child|first=Ben |title=Barack Obama 'teared up' watching Oscar-tipped drama The Butler |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/aug/28/barack-obama-oscar-tipped-drama-butler |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=August 28, 2013}} === Accolades === {| class="wikitable" width="100%" |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! colspan="5" style="background: LightSteelBlue;" | Awards |- style="background:#ccc; text-align:center;" ! Direction & Production Design |Diane Lederman, Tim Galvin |{{nom}} |} ===Historical accuracy=== Regarding historical accuracy, Eliana Dockterman wrote in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'': "Allen was born on a [[Virginia]] plantation in 1919, not in Georgia.... In the movie, Cecil Gaines grows up on a cotton field in Macon, where his family comes into conflict with the white farmers for whom they work. What befalls his parents on the cotton field was [[Stereotypes of African Americans|added for dramatic effect]].... Though tension between father and son over civil rights issues fuels most of the drama in the film, [Eugene Allen's son] Charles Allen was not the radical political activist that Gaines's son is in the movie."{{cite news|last=Dockterman |first=Eliana |title=The True Story of The Butler: Fact vs. Fiction in Lee Daniels' The Butler |url=http://entertainment.time.com/2013/08/16/what-the-butler-really-saw/ |newspaper=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=August 16, 2013}} Particular criticism has been directed at the film's accuracy in portraying President [[Ronald Reagan]]. While Alan Rickman's performance generated positive reviews, the director and screenwriters of the film have been criticized for depicting Reagan as indifferent to civil rights and his reluctance to associate with the White House's black employees during his presidency. According to [[Michael Reagan]], the former president's son, "The real story of the White House butler doesn't imply racism at all. It's simply Hollywood liberals wanting to believe something about my father that was never there."{{cite news|last=Bond|first=Paul|title=President Reagan's Son Attacks 'Lee Daniels' The Butler'|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/president-reagans-son-attacks-lee-614568 |accessdate=August 28, 2013|newspaper=The Hollywood Reporter|date=August 26, 2013}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/aug/29/the-butler-ronald-reagan-not-racist|publisher=The Guardian|title=The Butler falsely portrays Ronald Reagan as racist, says son|date=August 29, 2013|accessdate=September 1, 2013}}{{cite news|publisher=Newsmax|title=The Butler from Another Planet|url=http://www.newsmax.com/Reagan/Butler-Reagan-Oprah-Allen/2013/08/22/id/521814|date=August 27, 2013|first=Michael|last=Reagan|accessdate=December 25, 2013}} [[Paul Kengor]], one of President Reagan's biographers, also attacked the film, saying, "I've talked to many White House staff, cooks, housekeepers, doctors, and Secret Service over the years. They are universal in their love of Ronald Reagan." In regard to the president's initial opposition to sanctions against [[apartheid]] in South Africa, Kengor said, "Ronald Reagan was appalled by apartheid, but also wanted to ensure that if the apartheid regime collapsed in South Africa that it wasn't replaced by a Marxist-totalitarian regime allied with Moscow and Cuba that would take the South African people down the same road as Ethiopia, Mozambique, and, yes, Cuba. In the immediate years before Reagan became president, 11 countries from the Third World, from Asia to Africa to Latin America, went Communist. It was devastating. If the film refuses to deal with this issue with the necessary balance, it shouldn't deal with it at all."{{cite news|url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/lee-daniels-butler-reagan-biographers-608233|title=Lee Daniels' 'The Butler': Reagan Biographers Slam President's Portrayal|work=The Hollywood Reporter.com|date=August 16, 2013|accessdate=September 1, 2013}} ==See also== * ''[[Backstairs at the White House]]'', a 1979 miniseries with a similar theme * [[African-American Civil Rights Movement (1954–68) in popular culture]] * [[Great Migration (African American)|Great Migration]] * [[List of black films of the 2010s]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.weinsteinco.com/sites/leedanielsthebutler/ Official website] * {{IMDb title|1327773|The Butler}} * {{mojo title|butler|The Butler}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|lee_daniels_the_butler|The Butler}} * {{metacritic film|lee-daniels-the-butler|The Butler}} {{Lee Daniels|state=expanded}} {{Danny Strong}} {{African-American Civil Rights Movement}} {{Portal bar|2010s|African Americans|Film in the United States|Government of the United States}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Butler}} [[Category:2013 films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:2010s historical films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:American historical films]] [[Category:American political drama films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Lee Daniels]] [[Category:African-American films]] [[Category:African-American civil rights movement (1954–68) in film]] [[Category:Films about politicians]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Dwight D. revision.text:
[[Image:Ranoa.jpg|thumb|250px|Composite photograph from The Hapa Project by Kip Fulbeck]] '''The Hapa Project''' is a [[multiracial]] [[Cultural identity|identity]] [[art]] project created by American artist [[Kip Fulbeck]]. The project embodies a range of mediums, including a published book, traveling photographic exhibition, satellite community presentations, and online communities.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://citizen.nfb.ca/hapa-project |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-09-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120708100712/http://citizen.nfb.ca/hapa-project |archivedate=2012-07-08 |df= }} </ref> <ref name="imdiversity1">{{cite web|url=http://www.imdiversity.com/Villages/Asian/arts_culture_media/archives/fulbeck_hapa_project.asp |accessdate=September 5, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704071724/http://www.imdiversity.com/Villages/Asian/arts_culture_media/archives/fulbeck_hapa_project.asp |archivedate=July 4, 2008 }}</ref> <ref>[http://www.discovernikkei.org/forum/en/node/1188] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070614051826/http://www.discovernikkei.org/forum/en/node/1188 |date=June 14, 2007 }}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://manja.org/events/2006/05/11/kip-fulbeck-the-hapa-project-solo-exhibition |title=KIP Fulbeck: The Hapa Project Solo Exhibition |publisher=MANJA |date=2006-05-11 |accessdate=2015-02-19}}</ref>
==Overview== Fulbeck began the project in 2001, traveling the country photographing over 1200 volunteer subjects who self-identified as [[Hapa]] (defined for the project as mixed ethnic heritage with partial roots in Asian and/or Pacific Islander ancestry)<ref>[http://seaweedproductions.com/the-hapa-project/hapa-about/].</ref><ref>[http://www.discovernikkei.org/en/people/clip.php?id=495&nf=1] {{dead link|date=February 2015}}</ref> Each individual was photographed in a similar minimalist style (directly head-on, unclothed from the shoulders up, and without jewelry, glasses, excess make-up, or purposeful expression). After being photographed, participants chose their own racial/ethnic terms to describe themselves, then responded to the question "What are you?" in their own handwriting. The photographs, self-descriptions, and handwritten responses were then combined and displayed as a collection.<ref>[https://archive.is/20070518155355/http://www.discovernikkei.org/en/people/clip.php?id=480&nf=1] </ref>
Over 1200 volunteer participants were photographed at dozens of shoots throughout California and Hawaii, as well as Illinois, New York, and Wisconsin.<ref name="discovernikkei1">{{cite web|last=Fulbeck |first=Kip |url=http://www.discovernikkei.org/forum/en/node/2297 |title=kip fulbeck: part asian, 100% hapa – an artist’s thoughts |publisher=Discover Nikkei |date=2008-03-18 |accessdate=2015-02-19}}</ref>
==Objective== The Hapa Project was created to promote awareness and recognition of the millions of multiracial/multiethnic individuals of Asian/Pacific Islander descent in the U.S; to give voice to multiracial people and previously ignored ethnic groups; to dispel myths of exoticism, hybrid vigor and racial homogeneity; to foster positive identity formation and self-image in multiracial children; and to encourage solidarity and empowerment within the multiracial/Hapa community.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.imdiversity.com/Villages/Asian/arts_culture_media/archives/fulbeck_hapa_project.asp |accessdate=September 5, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080704071724/http://www.imdiversity.com/Villages/Asian/arts_culture_media/archives/fulbeck_hapa_project.asp |archivedate=July 4, 2008 }}</ref> Fulbeck also notes that a main objective "... was to make the book I wish I owned when I was a kid. I never knew anyone else like me, going through things I went through, not fitting in, always having to choose sides ... Identity is a personal process and I’m adamant that it should be a personal decision, not one made by a community, a government or others." <ref>[http://www.kyotojournal.org/10,000things/184.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513031725/http://www.kyotojournal.org/10,000things/184.html |date=May 13, 2008 }}</ref>
==Use of race as identifier== Fulbeck states that despite its utilization of common racial classifications, The Hapa Project is fundamentally a project about identity rather than a project about race: "It's about identity using race as a starting point." <ref name="fulbeck1">{{cite web|last=Fulbeck |first=Kip |url=http://www.discovernikkei.org/forum/en/node/2298 |title=kip fulbeck: part asian, 100% hapa – an artist’s thoughts - part 2 |publisher=Discover Nikkei |date=2008-03-19 |accessdate=2015-02-19}}</ref> He argues that race in itself is not biologically determined, but socially created: "For the record, race is not a scientifically sound assumption. For example, there is no DNA difference between human beings. We are all African. Biologically, race does not exist. It is a social and [[cultural construct]] ... The U.S. is a country with a long history of social genocide (Native Americans, African slavery, etc.) and this was all due to the seeming differences we attributed to race. Yes, it is very convenient to categorize people according to race. It is also extremely inaccurate, however." <ref name="fulbeck1"/>
==Conceptual strategies== [[Image:janm2.jpg|thumb|400px|The Hapa Project at the Japanese American National Museum]] [[Image:janm1.jpg|thumb|400px|The Hapa Project at the Japanese American National Museum]] The use of a clinical photographic style combined with the listing of the subject's ethnic heritage alongside their image visually quotes from various pseudo-scientific 18th and 19th century racial studies of [[Carl Linnaeus]], [[Johann Friedrich Blumenbach]], and [[Arthur de Gobineau]] [See: Spickard, Paul, ''Almost All Aliens'', Routledge, New York, NY 2007] However, Fulbeck's decision to have the subjects self-designate their ethnicity and to include their individual handwritten statements counters this methodology, giving ownership and responsibility to the subjects themselves. As historian Paul Spickard writes, "Kip Fulbeck is using the pictures to provoke and encourage his readers. He is using the old form, but with exactly opposite content." [See: Fulbeck, Kip, Part Asian, 100% Hapa, Chronicle Books, San Francisco 2006, p. 261]
The project also plays upon and critiques the official photographs each person has taken for their driver's licenses, passports and other forms of identification.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.janm.org/press/release/92/ |title=Photographic Exhibition Kip Fulbeck: Part Asian, 100% Hapa Explores Perceptions of Identity, Questions Notions of Race, Ethnicity | Press Releases | Japanese American National Museum |publisher=Janm.org |date= |accessdate=2015-02-19}}</ref>
A further strategy aimed at diminishing the power dynamic between photographer/subject was to have each participant choose their own image, with the option of re-photographing them if they desired. Fulbeck states, "... every participant not only got to write their statement the way they wanted to, they also got to pick their own image. A camera is a tremendously powerful tool and the power dynamic between photographer and subject is palpable. For this reason, I wanted to give some of the power back to the subjects. It was never going to be completely democratic – it is, after all, my concept, my project, and my design – but there are some strategies you can employ to make it less unilateral. Everyone got to see their image and choose to keep it or erase it and shoot again." One participant was re-photographed 27 times.<ref name="imdiversity1"/>
==Offshoot projects== Numerous schools and community organizations have created similar projects inspired by Fulbeck's work.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/emory_omps/sets/72157602156257949/set=72157602156257949&nsid=43037005@N00&lang=en-us |accessdate=September 5, 2008 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.brown.edu/Student_Services/TWC/2006_2007/aahm.html |title=ANNOUNCEMENTS | Brown Center for Students of Color |publisher=Brown.edu |date= |accessdate=2015-02-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dbq.edu/news/news1.cfm?ID=375 |accessdate=September 5, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080731214017/http://www.dbq.edu/news/news1.cfm?ID=375 |archivedate=July 31, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discovernikkei.org/nikkeialbum/en/collection/6926/item/7435 |title=The Hapa Collection |publisher=Discover Nikkei |date= |accessdate=2015-02-19}}</ref>
==Exhibition history== [[Image:hapaproject1.jpg|thumb|400px|Participatory component of The Hapa Project]] The Hapa Project publicly premiered in 2006 at the [[Japanese American National Museum]] with a 5-month solo exhibition entitled "kip fulbeck: part asian, 100% hapa." The work has also exhibited at Space180 Gallery (San Francisco), Mandeville Gallery (New York), [[The Field Museum]], [[University of North Carolina]], [[Oakland University]], [[Northern Arizona University]], [[Santa Clara University]], and [[Woodward Academy]], among others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://seaweedproductions.com/bio/curriculum-vitae/ |title=Curriculum Vitae - Kip Fulbeck |publisher=Seaweedproductions.com |date= |accessdate=2015-02-19}}</ref> Sixteen images from the series are included in the [[Science Museum of Minnesota]]'s exhibition ''Race: Are We So Different?'' currently touring nationally.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.smm.org/travelingexhibits/race/gallery/11/ |title=Science Museum of Minnesota - The Hapa Project |publisher=Smm.org |date= |accessdate=2015-02-19}}</ref>
Many of the exhibitions include a participatory component where visitors can take part in the project by having their picture taken and writing an individual statement.
==Public attention== The project has received both national and international news coverage, being featured on [[CNN]], [[MTV]], [[PBS]], [[NPR]], and [[Voice of America]]. Major newspapers covering the project include [[The Los Angeles Times]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/jun/11/local/me-hapas11 |title=Mixed-Race Asians Find Pride as Hapas - Los Angeles Times |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=2006-06-11 |accessdate=2015-02-19}}</ref> [[Orange County Register]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ocregister.com/ocregister/life/homepage/article_1158297.php |title=Hapa nation |publisher=Ocregister.com |accessdate=19 February 2015}}</ref> and Kyoto Journal. It has also been featured on dozens of websites exploring race and identity in the U.S. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://themadhapa.blogspot.com/2008/07/hapa-project.html |title=Behind the Orange Curtain: The Hapa Project |publisher=Themadhapa.blogspot.com |date=2008-07-24 |accessdate=2015-02-19}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://asiancajuns.blogspot.com/2007/05/were-hapas.html |title=AsianCajuns: We're Hapa(s): The Hapa Project |publisher=Asiancajuns.blogspot.com |date=2007-05-23 |accessdate=2015-02-19}}</ref> <ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110724020308/http://www.thefighting44s.com/forum/showthread.php?t=4465] </ref>
==Book== [[Image:Part Asian 100% Hapa Cover.jpg|thumb|''Part Asian, 100% Hapa'' (Chronicle Books)]] A book based on the project entitled ''Part Asian, 100% Hapa'' was published by [[Chronicle Books]] in 2006. It features a foreword by musician [[Sean Lennon]] and an afterword by historian Paul Spickard.
The book includes portraits and statements from approximately 10% of the overall project participants. Fulbeck has discussed the difficulties in selecting these images from the overall pool, as well the problematic of selecting a single image for the book cover. He also has written about the conscious decision to dispel stereotypes of Hapa people all being conventionally attractive.<ref name="discovernikkei1"/>
==Influences== Fulbeck cites photographer [[Jim Goldberg]] and comic artist [[Lynda Barry]] as specifically influential to the creation of the project. Lynda Barry also participated in the project and is included in ''Part Asian, 100% Hapa.'' Fulbeck also credits historian Paul Spickard as a major influence, particularly his book ''Mixed Blood: Intermarriage & Ethnic: Intermarriage And Ethnic Identity In Twentieth Century America'' (University of Wisconsin Press, 1991) [See: Fulbeck, Kip, ''Part Asian, 100% Hapa'', Chronicle Books, San Francisco 2006, pp. 8, 55, 259].
==Anonymity and celebrity== Participant names are listed alphabetically in both the photographic exhibition and book (without index to individual images). Fulbeck chose participant anonymity both for the safety of the children and as a thematic strategy. "...I wanted participants to have as blank a slate as possible to work with, to not be burdened by any pre-existing identifiers. It’s interesting with celebrities, because celebrities without their gear – their look or environment or entourage – don’t look like celebrities. They look like people. And that’s what I wanted. I could photograph Cher this way and she’d look like a regular person." <ref name="discovernikkei1"/>
Celebrities in the project include [[Lynda Barry]], [[Wuv Bernardo]], [[Asia Carrera]], [[Karen David]], [[Amy Hill]], [[Sean Lennon]], Liz Masakayan, [[Greg Pak]], [[Sonny Sandoval]], and [[Sandra Tsing Loh]].
==Emerging patterns== Two-thirds of the project volunteers were part Japanese-American. An overwhelming majority of participants were female, including some shoots where women outnumbered men 20:1.<ref name="discovernikkei1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discovernikkei.org/en/people/clip.php?id=485&nf=1 |accessdate=September 5, 2008 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref>
==Current work== Fulbeck followed ''Part Asian, 100% Hapa'' with the publication of ''Permanence: Tattoo Portraits by Kip Fulbeck'' in 2008 and ''Mixed: Portraits of Multiracial Kids'' in 2010 (both by [[Chronicle Books]]). Both books also had accompanying solo exhibitions.<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://asianamericanart.blogspot.com/2009/01/permanence-tattoo-portraits-by-kip.html |title=Asian American Art: “Permanence”, Tattoo Portraits By Kip Fulbeck Invisible NYC |publisher=Asianamericanart.blogspot.com |date=2009-01-05 |accessdate=2015-02-19}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.janm.org/exhibits/mixed/ |title=About | MIXED: Portraits of Multiracial Kids by Kip Fulbeck | Japanese American National Museum |publisher=Janm.org |date= |accessdate=2015-02-19}}</ref> A major speaker on the college circuit, Fulbeck has spoken on The Hapa Project at hundreds of campuses throughout the U.S. He is represented by The Creative Artists Agency in Los Angeles. <ref>{{cite web|url=http://seaweedproductions.com/the-hapa-project/exhibitions/ |title=Exhibiting - Kip Fulbeck |publisher=Seaweedproductions.com |date= |accessdate=2015-02-19}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Hapa]] *[[Multiracial]] *[[Mixed Race Day]] *[[Race of the Future]]
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== * [http://seaweedproductions.com/the-hapa-project/ The Hapa Project] * [http://www.discovernikkei.org/en/people/profile.php?id=48&nf=1 Interview with Kip Fulbeck/The Hapa Project - Discover Nikkei] * [http://articles.latimes.com/2006/jun/11/local/me-hapas11 Mixed-Race Asian Find Pride as Hapas - Los Angeles Times] * [http://www.hyphenmagazine.com/content/view/14/ Kip Fulbeck: The Face of Hapa - Hyphen Magazine] * [http://asiancemagazine.com/jul_2006/the_hapa_project A Hapa Project: Identity Outside the Color Lines - Asiance Magazine] * [http://www.kyotojournal.org/10,000things/184.html Global Hapa; A Conversation with Kip Fulbeck - Kyoto Journal] * [http://www.asiansofmixedrace.com/may06.htm Book Review: Part Asian, 100% Hapa - AsiansOfMixedRace.com] * [http://asiansofmixedrace.com/intmar08.htm Kip Fulbeck Interview - AsiansOfMixedRace.com] * [http://www.ocregister.com/ocregister/life/homepage/article_1158297.php Hapa Nation - Orange County Register] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3zUsCLBN9NQ Discussion of Hapa identity - CNN] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V_LI1GutNvE Growing Up Hapa - CNN's Betty Nguyen profiles Kip Fulbeck & The Hapa Project] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hV_m6dLlEMs The Hapa Project at Space180 Gallery - MTV-Chi] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1SJp36RFhig Reflections on Obama and being Hapa - PBS]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hapa Project}} [[Category:Asian-American issues]] [[Category:Asian-American culture]] [[Category:Ethnic studies]] [[Category:American studies]] [[Category:Asian studies]] [[Category:American art]] [[Category:Multiracial affairs in the United States]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | image_file = Jacob van Ruisdael - Watermill - NGV.jpg | caption = | painting_alignment = | image_size = 300px | title = The Watermill | alt = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | artist = [[Jacob van Ruisdael]] | year = c. 1660 | material = | height_metric = 64.7 | width_metric = 70.8 | length_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_metric = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | metric_unit = cm<!--don't leave this parameter blank—either don't include it, or include the default cm. Not including it will default it to cm.--> | imperial_unit = in<!--don't leave this parameter blank—either don't include it, or include the default in. Not including it will default it to in.--> | city = [[Melbourne]] | museum = [[National Gallery of Victoria]] | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the exact coordinates of the artwork itself (and only where known) and not for the coordinates of the museum. Leave blank if coordinates are not known. --> | owner = | url={{URL|www.ngv.vic.gov.au/explore/collection/work/4325/}} }} [[File:Jacob van Ruisdael, een watermolen schetsend Rijksmuseum SK-A-4865.jpeg|thumb|Historical painting of Jacob van Ruisdael sketching a watermill in Gelderland, by [[Gerard Bilders]], a 19th-century landscape painter who was inspired by Ruisdael's work]] '''''The Watermill''''' (c. 1660) is an [[oil painting|oil]] on canvas painting by the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] landscape painter [[Jacob van Ruisdael]]. It is an example of [[Dutch Golden Age painting]] and is now in the collection of the [[National Gallery of Victoria]].
This painting was documented by [[Hofstede de Groot]] in 1911, who wrote; "146. THE WATER-MILL. View across the mill-pool towards the water-mill, which stands amid trees. The same mill as that painted by [[Meindert Hobbema|Hobbema]], as, for example, in the two pictures at the Rijksmuseum (see Hobbema, 66, 67). The building on the right is roofed with red tiles, and the timbers are grey. To the left is a green hill. There is no distant view. On the road to the left is a man, followed by a dog. To the right is a flowering elder bush. To judge from the style, the picture was probably painted about the time when Hobbema and Ruisdael worked together (1660-63). Signed with the monogram on the left ; canvas, 25 inches by 27 1/2 inches.
Exhibited at the [[Royal Academy]] Winter Exhibition, London, 1876, No. 80, and 1902, No. 134. In the collection of the Right Hon. Lewis Fry, Clifton, Bristol. "<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/catalogueraisonn04hofsuoft#page/51/mode/1up Entry 146 (Ruisdael) for ''''The Water-Mill''] in Hofstede de Groot, 1911</ref>
This scene is very similar to other paintings Ruisdael and his pupil Hobbema made in this period and these often served as inspiration for later painters of landscape. <gallery> File:Jacob van Ruisdael - Watermill.jpg|Private collection, by Jacob and formerly in the [[Toledo Museum of Art]]. File:Een watermolen Rijksmuseum SK-C-144.jpeg|[[Rijksmuseum]], by Hobbema.<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/catalogueraisonn04hofsuoft#page/375/mode/1up Entry 66 (Hobbema) for ''''A Water-Mill''] in Hofstede de Groot, 1911</ref> File:Een watermolen Rijksmuseum SK-A-156.jpeg|Rijksmuseum, by Hobbema.<ref>[https://archive.org/stream/catalogueraisonn04hofsuoft#page/376/mode/1up Entry 67 (Hobbema) for ''''A Water-Mill''] in Hofstede de Groot, 1911</ref> </gallery>
Scholars have tried to locate this specific watermill as it was portrayed so many times, but so far it has only been documented as being "somewhere in [[Gelderland]]."
== References == {{Commons category|Paintings of waterworks by Jacob van Ruisdael}} {{reflist}}
{{Jacob van Ruisdael}} {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:The watermill}} [[Category:1650s paintings]] [[Category:Paintings by Jacob van Ruisdael]] [[Category:Paintings of the National Gallery of Victoria]] [[Category:Water in art]]
