revision.text:
[[File:Gustave Courbet - The Origin of the World - WGA05503.jpg|thumb|right|300px|[[Gustave Courbet]]'s 1866 painting "[[L'Origine du monde|The Origin of the World]]"]] The '''vagina and vulva have been depicted in art''' from [[prehistoric art|prehistory]] to the [[contemporary art]] era of the 21st century. [[Visual art]] forms representing the female genitals encompass two-dimensional (e.g. paintings) and three-dimensional (e.g. statuettes). As long ago as 35,000 years ago, people sculpted [[Venus figurine]]s that exaggerated the abdomen, hips, breasts, thighs, or [[vulva]].
In 1866, [[Gustave Courbet]] painted a picture of a nude woman which depicted the female genitals, entitled "[[L'Origine du monde|The Origin of the World]]". In the 20th and 21st century, artists such as [[Niki de Saint Phalle]], [[Jean Tinguely]], [[Megumi Igarashi]] and [[Anish Kapoor]] have created artworks that depict the [[vagina]] or [[vulva]]. Sometimes these are explicitly works of [[feminist art]]: [[Judy Chicago]] created ''[[The Dinner Party]]'' to celebrate 39 women of history and myth, many of whom had fallen into obscurity. Other artists deny that their works reference the vulva or vagina, although critics view them as such; the flower paintings of [[Georgia O'Keeffe]] are a case in point.
There have long been folklore traditions, such as the ''[[vagina loquens]]'' ("talking vagina") and the ''[[vagina dentata]]'' ("toothed vagina"). Playwright [[Eve Ensler]] wrote the ''[[Vagina Monologues]]'', a popular stage work about many aspects of [[human female sexuality|women's sexuality]]. In some cases, vagina- or vulva-themed art has attracted controversy and led to legal issues or official [[censorship]] pertaining to perceptions of [[obscenity]].
==Cultural aspects== {{See also|Culture and menstruation}} [[File:Cattien stone yoni.png|thumb|right|The vagina represents a powerful symbol as the ''[[yoni]]'' in [[Hindu]] thought. Pictured is a stone yoni found in [[Cát Tiên]] sanctuary, Lam Dong, Vietnam.]] Various perceptions of the vagina have existed throughout history, including the belief it is the center of [[sexual desire]], a metaphor for life via birth, inferior to the penis, visually unappealing, inherently unpleasant to smell, or otherwise vulgar.<ref name="Stone">{{cite book |last=Stone |first=Linda|title=New Directions in Anthropological Kinship|publisher=[[Rowman & Littlefield]]|page=164|isbn=058538424X |year=2002 |accessdate=June 9, 2014 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uaKaAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA164}}</ref><ref name="Hutcherson">{{cite book |last=Hutcherson |first=Hilda|title=What Your Mother Never Told You about Sex|publisher=[[Penguin Books|Penguin]]|page=8|isbn=0399528539 |year=2003 |accessdate=June 9, 2014 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xu8tb2o66iIC&pg=PA8}}</ref><ref name="LaFont">{{cite book |last=LaFont |first=Suzanne|title=Constructing Sexualities: Readings in Sexuality, Gender, and Culture|publisher=[[Prentice Hall]]|page=145|isbn=013009661X |year=2003 |accessdate=June 9, 2014 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dtftAAAAMAAJ&q=&hl=en&sa=X&ei=mVKWU4TuOoqbyATD_YL4CQ&ved=0CD4Q6AEwAjgK}}</ref> The vagina has been known by many names,<ref name="Ensler">{{cite book |last=Ensler |first=Eve |authorlink=Eve Ensler |title=The Vagina Monologues: The V-Day Edition |publisher=[[Random House|Random House LLC]] |isbn=0375506586|year=2001 |accessdate=June 9, 2014 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=G74c4i2SUmAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=The+Vagina+monologues&hl}}</ref> including the ancient [[vulgarism]] "[[cunt]]", euphemisms ("lady garden"), slang ("[[pussy]]"), and [[derogatory]] [[epithet]]s. Some cultures view the [[vulva]] as something shameful that should be hidden. For example, the term ''pudendum'', the Latin term used in medical English for the external genitalia, literally means "shameful thing".
Positive views of the vagina use it to represent female sexuality, spirituality, or life, e.g. as a "powerful symbol of womanliness, openness, acceptance, and receptivity ... the inner valley spirit".<ref name="Linn">{{cite book|author=Denise Linn|title=Secret Language of Signs|publisher=[[Random House|Random House Publishing Group]]|page=276|isbn=0307559556|year=2009 |accessdate=November 21, 2014|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YB5_AT_By6IC&pg=PA276}}</ref> Hinduism has given the world the symbol of the ''[[yoni]]'', and this may indicate the value that Hindu society has given female sexuality and the vagina's ability to birth life.<ref name="Wignaraja">{{cite book|authors=Ponna Wignaraja, Akmal Hussain|title=The Challenge in South Asia: Development, Democracy and Regional Cooperation|publisher=[[United Nations University Press]]|page=309|isbn=0803996039|year=1989 |accessdate=November 21, 2014|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y9DmV9-0on0C&pg=PA309}}</ref> Other ancient cultures celebrated and even worshipped the vulva, for example in some [[ancient Middle East]]ern religions and the [[paleolithic]] artworks dubbed "[[Old Europe (archaeology)|Old Europe]]" by archaeologist [[Marija Gimbutas]]. As an aspect of [[Goddess|Goddess worship]] such reverence may be part of modern [[Neopaganism|Neopagan]] beliefs.
==History==
===Prehistory=== [[File:Venus-of-Schelklingen.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The [[Venus of Hohle Fels]] sculpture, which is at least 35,000 years old, is the oldest example of a vulva in art.]]
Two-dimensional and three-dimensional representations of the vulva, i.e. paintings and [[figurine]]s, exist from tens of millennia ago. They are some of the earliest works of [[prehistoric art]].
The [[cave of Chufín]] located in the town of Riclones in [[Cantabria]] ([[Spain]]) has prehistoric rock art which may be a depiction of the vulva. The cave was occupied at different periods, the oldest being around 20,000 years ago. Aside from schematic engravings and paintings of animals, there are also many symbols, such as a those known as "sticks". There is also a large number of drawings using points (''puntillaje''), including one which has been interpreted as a representation of a vulva.
A [[Venus figurine]] is any [[Upper Paleolithic]] statuette portraying a woman. Most have been unearthed in Europe, but others have been found as far away as Siberia, extending their distribution across much of Eurasia. Most of them date from the [[Gravettian]] period (28,000–22,000 years ago), but examples exist as early as the [[Venus of Hohle Fels]], which dates back at least 35,000 years to the [[Aurignacian]], and as late as the [[Venus of Monruz]], from about 11,000 years ago in the [[Magdalenian]].
These figurines were carved from soft stone (such as [[steatite]], [[calcite]] or [[limestone]]), bone or ivory, or formed of [[clay]] and fired. The latter are among the oldest [[ceramic]]s known. In total, over a hundred such figurines are known; virtually all of modest size, between 4 cm and 25 cm in height. Most of them have small heads, wide hips, and legs that taper to a point. Various figurines exaggerate the abdomen, hips, breasts, thighs, or vulva. In contrast, arms and feet are often absent, and the head is usually small and faceless.
===Ancient times=== The ancient [[Sumer]]ians regarded the vulva as sacred<ref>{{cite book|last=Dening|first=Sarah|date=1996|chapter=Chapter 3: Sex in Ancient Civilizations|title=The Mythology of Sex|url=http://www.ishtartemple.org/myth.htm|location=London, England|publisher=Macmillian|isbn=978-0-02-861207-2|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Leick2013">{{citation|last=Leick|first=Gwendolyn|title=Sex and Eroticism in Mesopotamian Literature|publisher=Routledge|year=2013|isbn=978-1-134-92074-7|location=New York City, New York|page=96|quote=|via=|origyear=1994|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WKoWblE4pd0C&pg=PA64&source=gbs_toc_r&cad=3#v=onepage&q&f=false|ref=harv}}</ref> and a vast number of [[Sumerian poetry|Sumerian poems]] praising the vulva of the goddess [[Inanna]] have survived.<ref name="Leick2013"/> In [[Sumerian religion]], the goddess [[Nin-imma]] is the divine personification of female genitalia.<ref name="Ceccarelli">{{cite book|last=Ceccarelli|first=Manuel|date=2016|title=Enki und Ninmah: Eine mythische Erzählung in sumerischer Sprache|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0mI552wy2ccC&pg=PA21&dq=Nin-imma+personification+of+female+genitalia&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjxhcCyl_LaAhWZ2YMKHRQLDSIQ6AEIKzAB#v=onepage&q=Nin-imma%20personification%20of%20female%20genitalia&f=false|location=Tübingen, Germany|publisher=Mohr Siebeck|series=Orientalische Relionen in der Antik|volume=16|isbn=978-3-16-154278-7|page=21|ref=harv}}</ref><ref name="Launderville">{{cite book|last=Launderville|first=Dale|date=2010|title=Celibacy in the Ancient World: Its Ideal and Practice in Pre-Hellenistic Israel, Mesopotamia, and Greece|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yDe0gv9GJQcC&pg=PA184&dq=Nin-imma&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwja8rDAmfLaAhWL8YMKHSTDDesQ6AEIMjAC#v=onepage&q=Nin-imma&f=false|series=A Michael Glazier Book|location=Collegeville, Maryland|publisher=Liturgical Press|isbn=978-0-8146-5734-8|page=184|ref=harv}}</ref> Her name literally means "lady female genitals".<ref name="Launderville"/> She appears in one version of the myth of ''[[Enki]] and Ninsikila'' in which she is the daughter of Enki and [[Ninkurra]].<ref name="Launderville"/><ref name="Jacobsen">{{cite book|last=Jacobsen|first=Thorkild|date=1987|title=The Harps that Once...: Sumerian Poetry in Translation|url=https://books.google.com/?id=L-BI0h41yCEC&pg=PA184&dq=Uttu#v=onepage&q=Uttu&f=false|location=New Haven, Connecticut|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=0300072783|page=195|ref=harv}}</ref> Enki rapes her and causes her to give birth to [[Uttu]], the goddess of weaving and vegetation.<ref name="Launderville"/><ref name="Jacobsen"/> Vaginal fluid is always described in Sumerian texts as tasting "sweet"<ref name="Leick2013"/> and, in a Sumerian Bridal Hymn, a young maiden rejoices that her vulva has grown hair.<ref name="Leick2013"/> Clay models of vulvae were discovered in the temple of Inanna at [[Ashur]];<ref name="BlackGreen1992">{{cite book|last1=Black|first1=Jeremy|first2=Anthony|last2=Green|title=Gods, Demons and Symbols of Ancient Mesopotamia: An Illustrated Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=05LXAAAAMAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=Inana|publisher=The British Museum Press|year=1992|isbn=0-7141-1705-6|pages=150–152|ref=harv}}</ref> these models likely served as some form of [[amulet]]s, possibly to protect against [[impotency]].<ref name="BlackGreen1992"/>
===11th and 12th century=== [[File:SheelaWiki.jpg|thumb|left|upright|A 12th century sheela na gig on the [[SS Mary and David's Church, Kilpeck|church]] at [[Kilpeck]], [[Herefordshire]], England]] [[Sheela na gig]]s are 11th and 12th century figurative carvings of naked women displaying an exaggerated vulva. They are [[grotesque#In architecture|architectural grotesques]] found on churches, castles, and other buildings, particularly in Ireland and Great Britain, sometimes together with male figures. One of the best examples may be found in the [[Irish round tower|Round Tower]] at [[Rattoo]], in [[County Kerry]], Ireland. There is a replica of the round tower sheela na gig in the county museum in [[Tralee]] town. Another well-known example may be seen at [[Kilpeck]] in [[Herefordshire]], England.
Such carvings are said to ward off death and evil.<ref name=Andersen>Andersen, Jorgen ''The Witch on the Wall'' (1977) Rosenkilde & Bagger {{ISBN|978-87-423-0182-1}}</ref><ref name=Weir>Weir, Anthony & Jerman, James [https://books.google.com/books?id=lvgHL_LQ4H8C&printsec=frontcover&source=gbs_similarbooks_s&cad=1#v=onepage&q=&f=false Images of Lust: Sexual Carvings on Medieval Churches], London: B. T. Batsford Ltd, 1986</ref> Other grotesques, such as [[gargoyle]]s and [[hunky punk]]s, were frequently part of church decorations all over Europe. It is commonly said that their purpose was to keep evil spirits away through the use of [[apotropaic magic]]. They often are positioned over doors or windows, presumably to protect these openings.
Weir and Jerman argue that their location on churches and the grotesque features of the figures, by [[Middle Ages|medieval]] standards, suggests that they represented female lust as hideous and sinfully corrupting.<ref name=Weir/> Another theory, espoused by Joanne McMahon and Jack Roberts, is that the carvings are remnants of a pre-Christian fertility or [[mother goddess]] religion.<ref name=McMahon>McMahon, J. & Roberts, J. ''The Sheela-na-Gigs of Ireland and Britain: The Divine Hag of the Christian Celts – An Illustrated Guide,'' Mercier Press Ltd. (2000) {{ISBN|978-1-85635-294-9}}</ref> A 2016 book by Starr Goode called the ''Sheela na gig: The Dark Goddess of Sacred Power'', traces these images throughout history and contributes a discussion of the universality of "female sacred display" in it meanings and functions back to the origins of culture as seen in the Paleolithic cave art through the inclusion of the image in contemporary art, particularly [[feminist art]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Goode|first1=Starr|title='Sheela na gig: The Dark Goddess of Sacred Power|url=https://www.innertraditions.com/author/starr-goode/|website=Inner Traditions|publisher=Inner Traditions|accessdate=6 January 2017}}</ref>
===Folklore traditions=== The [[vagina loquens]], or "talking vagina", is a significant tradition in literature and art, dating back to ancient [[Motif (folkloristics)|folklore motifs]].<ref name=ozark>{{cite book|title=Unprintable Ozark Folksongs and Folklore: Blow the candle out|publisher=[[University of Arkansas Press]]|author=Vance Randolph, Gershon Legman |year=1992|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=S93LdPw2KP0C&source=gbs_navlinks_s|isbn=1557282374|pages=819–820}}</ref><ref name=Zizek>{{cite book|title=Organs without bodies: Deleuze and consequences|publisher=[[Routledge]]|author=Slavoj Zizek |year=2004|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Pp6-1yQbgmgC&source=gbs_navlinks_s|isbn=0415969212|page=173|accessdate=2015-10-21}}</ref> These tales usually involve vaginas talking due to the effect of magic or charms, and often admitting to their unchastity.<ref name=ozark/>
Another folk tale concerns the [[vagina dentata]] ("toothed vagina"). The implication of these tales is that sexual intercourse might result in injury, [[emasculation]], or [[castration]] for the man involved. These stories were frequently told as [[cautionary tale]]s warning of the dangers of unknown women and to discourage rape.<ref name=WhatsUp>{{cite book| isbn = 978-0-312-64436-9| url = https://books.google.com/?id=2ybaNhKqGmwC&pg=PA59| title = What's Up Down There?: Questions You'd Only Ask Your Gynecologist If She Was Your Best Friend| publisher = [[St. Martin's Press]]| date = 2010| accessdate = 2012-02-11| quote = | page= 59| author = Rankin, Lissa }}</ref>
===Contemporary art=== [[File:Blue-green.jpg|thumb|right|upright|While [[Georgia O'Keeffe]]'s paintings have been interpreted by some modern feminist artists as stylized depictions of the vulva, O'Keeffe herself consistently denied these Freudian interpretations of her paintings (pictured is "Blue and Green Music", 1921).]]
In 1966, the French artist [[Niki de Saint Phalle]] collaborated with [[Dadaist]] artist [[Jean Tinguely]] and [[:sv:Per Olof Ultvedt|Per Olof Ultvedt]] on a large sculpture installation entitled "hon-en katedral" (also spelled "Hon-en-Katedrall", which means "she-a cathedral") for Moderna Museet, in [[Stockholm]], Sweden. The outer form is a giant reclining sculpture of a woman with her legs spread. Museum patrons can go inside her body by entering a door-sized vaginal opening.<ref>[http://nikidesaintphalle.org/niki-de-saint-phalle/biography/#1965-1969 "Biography - 1965-69"], Niki de Saint Phalle Foundation, Retrieved 8 November 2014.</ref> Saint Phalle stated that the sculpture represented a [[fertility goddess]] who was able to receive visitors into her body and then "give birth" to them again.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.academia.edu/4436238/_In_sorrow_she_created_delight_An_Appeal_for_a_Greater_Appraisal_of_the_Life_and_Art_of_Niki_de_Saint_Phalle |title="In sorrow, she created delight": An Appeal for a Greater Appraisal of the Life and Art of Niki de Saint Phalle |last1=Tripp |first1=Andrew |last2= |first2= |date= |page=10 |website=www.academia.edu|publisher=Academia |access-date=24 October 2015 |quote=}}</ref> Inside her body is a screen showing [[Greta Garbo]] films, a goldfish pond and a soft drink vending machine. The piece elicited immense public reaction in magazines and newspapers throughout the world.
From 1974 to 1979, [[Judy Chicago]], a [[feminist art]]ist, created the vulva-themed [[installation art]]work "[[The Dinner Party]]". It consists of 39 elaborate place settings arranged along a triangular table for 39 mythical and historical famous women. [[Virginia Woolf]], [[Susan B. Anthony]], [[Sojourner Truth]], [[Eleanor of Aquitaine]], and [[Theodora (6th century)|Theodora of Byzantium]] are among those honoured. Each plate, except the one corresponding to Sojourner Truth (a Black woman), depicts a brightly-colored, elaborately styled butterfly-vulva form.<ref>{{cite web|title=Brooklyn Museum: Place Settings|url=https://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/place_settings/|website=www.brooklynmuseum.org}}</ref> After it was produced, despite resistance from the art world, it toured to 16 venues in six countries to a viewing audience of 15 million.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Reilly|first1=Maura|title=founding curator|url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/eascfa/dinner_party/tour_and_home.php|website=www.brooklynmuseum.org|accessdate=16 December 2014}}</ref> Since 2007, it has been on permanent exhibition in [[Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art|the Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art]] at the [[Brooklyn Museum]], New York. Chicago gave [[Georgia O'Keeffe]] a prominent place in ''The Dinner Party'', because some modern feminists believe that O'Keeffe's detailed flower paintings such as ''Black Iris III'' (1926) evoke a veiled representation of female genitalia. O'Keeffe consistently denied the validity these Freudian interpretations of her art.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.brooklynmuseum.org/opencollection/objects/166103/Georgia_OKeeffe_Place_Setting/ |title=Georgia O'Keeffe Place Setting |publisher=[[Brooklyn Museum]] |accessdate=June 5, 2015}}</ref>
Modern artistic representation of the vagina coincides with 18th century anatomical dissection and identification of the genitalia (i.e., [[William Hunter (anatomist)|William Hunter]]).<ref>Paola Uparella Carlos A. Jáuregui , "The Vagina and the Eye of Power (Essay on Genitalia and Visual Sovereignty)", H-ART. REVISTA DE HISTORIA, TEORIA Y CRITICA DE ARTE , 3 (Julio-Diciembre). https://doi.org/10.25025/hart03.2018.04</ref> Contemporary art, from a feminist perspective, has revisited and deconstructed the androcentric view of woman genitalia and the stereotypical identification with female subjectivity (i.e., Ana Mendieta, [[Enrique Chagoya]], [[Vik Muniz]], [[Candice Lin]], etc.).<ref>Paola Uparella and Carlos A. Jáuregui , "The Vagina and the Eye of Power (Essay on Genitalia and Visual Sovereignty)", H-ART. REVISTA DE HISTORIA, TEORIA Y CRITICA DE ARTE , 3 (Julio-Diciembre). https://doi.org/10.25025/hart03.2018.04</ref>
''[[The Vagina Monologues]]'', a 1996 episodic play by [[Eve Ensler]], has contributed to making female sexuality a topic of public discourse. It is made up of a varying number of monologues read by a number of women. Initially, Ensler performed every monologue herself, with subsequent performances featuring three actresses; latter versions feature a different actress for every role. Each of the monologues deals with an aspect of the [[Femininity|feminine experience]], touching on matters such as sexual activity, love, [[rape]], menstruation, female genital mutilation, masturbation, birth, orgasm, the various common names for the vagina, or simply as a physical aspect of the body. A recurring theme throughout the pieces is the vagina as a tool of female empowerment, and the ultimate embodiment of individuality.<ref>Ensler, Eve (2001). The Vagina Monologues: The V-Day Edition. Random House LLC. {{ISBN|0375506586}}. Retrieved June 9, 2014.</ref><ref name="Coleman">{{cite book |last=Coleman |first=Christine|title=Coming to Read "The Vagina Monologues": A Biomythographical Unravelling of the Narrative |publisher=[[University of New Brunswick]] |isbn=0494466553|year=2006 |accessdate=June 9, 2014 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4llrcDzDUYsC&dq=The+Vagina+monologues&hl}}</ref>
[[Jamie McCartney]], based in [[Brighton]] on the south coast of England, created the Great Wall of Vagina, made from dozens of models of vulvas, showing widespread variation.
[[Aidan Salahova]] is an Azerbaijanian artist, gallerist and public person. In an article entitled "Vagina Art Veiled at Azerbaijan's Venice Biennale Pavilion, Causing Some to Cry Censorship", Kate Deimling stated that in 2011, Salahova's "Black Stone", a "sculpture depicting the black stone in Mecca venerated by Muslims within a vagina-like marble frame, were both covered up".<ref>{{cite web|title=Vagina Art Veiled at Azerbaijan's Venice Biennale Pavilion, Causing Some to Cry Censorship|url=http://www.artinfo.com/news/story/37829/vagina-art-veiled-at-azerbaijans-venice-biennale-pavilion-causing-some-to-cry-censorship/|author=Kate Deimling|date=8 June 2011|work=Blouin Art Info}}</ref> She was representing the Azerbaijan Pavilion among other national artists at the 54th [[Venice Biennale]]. Two of her artworks previously approved by the ministry of culture were ordered to be covered and eventually removed from the exhibition a day before the opening, "because of government sensitives towards the nation's status as a secular Muslim country".<ref>Rob Sharp [https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/news/venetian-mask-azerbaijan-censors-its-own-biennale-entry-2292827.html ''Venetian mask: Azerbaijan censors its own Biennale entry''], The Independent (London), 4 June 2011. Retrieved 2011-12-30.</ref> The officials said the works had been damaged during transportation.<ref>Dan Duray [http://www.observer.com/2011/06/aidan-salakhova-sculptures-to-be-removed-from-azerbaijan-biennale-pavilion/ ''Aidan Salakhova Sculptures To Be Removed From Azerbaijan Biennale Pavilion''], The New York Observer, 8 June 2011. Retrieved 2011-12-30.</ref> Commenting on the conflict, the pavilion curator Beral Madra stated that the concept of the removed sculptures had been misinterpreted by the government, and added that in over 25 years of curating she had not "ever experienced this kind of conflict".
In 2012, an image of an 1866 [[Gustave Courbet]] painting of the female genitals, entitled "[[L'Origine du monde|The Origin of the World]]", being posted on [[Facebook]] led to a legal dispute. After a French teacher posted an image of the painting, Facebook considered the image to be [[pornography|pornographic]] and suspended his account for violating its terms of use.<ref name="Stern">{{cite news |last=Stern |first=Mark Joseph |date=3 July 2012 |title=France Wants To Punish Facebook For Censoring A Painting of A Vagina. Terrible Idea. |url= |newspaper= Slate|location= |accessdate= }}</ref> ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' called the painting "a frank image of a vagina."<ref>{{cite news |last=Denson|first=G. Roger |date=2 February 2013 |title=150-Year-Old Painting STILL Too Graphic For Facebook |url= |newspaper=Huffington Post |location= |accessdate= }}</ref> Mark Stern of ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', who called the painting a stunning, brilliant "....cornerstone of the [[Realism art movement|French Realistic]] movement", states that the teacher then sued the website for allegedly violating his [[freedom of speech]].<ref name="Stern"/> In October 2013, artist Peter Reynosa created a "... red and white acrylic painting [that] depicts [pop singer] [[Madonna (singer)|Madonna]] painted in the shape of a defiant yonic symbol that looks like a vagina or vulva."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.edgemedianetwork.com/health_fitness/hiv_aids/features//150456/controversial_madonna_painting_opens_magnet_hiv_clinic_ar.t_show |title=Controversial Madonna Painting Opens Magnet HIV Clinic Art Show |last1=McCroy |first1=Winnie |last2= |first2= |date=10 October 2013 |website=www.edgemedianetwork.com|publisher=Edge Media Network |access-date= 19 October 2015|quote=}}</ref>
''[[101 Vagina]]'' is a 2013 black-and-white [[photo-book]] by Philip Werner, with a foreword by [[Toni Childs]]. The book contains 101 close-up nude photos shot in a non-provocative way, along with an accompanying story or message written by each woman about her vagina. The book's photos and stories were exhibited five times in Australia in 2013, with a US and Canadian tour in 2014 taking in six locations.<ref name="The Age Carbone">{{cite news|last1=Carbone|first1=Suzanne|title=Here's a lesson on vaginas 101|url=http://www.theage.com.au/national/melbourne-life/heres-a-lesson-on-vaginas-101-20130313-2g0ng.html|accessdate=29 June 2014|publisher=The Age|date=14 March 2013}}</ref><ref name="LBCP Hansen">{{cite news|last1=Hansen|first1=David|title=Hansen: The Shame and Joy of 101 Vaginas|url=http://www.coastlinepilot.com/opinion/tn-cpt-me-0425-hansen-20140424,0,144764.story|accessdate=29 June 2014|publisher=Laguna Beach Coastline Pilot|date=24 April 2014}}</ref> Werner was initially inspired by ''[[The Vagina Monologues]]'' and subjects were found via [[social media]] after Werner publicised his objective to create a book that had both an educational and celebratory goal.<ref name="The Age Carbone"/><ref>{{cite news|last1=Price|first1=Jenna|title=Bodybits 101: the personal side of Selfies|url=http://www.canberratimes.com.au/federal-politics/bodybits-101-the-personal-side-of-selfies-20121119-29m6x.html|work=Canberra Times|publisher=Fairfax Media|date=November 20, 2012}}</ref> Stories accompanying the photos discuss various themes, including ageing, pregnancy, [[Bikini waxing#Brazilian waxing|Brazilian waxing]], first sexual encounter and poor body image.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Bielski|first1=Zosia|title=Controversial exhibit unveils natural beauty of 101 women|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/relationships/controversial-exhibit-unveils-natural-beauty-of-101-women/article19147999/|work=Globe and Mail|publisher=Globe and Mail|date=June 12, 2014}}</ref> In Sydney the exhibition was visited by police responding to a complaint that the images were visible from the street.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Stubbs|first1=Vanessa|title=Hide the vagina|work=MX - Sydney|publisher=News Ltd|date=28 June 2013}}</ref><ref name="VAH Sano">{{cite news|last1=Sano|first1=Melanie|title=Police Monitor Vagina Exhibition|url=http://visual.artshub.com.au/news-article/news/visual-arts/police-monitor-vagina-exhibition-195868|accessdate=29 June 2014|publisher=Visual Arts Hub|date=1 July 2013}}</ref> Images were required to be censored as part of a group exhibition at [[The Sydney Fringe]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Hunt|first1=Adam|title=Vagina censorship offensive|url=http://www.altmedia.net.au/vagina-censorship-continues/83834|work=City Hub|publisher=Altmedia|date=September 19, 2013}}</ref>
[[Lena Marquise]] is a [[Russians|Russian]]-born, American visual and performance artist. Her work often covers the subjects of [[sex work]] and censorship, eliciting critical response for its controversial eroticism. In 2014, at Art Basel Miami, Marquise performed in an [[installation art]]work, "Body As Commodity", at VECTOR Gallery. In this artwork, she charged cellphones with her vagina. Musical artist Usher visited VECTOR Gallery on December 3, 2014, and he participated by charging his cell phone<ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/12/08/usher-art-vagina-_n_6290846.html |last= Frank |first= Priscilla|date= 8 December 2014|website= Huffington Post |title= Yes, Usher Charged His Phone In A Vagina. And No, It Was Not Art (NSFW) |accessdate=13 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.miaminewtimes.com/arts/meet-lena-marquise-the-performance-artist-behind-the-vagina-phone-charger-nsfw-6494788 |last= Duran |first= Jose|date= 5 December 2014|website= Miami New Times |title= Meet Lena Marquise, The Performance Artist Behind The Vagina Phone Charger (NSFW) |accessdate=13 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://gawker.com/usher-apparently-charged-his-phone-inside-a-womans-vagi-1666876109 |last=Sargent |first=Jordan |date=4 December 2014 |website=Gawker |title=Usher Charged His Phone Inside a Woman's Vagina at Art Basel |accessdate=13 April 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150413191643/http://gawker.com/usher-apparently-charged-his-phone-inside-a-womans-vagi-1666876109 |archivedate=13 April 2015 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.complex.com/style/2014/12/usher-charged-phone-inside-womans-vagina |last= Sanchez |first= Karizza|date= 4 December 2014|website= Complex |title= Usher May or May Not Have Charged His Phone With a Woman's Vagina at Art Basel, but It Sure Looks Like It |accessdate=13 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/the-juice/6363519/usher-vagina-phone-charger-art-basel-miami |last= |first= |date= 4 December 2014|website= Billboard |title= Usher Tests the Limits of Art With This Vagina Phone-Charger: NSFW |accessdate=13 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url= http://www.tmz.com/2014/12/04/usher-charges-iphone-from-naked-girl-photos/?adid=TMZ_Search_Results |last= |first= |date= 4 December 2014|website= TMZ |title= Usher Charges Iphone In Woman's Vagina |accessdate=13 April 2015}}</ref> inside the installation. It was the top story generated during Art Basel. VECTOR Gallery is curated and operated by [[JJ Brine]], who is an American [[visual artist]] and [[Contemporary art gallery|gallerist]]. He has drawn attention and critical response for his use of controversial Satanic imagery.<ref name="JJ Brine's 'VECTOR Gallery' In New York City">{{Cite web |url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/01/20/vector-gallery-jj-brine_n_4619179.html|publisher= The Huffington Post|title= JJ Brine's 'VECTOR Gallery' In New York City|accessdate=January 24, 2014}}</ref> Brine and Lena Marquise have previously collaborated on an erotic Satanic short film "The Visitor" written by Brine and performed by Marquise as the Biblical Mary where she masturbates with a knife while chanting patriarchal verses as a commentary on [[Female genital mutilation|mass genital mutilation]] in Egypt.<ref name="On JJ Brine's contribution to Satanic Artwork">{{Cite web |url= http://asthmamagazine.tumblr.com/post/114252631638/jjbrine-jj-brine-presents-the-visitor|publisher= Asthma Magazine|title= JJ Brine's 'VECTOR Gallery' Creation|accessdate=December 1, 2014}}</ref>
In Japan, artist [[Megumi Igarashi]] has drawn attention for her work featuring vaginas and vulvas, which she considers "overly hidden" in Japan compared to male genitalia. In July 2014, Igarashi was arrested by Japanese authorities for distributing 3D data of her vulva to contributors of her crowdsource campaign. She has also made vagina-themed sculptures.<ref name="The Guardian 15 July 2014">{{cite news|last1=McCurry|first1=Justin|title=Vagina selfie for 3D printers lands Japanese artist in trouble|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2014/jul/15/vagina-selfie-for-3d-printers-lands-japanese-artist-in-trouble|accessdate=15 July 2014|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=15 July 2014}}</ref> While police charged Igarashi for her vulva- and vagina-themed artworks, there are several phallus festivals in Japan in which participants parade with massive penis sculptures, a practice which is deemed acceptable by authorities.
In 2015 [[Anish Kapoor]], a [[Turner Prize]]-winning artist, created controversy with his sculpture entitled "Dirty Corner", a "massive steel funnel set in broken stone, placed in the garden of the...[[Palace of Versailles]]", which he claims is a depiction of the vagina of the former Queen of France.<ref>{{cite news |last=Frank |first=Priscilla|date=6 August 2015 |title=Anish Kapoor Put A Vagina Sculpture In Versailles' Garden, And People Are Unimpressed |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/entry/anish-kapoor-vagina-sculpture_n_7537204 |newspaper=The Huffington Post |location= |accessdate= }}</ref>

page.title: Wise Old Man and Wise Old Woman

contributor.username: Me, Myself, and I are Here

revision.comment: fixed [[MOS:DASH|dashes]] using a [[User:GregU/dashes.js|script]]
revision.text:
In [[Carl Jung]]'s theory of [[analytical psychology]], the '''Wise Old Woman and the [[Wise Old Man]]''' are [[archetypes]] of the [[Collective Unconscious]]. 'The "wise old woman"...[or] helpful "old woman" is a well-known symbol in myths and fairy tales for the wisdom of the eternal female nature'.<ref>Jolande Jacobi, "Symbols in an Individual Analysis" in C. G . Jung ed., ''Man and his Symbols'' (London 1978) p. 331 and p. 335</ref> The 'Wise Old Man, or some other very powerful aspect of eternal masculinity'<ref>Barbara Hannah, ''Striving towards Wholeness'' (Boston 1988) p. 291</ref> is her male counterpart.
==Individuation==
In Jung's thought, the [[individuation]] process was marked by a sequence of archetypes, each acquiring predominance at successive stages, and so reflecting what he termed an ascending psychic scale or 'hierarchy of the unconscious'.<ref>C. G. Jung, ''Two Essays on Analytical Psychology'' (London 1953) p. 226</ref> Thus, starting with the intermediate position of '[[Anima and animus|anima or animus]]...just as the latter have a higher position in the hierarchy than the [[Shadow (psychology)|shadow]], so wholeness lays claim to a position and a value superior'<ref>C. G. Jung, ''Aion'' (London 1959) p. 31</ref> still. The Wise Old Woman and Man, as what he termed "[[Mana]]" personalities or "supraordinate" personalities, stood for that wholeness of the self: 'the ''mother'' ("Primordial Mother" and "[[Earth Mother]]") as a supraordinary personality...as the "self"'.<ref>C. G. Jung, ''The Archetypes and the Collective Unconscious'' (London 1996) p. 183 and p. 187</ref>
As [[Marie-Louise von Franz|von Franz]] put it, 'If an individual has wrestled seriously and long enough with the anima (or animus) problem, so that he, or she, is no longer partially identified with it, the unconscious again changes its dominant character and appears in a new symbolic form representing the Self, the innermost nucleus of the personality. In the dreams of a woman this centre is usually personified as a superior female figure – a priestess, sorceress, earth mother, or goddess of nature or love. In the case of a man, it manifests itself as a masculine initiator and guardian (an Indian ''[[guru]]''), a wise old man, a spirit of nature and so forth'.<ref>M.-L. von Franz, "The Process of Individuation", in C. G. Jung ed., ''Symbols'' p. 207–8</ref>
The masculine initiator was described by Jung as 'a figure of the same sex corresponding to the father-imago...the mana-personality [a]s a dominant of the collective unconscious, the recognized archetype of the mighty man in the form of hero, chief, magician, medicine-man, saint, the ruler of men and spirits'.<ref>Jung, ''Two Essays'' p. 226-7</ref> Similarly, 'the wise Old Woman figure represented by [[Hecate]] or the [[Crone]] ...the Great Mother'<ref>Claire Douglas, ''The Old Woman's Daughter'' (Texas 2006) p. 42</ref> stood for an aspect of the mother-imago. The archetypes of the collective unconscious can thus be seen as inner representations of the same-sex parent – as an 'imago built up from parental influences plus the specific reactions of the child'.<ref>Jung, ''Two Essays'' p. 184-5</ref> Consequently, for the Jungian, 'the making conscious of those contents which constitute the archetype of the mana personality signifies therefore "for the man the second and true liberation from the father, for the woman that from the mother, and therewith the first perception of their own unique individuality"'.<ref>Jung, quoted in Jolande Jacobi, ''The Psychology of C. G. Jung: An Introduction'' (London 1946) p. 116</ref>
==Mana attributes: positive and negative==
In Jung's view, 'all archetypes spontaneously develop favourable and unfavourable, light and dark, good and bad effects'.<ref>Jung, ''Aion'' p. 267</ref> Thus 'the "good Wise Man" must here be contrasted with a correspondingly dark, chthonic figure',<ref>Jung, ''Aion'' p. 229</ref> and in the same way, the priestess or sibyl has her counterpart in the figure of 'the witch...called by Jung the "terrible mother"'.<ref>Northrop Frye, ''Anatomy of Criticism'' (Princeton 1971) p. 196</ref> Taken together, male and female, 'The hunter or old magician and the witch correspond to the negative parental images in the magic world of the unconscious'.<ref>Jung, ''Archetypes'' p. 235</ref>
But judgement of such collective archetypes must not be hasty. 'Just as all archetypes have a positive, favourable, bright side that points upwards, so also they have one that points downwards, partly negative and unfavourable, partly chthonic' – so that (for example) 'the sky-woman is the positive, the bear the negative aspect of the "supraordinate personality", which extends the conscious human being upwards into the celestial and downwards into the animal regions'.<ref>Jung, ''Archetypes'' p. 226 and p. 195</ref> Yet both aspects, celestial and chthonic, were (at least potentially) of equal value for Jung, as he sought for what he termed a "coniunctio oppositorum", a union of opposites. 'One does not become enlightened by imagining figures of light', he argued, 'but by making the darkness conscious'.<ref>C. G. Jung, ''[[Alchemical Studies]]'' (London 1978) p. 265-6</ref> Similarly with respect to the goal of the individuation process itself, 'as a totality, the self is a coincidentia oppositorum; it is therefore bright and dark and yet neither'.<ref>C. G. Jung, ''Mysterium Coniunctionis'' (London 1963) p. 108n</ref>
Coming to terms with the Mana figures of the collective unconscious – with the parental imagos – thus meant overcoming a psychic [[splitting (psychology)|splitting]], so as to make possible an acceptance of 'the Twisted side of the Great Mother'; an acceptance of the way 'the father contains both Kings at once...the Twisted King and the Whole King'.<ref>Robert Bly, ''Iron John'' (Dorset 1991) p. 115 and p. 113</ref>
